This course is for anyone wishing to gain a university-level computer networking and software development qualification. It is designed to provide a thorough grounding and is therefore a combination of the practical and theoretical aspects which reflect current practice and advances.

Modules

Year 1

  • Networked Communications Technologies (20  credits)
  • Databases & Information Systems (20  credits)
  • Converging Technology & Information (10  credits)
  • Human Computer Interaction (10  credits)
  • Website Development (20  credits)
  • Introduction to Programming (10  credits)
  • Numerical Solutions in Business (10  credits)
  • Personal & Employability Skills Development (20  credits)

 Year 2

  • Systems Analysis & Design (10  credits)
  • Object Orientated Programming (20  credits)
  • IT Management & Security (20  credits)
  • Application of E-Business Technologies (10  credits)
  • Multi-User Databases (10  credits)
  • Planning & Managing Projects (10  credits)
  • Project (20  credits)

Computer Networking option

  • Local & Wide Area Networks (20  credits)

 Software Development option

  • Visual Programming (10  credits)
  • Server Side Programming (10  credits)

course.dc:title: FdSc Computing, Networking and Software Development
course.abstract: FdSc Computing, Networking and Software Development
course.learningOutcome:
On successful completion and with the relevant work experience, you could find yourself heading towards a career with Government Communications Headquarters (GCHQ) or elsewhere working in  helpdesk support or as an IT systems analyst; a network manager or administrator in design or installation; a software or website developer or programmer.

Students who successfully complete the FdSc in Computing, Networking and Software Development may progress to Stage 3 level-6, the final stage at:

  • Camborne studying BSc(Hons) Computing Technologies or: 
  • Plymouth studying BSc (Hons) Computing

There are no bridging modules that need to be attended for progression.

If you progress to the final stage of a University of Plymouth programme then your stage one (level 4) and stage two marks (level 5 modules) will be taken into account in your final degree classification.

 

Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression. 

Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm)

Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
The FdSc in Computing, Networking & Software Development has been specifically designed and written to ensure that our graduates join industry fit for purpose, professional and with the ability to respond to its rapidly changing demands.

This is achieved by combining formal lectures and hands-on practical experience, embedding work-based learning and incorporating Cisco vendor qualifications. There is a variety of work-based learning opportunities available to you through both paid and unpaid internships which satisfy short term contracts and you will have the support of your employer and college staff. Internships range from software or website development to network security or installation.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - PPP Grades required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3.  Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language and mathematics: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 0845 22 32 567 or email enquiries@cornwall.ac.uk.

Information & Communication Technology
course.dc:title: CCNA Routing and Switching 1 - Introduction to Networks (Evenings)
course.learningOutcome: Progression onto CISCO CCNA Exploration - Routing Protocol and Concepts
course.mlo:objective:
This course runs for 15 weeks and comprise 30 hours guided learning within the Cisco Lab and, but also require the students to complete approx. 4 – 6 hours of home based online CISCO NetAcademy curriculum study a week. Each unit requires a student to achieve a 70% pass rate before progressing onto the next module, with each unit having to be studied succinctly.

Introduction to Networks introduces the architecture, structure, functions, components, and models of the internet and other computer networks. The principles and structure of IP addressing and the fundamentals of Ethernet concepts, media, and operations are introduced to provide a foundation for the curriculum. By the end of this part, you will be able to build simple LANs, perform basic configurations for routers and switches, and implement IP addressing schemes.
course.mlo:prerequisite: Students must have a broadband connection to the internet as the study material is only accessible online. The study material contains active content, which means that students will need to set up your firewall to allow pop-ups from the Cisco sites.

course.dc:description: This course provides a comprehensive, theoretical, and practical approach to learning the technologies and protocols needed to design and implement a converged switched network. Students learn about the hierarchical network design model and how to select devices for each layer. The course explains how to configure a switch for basic functionality and how to implement Virtual LANs, VTP, and Inter-VLAN routing in a converged network. The different implementations of Spanning Tree Protocol in a converged network are presented, and students develop the knowledge and skills necessary to implement a WLAN in a small-to-medium network.

course.dc:description: This course discusses the WAN technologies and network services required by converged applications in enterprise networks. The course uses the Cisco Network Architecture to introduce integrated network services and explains how to select the appropriate devices and technologies to meet network requirements. Students learn how to implement and configure common data link protocols and how to apply WAN security concepts, principles of traffic, access control, and addressing services. Finally, students learn how to detect, troubleshoot, and correct common enterprise network implementation issues
course.dc:subject: IT, ICT, Information Technology, Systems, IT support, IT systems, WAN, wireless area network, wireless, wifi,
Information & Communication Technology
course.dc:title: CCNA Routing & Switching 4 - Connecting Networks (Evenings)
course.mlo:objective:
This unit runs for 15 weeks and comprise 30 hours guided learning within the Cisco Lab and, but also require the students to complete approx. 4 – 6 hours of home based online CISCO NetAcademy curriculum study a week. Each unit requires a student to achieve a 70% pass rate before progressing onto the next module, with each unit having to be studied succinctly.

Connecting Networksdiscusses the WAN technologies and network services required by converged applications in a complex network. Completing this part will enable you to understand the selection criteria of network devices and WAN technologies to meet network requirements. You will learn how to configure and troubleshoot network devices and resolve common issues with data link protocols. You will also develop the knowledge and skills needed to implement IPSec and virtual private network (VPN) operations in a complex network.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
Prerequisites: CISCO CCNA Exploration Network Fundamentals, Routing Protocols and Concepts, and LAN Switching and Wireless

Students must have a broadband connection to the internet as the study material is only accessible online. The study material contains active content, which means that students will need to set up your firewall to allow pop-ups from the Cisco sites.

This course is intended for people who love reading and have their own stories to tell, both beginners and more experienced writers who feel in need of a little inspiration.  

Wednesdays from 6.30pm to 8.30pm

5 weeks  - 5th of October 2016 (start date changed)

5 weeks  - 22nd of February 2017

5 weeks - 26th of April 2017

Course fee - £50.00

course.dc:subject: Cornwall College
course.dc:title: Creative Writing (JP)
course.abstract: Intended for people who have stories to tell, both beginners and more experienced writers who feel in need of a little inspiration.
course.learningOutcome: After the course you can enrol onto one of our other courses we offer.
course.mlo:objective:
The sessions are divided into discussions and writing exercises designed to stimulate the imagination and generate ideas.  Each week students take home a short story or life writing extract and the sessions begin with a discussion of its particular qualities.  Every workshop has a different focus, writing descriptively about place or to evoke a particular emotion or creating believable characters and convincing dialogue.  Students are encouraged to share their writing and, as they grow in confidence, to contribute constructive ideas on the writing of others.  One session is spent exploring the different aspects of genre writing and the course concludes with a short introduction to editing and re-writing.  If desired, one week is set aside for poetry.

If all this sounds a little daunting please don't be put off, whatever level your writing has reached, our groups are friendly and above all, very enjoyable.

Puzzled by the huge range of artist's colours? This one-day Colour Mixing Workshop for Beginners explains which are the must-haves and which are the ones you can do without, and how to get the most out of this basic range in terms of mixing them.

Saturdays from 10.00am to 3.30pm.

course.dc:subject: Cornwall College
course.dc:title: Colour Mixing Workshop (JP)
course.abstract: Learn how to get the most out of a basic range of paint colours
course.learningOutcome: You can do one of our other recreational workshops or courses.
course.mlo:objective:
Understanding  how to use paint involves knowing a certain amount of colour theory, so hand in hand with using the materials, you'll be finding out about primary and secondary colours, complementary, tonal values, neutrals and tints, and discovering how the theories behave with the actual stuff!

The workshop is designed for painters in either oils or acrylics.  For reasons of drying times, acrylics are an easier option for the day, and quality artist's acrylics will be supplied, but everything you learn on the course will apply equally to oils.  Please bring overalls, paint-rags, some brushes, and a palette and palette knife for mixing, if you have them.

Starts 19th January 2017 - 10 weeks  - £160.00

course.dc:subject: welding skills , arc , mig weld , welding , fabrication ,
Cornwall College
course.dc:title: Welding Skills - ARC/MIG (JP)
course.abstract: A series of Welding sessions leading to a qualification
course.learningOutcome: You could enrol on to one of our other recreational courses or workshops that we offer.
course.mlo:objective:
You will gain a basic understanding of basic ARC welding, covering downhand single weld beads, re-joining of runs, build-up weld runs to form a weld pad, welding inside and outside corner joints and horizontal/vertical fillet welds on 3-12mm thick plate.

The MIG welding section will cover the setting-up of the machine (volts and wire speed etc) for correct operation to deposit welds in the downhand, horizontal/vertical and vertical weld positions, material thickness 1-6mm.

course.dc:title: British Sign Language SIGNAT Certificate Level 2
course.learningOutcome: Once you have successfully completed this course you can use sign language in everyday life for business and social communication. You may wish to progress onto British Sign Language Level 3 NVQ.
course.mlo:objective: This course is designed to enable students to acquire more knowledge of British Sign Language and should enable you to: participate in a conversation using sign language without frequent repetition or misunderstanding; demonstrate an appropriate selection of vocabulary and grammatical principles; convey information clearly and accurately; understand a signed narrative without major omissions or inaccuracies; respond accurately to signed questions relating to a signed narrative; describe the content of a sequence of pictures using sign language; demonstrate a range of vocabulary clearly and accurately and demonstrate a selection of grammatical principles clearly and accurately.
course.mlo:prerequisite: Applicants for this course should ideally have passed the Stage 1 examination and will be expected to be familiar with the Stage 1 British Sign Language curriculum. If you at all unsure as to your suitability for this course then please enquire and the programme manager will be able to discuss this with you as entry for this course is at the discretion of the course manager if you do not have the stated entry requirements.

course.dc:description: The course is primarily for students who wish to gain valuable qualifications without having to attend College full time. GCSE Maths and English are probably the most important qualifications you'll ever take! Did you know that most employers still require you to have achieved a Grade C or above in GCSE Maths and English? Did you also know that even if you have achieved a degree in Higher Education, you still need GCSE Maths and English to become a teacher?
course.dc:subject: Short Qualifications
course.dc:title: Mathematics (Linear) B AQA GCSE Level 2
course.abstract: The course is primarily for students who wish to gain valuable qualifications without having to attend College full time.
course.learningOutcome: GCSE maths provides a foundation for AS and A-level study in Mathematics. GCSEs are universally recognised and allow the development of skills considered by many employers.
course.mlo:objective: Mathematics GCSE includes transferable skills which may help you in your other subjects. You will learn how to use problem-solving strategies and to work efficiently by breaking down complex situations into simpler steps. You will be able to explore, identify and interpret mathematical situations and communicate them clearly.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal qualifications or experience necessary to gain entry onto this course. You will need a high degree of self motivation and enthusiasm for the subject area. You will also be invited for an informal interview to determine suitability.

course.dc:description:
Duchy College has been training within the childrens workforce for over 17 years. We have past students working in a range of employment positions and provisions including Nursery, Primary, Pre school settings throughout Devon and Cornwall, as well as other careers within the childrens workforce.

We aim to set high standards in our teaching in order to ensure that our students when they qualify, are striving for outstanding practice in their work settings. We have trained whole staff teams at levels 2, 3 and 4 in settings which, as a result of their excellent practice, have been graded by Ofsted as Outstanding; these settings have included locally Pensilva Pre School, Ducklings Pre School, Kingfisher Nursery.

Our teaching and assessment team are all experienced practitioners and have all worked within the Early Years sector in positions such as Nursery and Pre School Managers, Primary Teaching, Forest School Leader, Private Nanny and Home Based Child Care. All teaching staff undertake regular professional updating within their chosen sector ensuring that students have the most up to date teaching available.

All students who work with children are required to have a DBS check prior to starting the course which costs in the region of £44 (this can be arranged through the college).

This course is for applicants who wish to gain Early Years Educator status as a fully qualified member of the Early Years team in roles such as Keyperson, Nursery or Pre-School Supervisor in employment within the Early Years Sector or to progress on to Higher level qualfications that lead to careers in other areas of the Children and Young people's Workforce.

 

Some applicants will already hold a level 2 Certificate for the Children and Young People's Workforce, others may be volunteering, as yet unqualified, and wish to become employed or to count towards level 3 staff to child ratios in the setting. The profile of learner is often parents who wish to return to the workforce with a change of career which supports their family commitments to children who are at nursery or school. The course mirrors the school day in terms of term times and hours of delivery.
course.dc:subject: Early Years
course.dc:title: Early Years Practitioner (Early Years Educator) CG Diploma Level 3
course.abstract: Gain Early Years Educator status or progress to higher qualifications
course.learningOutcome: Students can go into employment within the Early Years Sector in positions within Primary Schools, Nursery or Pre-Schools, among other settings. The Diploma for the Early Years Practitioner (Early Years Educator) is considered a full and relevant qualification for working with children aged birth to 7 years. Those who successfully gain the full Diploma may progress into Higher Education by undertaking the Foundation Degree for the Children and Young People's Workforce
course.mlo:objective:
Your course includes weekly attendance at college, for one day each week from 9am - 2.30pm, term time only. At college you will study the Mandatory units which make up the Early Years Educator which include: Developing Effective Study Skills; Promote Partnership working with parents;  Model, promote and support positive behaviour with chidlren; Principles of Safeguarding policies and procedures in the early years sector; Working in partnership with colleagues and other professionals in early years settings; Plan and implement activities, play opportunities and educational programmes in an early years setting; Promoting childrens health and welfare in an early years setting; Promoting health and safety of children;Promote childrens speech and language and communication development; Support organisational requiremetns for recording storing and disclosing information and providing reports in an early years setting; mSupporting chidlrens creative and imaginative play experiences; Supporting chidlren experiencing transitions and significant events in the early years sector; Continuous professional development using Reflective Practice; Theories which underpin practice in the Early years sector; Child Development from conception to 7 years 11 months; Observation and assessment in the Early years. 

 In addition to attendance at college you will receive regular assessments of written assignment work , portfolio evidence and observations of your working practice within your work setting.
course.mlo:prerequisite: Applicants should ideally have achieved GCSE Grade C in English and Maths before they start the course, but could study these alongside the level 3.  Employers will ask to see your GCSE results and can only include level 3 qualified staff in their higher staff:child ratios if they hold ‘C’ grade English Language and maths.  Throughout the course you will need to be either employed or be volunteering in an Early Years setting for at least 2 half days or one full day each week whilst attending college on one day.  This needs to increase to 2 days each week once the attendance at college ceases in July of the first year.  You will need to have gained approximately 700 hours in an early years setting whilst you are working towards your qualification.

course.dc:description:
Expert tutors who are experienced in health care, small group learning sets, ongoing  guidance and support  throughout the course and access to books and computers ( Knowledge Spa library and Cornwall College).

Nine 4 hour tutor led sessions from 2-6pm at the Knowledge Spa, Treliske.

Contact Kate Poole  01209 617758

People who are either working in a care role or who want to move into a care role but need some experience before applying. It's a module that anyone who has an interest in the human body could do, and also is good as a foundation/refresher for anyone going on to study any course that involves physiology, pathology or human biology.
course.dc:title: The Biology of Health
course.learningOutcome: This module is part of the FdSc in healthcare practice. You may wish to carry on your studies and undertake the full foundation degree this would then equip you with the relevant qualifications to be considered for a band 4 post (assistant practitioner) within a care setting.
course.mlo:objective:
The course is fact based and will cover:

  • Human Growth and Development
  • How normal body functions are maintained   throughout life including
  • The nature and role of blood,
  • The rate and depth of breathing,
  • The nervous system,
  • The different types of hormones,
  • The liver, blood sugars and metabolism,
  • Water balance and the function of the kidneys.

 

 

 

 

You will be encouraged to read around the subject and, where possible, put into practice your new learning and understanding. There is an in-class test  and you will be required to write a short case study.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
Yyou should be in a care role (or wanting to move into a care role or strengthen application for a health or biology /psychology based degree. Have a level 3 qualifiation, level 2 in English and Maths (preferable).

Each learner will be contacted by a Guidance Mentor to ensure that this is the right course for them and to help prepare them for the course.

course.dc:description: The aim of this qualification is to recognise the skills, knowledge and competence required for an individual to work unsupervised as a personal trainer. This includes being able to offer one-to-one training, baseline assessment, nutritional advice and progressive programming which is specific to the individual needs of a client.

St Austell

Day Course - Monday & Tuesday - 9am - 4.30pm (13 weeks)

Evening - Monday - 6 - 9pm (30 weeks)

Camborne

Day Course - Wednesday & Thursday - 9am - 4.30pm (13 weeks)

At Cornwall College we pride ourselves in the expert teaching we provide our students with but also the excellent support that we provide alongside all of our programmes, treating all students equally and fairly.

Your attendance, attitude, aptitude and performance on your course will be monitored regularly by your course tutor and course manager. If any of the above are a cause for concern your course tutor will address these with you.

If support is required it may be provided on a one-to-one basis or extra revision sessions in the lead up to the exams for those requesting it for example. If required you may be placed on a supportive action plan to get you back on track - our aim is to get you to achieve.

The department also has a senior tutor who may be involved in discipline matters or to provide support if required.
course.dc:subject: Personal Trainer Training Instructor, gym, fitness, toning,
Sport
course.dc:title: Personal Training YMCA Certificate Level 3
course.abstract: CYQ Level 3 Personal Training Diploma
course.mlo:assessment:
You will be taught by highly qualified and voacionally experienced lecturers at both sites with members of our team National CYQ Judges for their annual championships - learn from the best!

You will be assessed via a variety of methods as listed below:

1 x A&P Theory Exam

1 x Nutrition Theory Exam

Formative, mock exams will be carried out regulary to ensure you are on track. 

Nutrition Knowledge Questions Worksheet and Case Study

Programming Knowledge Questions Worksheet

Personal Training Programme –

  • Client Profile
  • 4 Programme Cards
  • 12 Week Programme Overview
  • Physical Measurements

Delivery Knowledge Questions Worksheet

Summative Observation of Practical Teaching – Practical Exam
course.learningOutcome: All courses allow successful learners to apply to be on the Register of Exercise Professionals (REPS). This means that they meet strict industry standards to deliver exercise advice and/or demonstration. To protect the public, all registered exercise professionals are bound by a code of ethical practice that covers professional standards and conduct.
course.mlo:objective:
Learners will cover:

    • anatomy and physiology including:
      - the heart and circulatory system
      - the musculoskeletal system
      - postural and core stability
      - the nervous, endocrine and energy systems and their relation to exercise and health

    • how to maintain health, safety and welfare in a variety of fitness environments, including the safeguarding of children and vulnerable adult

    • how to programme safe and effective exercise for a range of clients, the health benefits of physical activity and the importance of healthy eating

    • how to communicate with clients effectively, and motivate clients to adhere to an exercise programme

    • how to apply the principles of nutrition to support client goals as part of an exercise and physical activity programme

    • how to design, manage, and adapt a personal training programme with apparently healthy adults of all ages

    • how to deliver exercise and physical activity as part of a programme for apparently healthy adults of all ages
course.mlo:prerequisite:
You must hold a relevant level 2 fitness instructor - gym based qualification.

A grade C or level 2 equivalent in English

A grade C or level 2 equivalent in Maths is desirable - if you do not hold this qualifications the college can support you to complete this alongside this course as part of your study programme*

*more information available on request

Candidates must be over 16 at time of interview and have a passion for the fitness industry

1 x A&P Theory Exam

1 x Nutrition Theory Exam

Formative, mock exams will be carried out regulary to ensure you are on track. 

Nutrition Knowledge Questions Worksheet and Case Study

Programming Knowledge Questions Worksheet

Personal Training Programme –

  • Client Profile
  • 4 Programme Cards
  • 12 Week Programme Overview
  • Physical Measurements

Delivery Knowledge Questions Worksheet

Summative Observation of Practical Teaching – Practical Exam

course.dc:description:
The BSc (Hons) Sport, Health and Exercise Science (Level 6 top-up) programme is a fantastic new option for students aspiring to work in the following industries; health referral, teaching, leisure industry, sports performance. The programme will also allow learners to gain transferable skills to support their application to wider employment opportunities.

This course is focussed on the practical application (including work placment) of theoretical constructs in an industry relevant manner with the vision to enhance both employability and entrepreneurial acumen. Students will get the opportunity to apply theory to practice across the provision including laboratory and field-based testing. Learners will carry out primary and secondary research throughout the programme; including the honours dissertation where graduates chose topics of interest aligned with their subject specialisms. Work-based practices will be mandatory in the Sport, Health and Exercise Sciences core module with the option to carry out physical education, health promotion, sport performance/development placements; this will be supported with coaching placements in the Applied Coaching optional module.
course.dc:subject: Sport Health Exercise Science
Sport
course.dc:title: BSc (Hons) Sport, Health and Exercise Science (Top Up)
course.mlo:objective:
The new programme will include the following mandatory modules;

Honours Dissertation (40 credit) Lifelong Health (20 credits) and Sport, Health and Exercise Sciences (20 credit).

The rest of the programme will consist of a choice of four optional modules; learners can pick two to suit their pre-requisite qualification and progression aspiration.

Module options include: Application of Sport Psychology, Sport and Exercise Physiology, Principles of Nutrition and Applied Coaching.

This course is focussed on the practical application of theoretical constructs in an industry relevant manner with the vision to enhance both employability and entrepreneurial acumen. Students will get the opportunity to apply theory to practice across the provision including laboratory and field-based testing. Learners will carry out primary and secondary research throughout the programme; including the honours dissertation where graduates chose topics of interest aligned with their subject specialisms. Work-based practices will be mandatory in the Sport, Health and Exercise Sciences core module with the option to carry out physical education, health promotion, sport development and sport performance placements; this will be supported with coaching placements in the Applied Coaching optional module.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
Relevant foundation degree or HND.


Applicants will require prior learning in two of the following three modules: Exercise Physiology, Sports Psychology, and Nutrition from their relative Foundation Degree or HND ideally at least 20 credits at Level 4 or 5.

course.dc:title: Sports Development and Coaching UOPLY FdSc Level 5
course.abstract: FdSc Sports Development and Coaching
course.learningOutcome: On successful completion of the course you will have the opportunity to carry on with your education by taking the final year of an honours degree or move into employment in the expanding world of sports development and coaching. The programme and specifically its work-based elements will provide you with excellent opportunities to network for your future career.
course.mlo:objective:
The course has been designed with the UK Coaching Certificate guidelines at its core, so you will be engaged in the advancement of your coaching ability, while gaining your degree.

Opportunities are provided to develop your knowledge of the science behind coaching across a range of modules that allow you to apply the underpinning theories and put them into practice.

Learning methods include working as part of a group or as an individual throughout the programme to develop your employability and academic skills. Working with local school groups and organising events within the community will be part of your study. You will also conduct lab-based experiments e.g. dissections and practical fitness testing and training to investigate the effects of exercise on the body systems.

The programme may provide opportunities for you to gain relevant National Governing Body qualifications in, for example:

  • FA Level 1
  • CYQ Level 2 Gym Instructor
  • CYQ LEVEL 3 Personal Trainer
  • MIAS Mountain Bike Leaders

Valuable work-related experience is undertaken as part of the programme to develop your employability skills and experience to ensure that you meet the needs of your future career choice and employers.

A partnership with a well-established UK activity centre provides the opportunity for you to undertake a paid summer placement from April or May to September in your first year

The course has been designed with the UK Coaching Certificate guidelines at its core, so students will be engaged in the advancement of their coaching ability, while gaining the foundation degree. The course will provide opportunities for students to gain relevant NGBs in sport, (e.g. FA Level 1 & HSLA), fitness (e.g. CYQ L2 Gym Instructor & L3 Personal Trainer) and outdoor (e.g. MIAS Mountain Bike Leaders or GNAS Level 1 Archery). 

Valuable work-related experience is undertaken as part of the course to develop your employability skills and experience to ensure that you meet the needs of your future career choice and employers.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - PPP Grades required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3.  Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language and mathematics: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

Potential students must be prepared to be actively involved with the many practical opportunities whilst on the course.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 0845 22 32 567 or email enquiries@cornwall.ac.uk.

A Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check will be a mandatory requirement after you have been accepted on the programme. It is your responsibility to undertake this before commencing your study.

course.dc:description: The FdSc Sport, Health and Fitness programme is a new two year course validated by the University of Plymouth, but taught entirely at Cornwall College Camborne. It is delivered through a variety of formal lectures, small group seminars and practical sessions. The course has been designed, in conjunction with industry experts, to equip successful graduates with a range of skills and knowledge to allow them to find employment in a range of jobs within the Sport and Leisure sector, as well as the rapidly growing Health and Fitness industry. Progression onto a third year degree programme, within the University of Plymouth is also an option for successful graduates after the programme. Assessment is through written assignments, presentations, practical and theoretical exams, and a research project in the second year. Students on the programme also get assessed working on real life projects, such as coaching sport in local primary and secondary schools, or developing sport and physical activity in the wider community. All lecturing staff on the programme are qualified to degree level, and many to Postgraduate level as well as being involved in research and professional development in the areas of sports science and injuries, coaching and sports psychology.

Modules

Year 1

  • Personal & Employability Skills Development (20 credits)
  • Sport & Fitness Coaching (20 credits)
  • Applied Anatomy & Physiology (20 credits)
  • Exercise Physiology 1 (20 credits)
  • Health & Fitness Applications (20 credits)
  • Biomechanics (10 credits)
  • Sports Development I (10 credits)

Year 2

  • Special Study (20 credits)
  • Research Methods (10 credits)
  • Facility Management (10 credits)
  • Nutrition (20 credits)
  • Measurement & Evaluation of Fitness (10 credits)
  • Exercise Physiology 2 (10 credits)
  • Inclusive Sport & Exercise (10 credits)
  • Sports Injuries & Therapies (20 credits)
  • Psychology of Sport and Exercise (10 credits)

course.abstract: The course has been designed in conjunction with industry experts
course.learningOutcome:
Successful graduates can find employment in the wider sport, leisure and fitness industry, either as gym based fitness trainers or in junior managerial positions. Careers in sports development or coaching are also possible. Teacher training is also an option for those graduates who progress on to, and successfully complete, a final year top-up to an honours degree.

Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression.

Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm)

Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
The FdSc Sport, Health & Fitness is a two year course delivered through a variety of formal lectures, small group seminars and practical sessions.

You will be in a class size of around 20 students and attend lectures and seminars over approximately two days per week.

The programme is intended to enable you to critically, systematically and reflectively analyse issues surrounding sport and exercise science and health and fitness.

You will also learn to design, administer and evaluate sport related strategies at a variety of levels.

Assessment is through written assignments, presentations, practical and theoretical exams, and a research project in your second year.

You will also be assessed working on real life projects: coaching sport in local primary and secondary schools, or developing sport and physical activity in the wider community.

All lecturing staff on the programme are qualified to degree level and many to postgraduate level as well as being involved in research and professional development in the areas

Potential students must be prepared to be actively involved with the many practical opportunities whilst on the course.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

This foundation degree has been designed to meet the developing roles within the sector for those working with children, young people and their families. It is anticipated that applicants will be developing careers within the children's workforce and seeking a qualification which will facilitate the opportunity to explore a wide range of career directions, which may include those in Nursery or Primary education, care, special needs, family support, outdoor learning or play, among others. It may be of particular interest to practitioners already in employment who would like to study in college on one day a week and undertake their research and self study in their work or home environments. 

The successful completion of this course qualifies you to level 5.  You may then if you wish continue with a top up course to obtain a full Honours degree at level 6.

Modules

Year 1

Core

  • Reflective Practice (20 credits)
  • Interpersonal & Communication Skills (20 credits)
  • Safeguarding Children & Young People (20 credits)
  • Developmental Perspectives (20 credits)
  • Personal & Employability Skills Development (20 credits)

 Optional (choose one)

  • Constructions of Childhood & Youth (20 credits)
  • Working with children & Families (20 credits)
  • Forest School (20 credits)
  • Risk Versus Challenge in the Outdoors (20 credits)
  • Sport & Young People (20 credits)
  • Supporting Learners Learning (20 credits)
  • Curriculum Issues (20 credits)
  • New Learning Technologies (20 credits)
  • Behaviour for Learning (20 credits)
  • Special Study (1) (20 credits)
  • The Third Sector (20 credits)
  • Supporting Special Educational Needs (20 credits)
  • Entrepreneurship & Applied Practice (20 credits)

 Year 2

Core

  • Supporting Transitions (20 credits)
  • Multi-agency Collaboration (20 credits)
  • Inclusive Practice (20 credits)
  • Applied Research Practice Project (20 credits)

Optional (choose two)

  • Outdoor Experiential Learning (20 credits)
  • Crime, Young People & the Law (20 credits)
  • The Lead Professional (20 credits)
  • Working with Disaffected Young People (20 credits)
  • The Learning Mentor Role in Schools (20 credits)
  • Role of the Play-based Curriculum (20 credits)
  • Psychology of Learning & Teaching (20 credits)

course.learningOutcome:
This programme is intended to provide you with the knowledge, understanding and skills you'll need to gain employment in this highly competitive field and prepare you for honours degree study.

Possible Further Study (subject to availability)

  • BA (Hons) Education & Training final year at Cornwall College Camborne
  • BA (Hons) Early Childhood Studies at University of St Marks & St Johns
  • BA (Hons) Education Studies at Plymouth University
  • BSc (Hons) Combined Social Science final year at Cornwall College Camborne
  • BSc (Hons) Health, Community and Social Sciences final year at Cornwall College Camborne 

Careers include: 

  • Teacher (primary)
  • Teaching assistant
  • Early years practitioner
  • Early years manager
  • Further education lecturer
  • Social care worker
  • Volunteer
  • Advice & Guidance
  • SEN teacher

 Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression. Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm) Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
The course will develop essential understanding of the key concepts and principles of the Common Core in relation to the children's workforce, as well as allowing you to specialise in their particular field.

You will be assessed using a mixture of methods appropriate to the modules: technical and analytical reports, presentations, practical work-based research and reflection, workshop exercises, case studies and essays. You will also be called upon to present your work to your peers.

The course will develop essential understanding of the key concepts and principles of the Common Core in relation to the Children's workforce, as well as allowing students to specialise in their particular field.

In Year 1 you will study the following Core Modules: Developmental Perspectives, Interpersonal and Communication Skills, Reflective Practice, Safeguarding Children & Young People, Personal and Employability Skills Development. 

You will select one option from a range which could include: Constructions of Childhood and Youth, Working with Children and Families, Forest School, Supporting Learners Learning, Curriculum Issues, Behaviour for Learning and others. 

In Year 2 you will develop your study to further Core Modules: Supporting Transitions, Multi-Agency Collaboration, Inclusive Practice, Applied Research Practice Project. 

Two further options will be selected from:  Outdoor Experiential Learning, The Learning Mentor Role in Schools, Role of the Play-based Curriculum, Unlocking Creativity in the Classroom and others.  

Information on the wide range of options available which may support your chosen carer direction is available on request in the course handbook.  Options are selected based on the interest and demand of the student group.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - PPP Grades required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3. NVQ 3 or National Diploma in Children's Care Learning and Development, NVQ 3 in Working with Children and Young People considered on an individual basis. Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language and mathematics: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 0845 22 32 567 or email enquiries@cornwall.ac.uk.

A Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check will be a requirement after you have been accepted on the programme, however this may be arranged through your place of work, work placement or on an individual basis.

course.mlo:objective:
The course will develop essential understanding of the key concepts and principles of the common core of skills and knowledge for the children and young people's workforce, as well as allowing you to specialise in a particular field.

You will study modules in developmental perspectives, interpersonal and communication skills, reflective practice, safeguarding children and young people, personal and employability skills development and one other.

You will be assed using a mixture of methods appropriate to the modules: this could include technical and analytical reports, presentations, practical work based research and reflection, workshop exercises, case studies and essays. You will often need to present work to your fellow students.

course.dc:description:
This course is for experienced learning support staff who undertake a varied range of responsibilities at school under the direction of the class teacher.  They will contribute to planning, implementing and evaluating learning activities and will work alongside the teacher to support whole class activities, as well as working on their own with individuals or groups of pupils.

This course is for experienced learning support staff who undertake a varied range of responsibilities at school under the direction of the class teacher.  They will contribute to planning, implementing and evaluating learning activities and will work alongside the teacher to support whole class activities, as well as working on their own with individuals or groups of pupils.

course.dc:title: Specialist Support for Teaching and Learning in Schools CG Diploma Level 3
course.abstract: Specialist Support for Teaching and Learning in Schools CG Diploma Level 3
course.learningOutcome: Upon successful completion of this course, you may be able to gain employment as a senior teaching assistant (eg Lead TA).  Having gained sufficient school experience you will have the opportunity to progress onto the Foundation Degree for Children and Young Peoples Workforce.
course.mlo:objective:
You will study on a part-time basis, attending workshops and carrying out some home study alongside your work in the classroom.  You will need to be able to spend 1-2 hrs per week on building your portfolio.  You will be offered regular tutorial support.

You will work towards:

Nationally recognised units from the QCF (Qualifications and Credit Framework) to achieve the Level 3 Diploma in Specialist Support in Teaching and Learning in Schools by attending taught sessions that will cover key aspects to include:

  • Support learning activities
  • Promote children and young people's positive behaviour
  • Support assessment for learning
  • Understand child and young person development
  • Understand how to safeguard the wellbeing of children and young people
  • Functional Skills (unless already achieved at GCSE) - Level 2 Mathematics, Level 2 English and Level 2 ICT.
  • Employment Responsibilities and Rights (ERR)
  • Personal Learning and Thinking Skills (PLTS)
course.mlo:prerequisite:
Support staff will need to have sufficient language, literacy and numeracy skills at the level required to support pupils' learning.  The formal entry requirement for the Advanced Apprenticeship is Level 1 in English, Mathematics and ICT.  Relevant skills and attributes include:

  • To have experience, an interest and commitment to working with children and/or young people
  • Ability to relate well to children, young people and adults
  • Willing to reflect on your own practice, learn and apply that learning in the workplace

course.mlo:objective:
This qualification comprises 9 mandatory units including:

  • Equality, diversity and inclusion

  • Role of the social care worker

  • Health and safety

  • Duty of care

College sessions provide underpinning knowledge and assessment is by assignment.

course.dc:title: Preparing to Work in Adult Social Care CG Certificate Level 3
course.learningOutcome: progression would be onto the Health and Social Care Diploma Level 3.
course.mlo:objective:
This qualification comprises 9 mandatory units including:

  • Communication
  • Equality, diversity and inclusion
  • Personal development
  • Role of the social care worker
  • Handling information
  • Health and safety
  • Safeguarding
  • Duty of care
  • Person centred approaches

 They do not confirm competence but relate to the knowledge elements covered in the mandatory units of the Health and Social Care Diploma at L3. They can be used as standalone qualifications or as part of the Apprenticeship in Health & Social Care at Level 3.

To achieve the Level 3 Certificate in Preparing to Work in Adult Social Care (QCF) candidates will need to complete 21 credits from 9 mandatory units

College sessions are provided and assessment is by assignment.
course.mlo:prerequisite: A previous Level 2 is advised but not essential. Inital assessment and an interview will be required.

course.learningOutcome:

course.mlo:objective:
The Diploma consists of separate units that have been allocated various credit values.  To gain the diploma you will need to achieve a total of 50 credits. 

You will complete eleven mandatory units that include: 

  • Communication

You will then select from a selection of optional units that are suitable to your job role.

Competence will be assessed in the workplace.

Health & Social Care

course.learningOutcome: You could progress onto the Level 3 Diploma in Health and Social Care.
course.mlo:objective:
The Diploma consists of separate units that have been allocated various credit values.  To gain the diploma you will need to achieve a total of 46 credits. 

You will complete nine mandatory units that include: 

  • Communication
  • Health and Safety
  • Duty of Care
  • Record keeping
  • confidentiality
  • Safeguarding
  • Equality and inclusion

You will then have the choice of several optional units to meet your role.  There are different routes that you will be able to select.  These include:

Knowledge sessions will be provided at college for you to attend. 

Competence will be assessed in the workplace.

You will need to attend an interview prior to acceptance on this course.

course.dc:description:
This course can be available across all our localities at Camborne, St Austell and Saltash and may also be available at other locations.

Various start dates are available.

Please contact us for fees and funding information.

The Level 3 Diploma in Dental Nursing focuses on direct chair side work and support during a range of dental treatments: the student would need to have some considerable knowledge and skills in relation to dental equipment, instruments and materials and be able to work as a key member of the oral healthcare team. The course has been built on a number of principles: encourage access by those groups of staff for whom they are designed; promote good quality practice and high quality services; help the sector respond to changing requirements; encourage transfer and progression; be consistent with future legislation for statutory registration.

This course is suitable for 16 plus who have an employed position in Dental Nursing. It consists of 15 units, plus an online mandatory examination that assesses underpinning knowledge.

The units studied are all mandatory.

This course is offered as a Level 3 Diploma in Dental Nursing (City and Guilds). We also offer the apprenticeship route, contact us for more information.
course.dc:subject: dental, dentist,
Health & Social Care
course.dc:title: Dental Nursing CG Diploma Level 3
course.abstract: Level 3 Dental Nursing Diploma
course.learningOutcome: On completion of the course you will become a qualified dental nurse to be registered with the GDC.
course.mlo:objective:
You will study the following units

  • Emergency First Aid Skills
  • Ensure your own actions reduce risks to health and safety
  • Prepare and maintain environment, instruments, and equipment for clinical dental procedures
  • Offer information and support to individuals on the protection of their oral health
  • Provide chairside support during the assessment of patients' oral health
  • Contribute to the production of dental images
  • Provide chairside support during the prevention and control of periodontal disease and caries and the restoration of cavities
  • Provide chairside support during the provision of fixed and removable prostheses
  • Provide chairside support during non-surgical endodontic treatment
  • Provide chairside support during the extraction of teeth and minor oral surgery
  • Principles of infection control in the dental environment
  • Assessment of oral health and treatment planning
  • Dental radiography
  • Scientific principles in the management of oral health diseases and dental
 Classes are provided in College. Assessment is via a portfolio of evidence, observations in the workplace and an online examination.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
You need to be working in a dental practice.

Initial assessments and an interview will be required.

course.dc:description: A Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check will be a mandatory requirement after you have been accepted on the programme, which the College will support you with.

This course is suitable for learners who work or want to work as an Assistant Practitioner in Healthcare and related services and who want to extend their knowledge, skills and potential to earn and people new to working in care who have completed recent academic study and/or experience.
course.dc:title: Assistant Practitioners in Healthcare CG Diploma Level 5 (Higher Apprenticeship)
course.learningOutcome: On completion of this qualification, learners may progress onto further qualifications specific to their work context. A wide range of qualifications are available such as higher education qualifications or other work-related education and training to support Continuing Professional Development.
course.mlo:objective:
To achieve the Level 5 Diploma for Assistant Practitioners in Healthcare, learners must achieve 120 credits studying a range of units such as:

Safeguarding, professional development, functions of the body, communication, health and saftey, nutrition and fluid balance, principles and philosophy of healthcare, equality, diversity and inclusion, infection prevention and control. You will also undertake a research project as well as employment and personal learning skills.

Learners will attend College 1 day a month, with additional support sessions planned throughout the year, with the rest of your course and work based skills being carried out in the workplace.

Throughout the programme of study  learners will be assigned an assessor who will carry out observations in the workplace against set competences, as well as meet with your mentor to discuss progress.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
Applicants should be employed for at least 15 hours (2 days) per week in the healthcare sector.  For learners not employed in a setting where they will be able to learn and practice clinical skills, a weekly placement for the duration of the course will need to be arranged with a suitable mentor to support them through the practice elements of the programme. Learners will be supported by the appropriate College staff to find a suitable placement. This will need to be agreed with the Course Manager on application with a supporting letter from your employer/work placement provider.

In addition learners should have a minimum of a relevant level 3 qualification or equivalent and preferably have previous experience of working or volunteering in a care or health setting. GCSEs required at grade C or above in English language and mathematics.

presentation.dc:title: Assistant Practitioners in Healthcare CG Diploma Level 5 (Higher Apprenticeship)

This qualification fulfils the regulatory requirement for managers of adult residential and domiciliary services and replaces the NVQ Level 4 care and the leadership and management qualifications.

This qualification is for those already working in health or health and social care as a manager or assistant / deputy manager. You are responsible for running a facility that provides services for adults.
course.dc:title: Leadership for Health and Social Care and Children and Young People's Services CG Diploma Level 5
course.learningOutcome: Following this course you may wish to progress on to a degree level course or an advanced management course.
course.mlo:objective:
The Diploma is made up of a range of units across diffrerent subject areas such as:

    • Communication
    • Professional Development
    • Equality, Diversity and Inclusion
    • Health, Safety and Risk Management
    • Working in Partnership in Health and Social Care
    • Lead and manage a team
    • Develop professional supervision
    • Lead Practice that supports positive outcomes
    • Safeguarding and Protection of Vulnerable Adults
    • Lead Person-Centred Practice
    • Recruitment and Selection
    • Facilitate Coaching and Mentoring
    • Manage Induction in Health and Social Care
course.mlo:prerequisite:
You need to be already working in health and social care as a manager or assistant / deputy manager. You will be responsible for running a facility that provides services for adults and have a good level of literacy.

Initial assessments and an interview will be required prior to being accepted onto this course.

For anyone already working or volunteering in the Health and Social Care Sector, this course will count towards Continuing Professional Development hours.

It is also suitable for anyone looking to start work in the care sector, or to progress to a formal Health and Social Care qualification.
course.dc:title: Contribute to Health and Safety in Health and Social Care Taster
course.learningOutcome: Opportunities for progression onto a wide range of formal qualifications offered by Cornwall College within the Health and Social Care subject area.
course.mlo:objective:
This course will give you some understanding of the knowledge and skills required to carry out work safely including :-

  •  Own responsibilities, and the responsibilities of others, relating to health and safety in health and social care

  • The use of risk assessments in relation to health and safety in health and social care

  • Procedures for responding to accidents and sudden illness

  • How to reduce the spread of infection

  • How to move and handle equipment and other objects safety

  • How to handle hazardous substances and materials

  • How to promote fire safety in the work setting

  • How to manage own stress
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no entry requirements, just an interest in the subject whether from a professional or personal viewpoint.

course.dc:title: Principles of Infection Prevention and Control Taster
course.learningOutcome: Opportunities for progression onto a wide range of formal qualifications offered by Cornwall College within the Health and Social Care subject area.
course.mlo:objective:
This course will introduce national and local policies in relation to infection control and will give you some understanding of employers and employee’s responsibilities in this area, as well as how procedures and risk assessment can help minimise the risk of an outbreak of infection. Subjects covered will include:-

  • Roles and responsibilities in the prevention and control of infections

  • Legislation and policies relating to prevention and control of infections

  • Systems and procedures relating to the prevention and control of infections

  • Risk assessment in relation to the prevention and control of infections

  • Using Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)

  • The importance of good personal hygiene in the prevention and control of infection
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements, just an interest in the subject whether from a professional or personal viewpoint.

course.dc:title: Provide Information and Support to Patients on the Protection of their Oral Health Taster
course.learningOutcome: Opportunities for progression onto a wide range of formal qualifications offered by Cornwall College within the Health and Social Care subject area.
course.mlo:objective:
This course will give you an understanding of how a patient’s oral and physical health may be affected by:-

 

  • diet

  • medication

  • medical conditions

  • psychological conditions

  • alcohol and substance use

 

Other subjects covered include:- 

 

  • How to provide patients with oral health information

  • How to prepare and use oral health education aids

  • Advising patients on suitable oral hygiene techniques

  • Giving advice on how to clean and care for dentures
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements, just an interest in the subject whether from a professional or personal viewpoint.

course.dc:description:
For anyone already working or volunteering in the Health and Social Care Sector, this course will count towards Continuing Professional Development hours.

It is also suitable for anyone looking to start work in the care sector, or to progress to a formal Health and Social Care qualification.
course.dc:title: Principles of Safeguarding and Protection in Health and Social Care Taster
course.learningOutcome: Opportunities for progression onto a wide range of formal qualifications offered by Cornwall College within the Health and Social Care subject area.
course.mlo:objective:
This course will give you an understanding of the important area of safeguarding individuals from abuse including :-

  • How to identify and recognise signs of abuse

  • How to respond to suspected or alleged abuse

  • The national and local context of safeguarding and protection from abuse

  • Ways to reduce the likelihood of abuse

  • How to recognise and report unsafe practices
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no entry requirements,, just an interest in the subject whether from a professional or personal viewpoint.

course.learningOutcome: You can progress onto other units of study or other courses offered within Health and Social Care.
course.mlo:objective:
You will be able to:

  • Understand the theoretical background to person-centred interactive training.
  • To plan person-centred interactive training sessions to enhance whole team performance.
  • Lead person-centred interactive training sessions in situ.
  • To provide support to improve the performance of others.

This unit can be combined with the Support Individuals to access education, training or employment.

course.dc:title: Support Individuals to Access Education, Training or Employment
course.learningOutcome: You can progress onto other units of study or other courses offered within Health and Social Care.
course.mlo:objective:
You will be able to:

  • Understand the value of engagement in education in training, education or employment for individuals and settings.
  • Understand how legislation, guidance and codes of practice support an individual and settings to access training, education and employment.
  • Understand the support available to individuals accessing education, training or employment.
  • Be able to support an individual or setting to identify and access education, training or employment that meet needs and preferences, for e.g. consideration over new requirements – Care Certificate.

  • Be able to evaluate engagement in education, training or employment.

This unit can be combined with the Lead Interactive Training Unit.

course.dc:title: Dementia Awareness Unit Level 2
course.learningOutcome: You will be able to progress onto the level 2 Certificate in Dementia or onto the Level 2 Diploma in Health and Social Care.
course.mlo:objective:
This qualification is to enable learners to gain knowledge on what Dementia is, the different forms of Dementia and how others can have an impact on the individual with Dementia.

The outcomes are:

  • Understand the key features of the theological methods of Dementia

This course is for individuals who want to achieve a qualification recognised by employers as an Emergency First Aider. This qualification covers the syllabus as outlined by the Health & Saftey Executive (HSE) and is a nationally recogonised qualification.

You will be gaining knowledge and competence to administer first aid and basic life support - an extremely valuable life skill to have.
course.dc:subject: Emergency First Aid at work
course.dc:title: Emergency First Aid at Work FAA Award Level 2 (QCF)
course.learningOutcome:
Assessment is based on practical and oral assessment throughout the course and successful completion of a written test at the end of the course.

Certificates last for 3 years and to renew you need to retake the full course. It is recommended that, during the 3 year period, you attend an annual refresher course.

 You can attend a 3 day appointed First Aider at work course.
course.mlo:objective:
Course content

This course is made up of a theoretical and practical session to include

  • Responsibilities & reporting
  • assessment of the situation
  • Choking
  • Dealing with an unresponsive casualty
  • Minor injuries
  • Bleeding control
  • Seizures
  • Infection control
  • Reuscitation
  • Recovery position
  • hock
  • Safe use of equipment
course.mlo:prerequisite: Applicants must be 16 and over

This qualification is a 1 day course and serves as an introduction into Paediatric First Aid.

CERTIFICATION

Assessment is ongoing by the instructor in respect of the learner's practical skills and there will be a multiple choice question paper to answer in respect of the learners  knowledge.

  • Anaphylaxis
  • Epilepsy
  • Fainting
  • Infection control
  • Minor injuries
  • First Aid equipment

DURATION

A minimum of 6 hours makes up this unit consisting of theoretical and practical work.

course.dc:description:
Swedish massage is the most common and best known type of massage in the west.  It is thought to reduce pain, joint stiffness and poor circulation and is the basis for other types of massage including sports massage.

This course is suitable for people who are serious about practicing professionally as a therapist in Swedish massage and is a good grounding for other types of massage. Applicants may be looking to advance in their profession.
course.dc:subject: Swedish Massage Beauty Therapy Holistic
Hair & Beauty
course.dc:title: Swedish Massage VTCT Certificate Level 3
course.learningOutcome:
After this course, you will be qualified to perform professional Swedish massage treatments for clients via employment or self-employment in the beauty therapy or complementary therapy industry.

There is also the prospect of moving onto one of our other specialist massage qualifications such as Sports massage or you may choose to compliment your skills with other Holistic therapy qualifications such as Aromatherapy or Reflexology.
course.mlo:objective:
This VTCT qualification will enable you to gain the skills, knowledge and understanding required to perform Swedish massage treatments for clients.  It is an intensive course in which you will learn the five massage strokes; effleurage, kneading, rhythmic tapping, friction and vibration/shaking.

Not only do you learn how to massage professionally, you will also learn health, safety and hygiene, basic anatomy and physiology, preparing the treatment area and consultation techniques.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
For this course, you will need a good standard of English and the ability and motivation to self-study as this is a fast track course that requires the student to study to a high standard.  You should also hold a level 2 qualification in beauty or massage.

If you are unsure as to whether or not you meet the requirements, please call the Hair and Beauty Department and ask to speak to the course manager who will be happy to discuss this with you.

This is an ideal course for those looking for a first step into the Hotel and Catering industry, or for those in the industry wishing to gain a recognised qualification.
course.dc:subject: Professional Cookery, Hospitality, Diploma, Food, Catering, cooking, chef, CG, C&G, city & guilds, city and guilds
Apprenticeships
Catering & Hospitality
course.dc:title: Culinary Chef CG Diploma Level 2
course.abstract: This is an ideal course for those looking for a first step into the Hotel and Catering industry
course.learningOutcome: Upon successful completion of this course, you can enter employment as a Chef or you can continue onto a Level 3 programme at the college.
course.mlo:objective: You will learn the Principles of food preparation and cooking, become skilled in such important skills as frying, baking, grilling, poaching, steaming and griddling and you will learn how to prepare and cook a variety of interesting and exciting dishes including meats, fish, sauces, soups, vegetables, salads, pastries, and hot and cold desserts. You will also undertake Functional skills, ERR, CIEH food safety award, Sustainability in Professional Kitchens, Introduction into foraging and wild food, Allergen awareness, safety and hygiene in the kitchen and the importance of teamwork in cooking for our busy restaurant.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements although you will need to show a strong commitment to pursuing a career in food preparation and cookery and have literacy and numeracy skills to Level 1 or above. All applicants for will be required to attend an interview and assessment.  If you are at all unsure as to your suitability for the course we will discuss each individual at an arranged interview. Please contact the college and the programme manager will be happy to discuss the course and its content with you.

CE:cost.dc:description: Please call our Enquiries Team for more details on this course.
Please call our Enquiries Team for more details on this course.

course.dc:description:
Ideal if: you wish to develop your practical skills and learn contemporary techniques in the production of fermented dough products, petit fours, paste products, desserts, chocolate and sugar work.

You'll need: a level 2 qualification in Professional Cookery or equivalent, or expeience in the catering industry.

You'll learn: from a combination of practical and theoretical units which will be delivered inan excellent industry-level environment. In addition to developing practical skills and contemporary techniques in patisserie and confectionery, you will also study the nutritional values of foods and ingredients, management and supervisory skills, successful kitchen management and how to store, prepare and cook food safely.

Expect: to be assessed throughout your course through assignments, projects and practical examinations.

You'll love: that whatever your passion, or specialism, we will help hone your talents and bring out the gastronomist in you, with a number of culinary and food foraging trips, restaurant visits and the organisation of a Gastronomy Fair.

You'll go onto: employment or university study such as our Foundation Degree in Hospitality and Tourism.
course.dc:subject: Cookery Patisserie Confectionery Food Professional Diploma Catering Chef Cooking Cake Pastry Chocolate
Catering & Hospitality
course.dc:title: Patisserie and Bakery Skills CG Diploma Level 3
course.abstract: Develop your practical skills in a variety of techniques associated with desserts, chocolate and sugar work
course.mlo:assessment: You will be assessed throughout your course through assignments, projects and practical examinations.
course.learningOutcome: After successfully completing the NVQ 3 and with sufficient industry experience you will have the opportunity to progress onto a Foundation Degree. This qualification will also enable you to apply for positions in first class establishments with the knowledge that the qualification will enhance your job prospects.
course.mlo:objective:
You will be attending the college for one day a week, developing the advanced techniques for working nationally and internationally in Patisserie and Confectionery.  You will be training in fully equipped, industry standard kitchens, gaining further experience servicing our silver service restaurants and learning in a highly innovative environment where creativity and enthusiasm is actively encouraged.

Areas of study will include:

  • Bread and Dough Products. From sour dough to focaccia, to doughnuts and lardy cake.
  • Cakes, Sponges, Biscuits and Scones. This will include Christmas cakes, brandy snaps, yule logs, macaroons and many types of cakes and gateaux.
  • Sweet and Savoury Pastry Products such as strudels and suet puddings.
  • Chocolate Products. This will include truffles, marshmallows, moulding chocolate in all sorts of shapes as well as making chocolate flowers and figures. 
  • Marzipan, pastillage and sugar products. Not only will you be modelling and moulding using many types of mediums such as icing, sugar paste, boiled sugar, fondant and more, you will also be using a variety of skills such as casting, moulding, piping and dipping.
  • Hot Deserts, steamed sponges, various apple dishes, soufflés, classics puddings and the rich sauces to match.
  • Cold Deserts, cheesecakes and mousses, charlottes and jellies, sorbets, ice creams, parfaits, frozen soufflés and much more.
  • Sauces, fillings and coatings. Creams, fillings, sauces, glazes, sabayons, meringues.
  • Functional skills
  • ERR
  • CIEH level 3 food safety award
  • Sustainability in Professional Kitchens level 3
  • Food science
  • Product development and food costing
  • Allergen training
  • Artisan bakery workshop
  • Chocolate from bean to bar

The list covers a multitude of all sorts of confections to raise your skill level.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements. However, because of the advanced nature of the course it is advisable that you are either the holder of NVQ level-2 Food Preparation and Production or City and Guilds 706/1 and 706/2 or are already working in a first class establishment. Equally, you can be a mature student who may never have attended college and would like to gain a nationally recognised qualification. In all cases real enthusiasm for the industry and a love of food is vital.

presentation.dc:title: Patisserie and Bakery Skills Diploma Level 3 (19+)

course.dc:description: Contact us for more information.

Under the Licensing Act 2003, anyone authorising the retail sale of alcohol will have to hold a personal licence. In order to qualify for a personal licence, an applicant must hold a licensing qualification which is: Qualifications and Curriculum Authority (QCA) accredited, and Government approved.

BIIABs new qualification, the BIIAB Level 2 Award for Personal Licence Holders, is both QCA accredited and Government approved, and has been specifically designed to meet the statutory requirements of the Licensing Act 2003.
course.dc:subject: Personal Licence Holders, Award, BIIAB, Licensing, 2003, Alcohol, hospitality, city and guilds, drink, CG, C&G, city & guilds
Catering & Hospitality
course.dc:title: Personal Licence Holders BIIAB Award Level 2
course.abstract: Under the Licensing Act 2003, anyone authorising the retail sale of alcohol will have to hold a personal licence.
course.learningOutcome:
On successful assessment the candidate will receive a national qualification awarded by the BIIAB, which is recognised as evidence of the applicants knowledge and understanding of licensing law and the social responsibilities associated with running licensed premises.

The BIIAB Level 2 Award for Personal Licence Holders is a nationally recognised qualification designed for anyone authorising the retail sale of alcohol in licensed premises including:

  • Public Houses
  • Convenience stores
  • Bars
  • Sports and social clubs
  • Hotels
  • Entertainment establishments
  • Restaurants
  • Nightclubs
  • Off-licences
  • Leisure parks
  • Supermarkets
  • Casinos and any other venue or site where alcohol is sold
course.mlo:objective:
BIIAB´s Level 2 Award for Personal Licence Holders covers the syllabus set by Government, to enable candidates to understand the law in relation to:

  • The roles, responsibilities and functions of licensing authorities within the framework of the licensing objectives.
  • The application process for a personal licence.
  • The role and legal responsibilities of the personal licence holder, and the penalties relating to failure to comply with the law.
  • The premises licence.
  • The content and purpose of operating schedules.
  • The role and duties of the designated premises supervisor.
  • The unauthorised licensable activities.
  • The permitted temporary licensable activities.
  • The rights of entry to licensed premises.
  • The police powers with regard to suspension and closure of licensed premises.
  • The specific prohibitions for the sale of alcohol.
  • The strengths of alcoholic drinks, and the effects of alcohol on the human body.
  • The protection of children from harm.
  • The responsible retail sale of alcohol.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
In order to be eligible to apply for a personal licence a person must:

  • Be 18 years of age or above
  • Not have forfeited a personal licence in the preceding 5 year period
  • Must not have any unspent convictions for any relevant offences in either England or Wales or for any foreign offences.

This course is for supervisors and managers in the catering industry who will have a responsibility for implementing food hygiene policies. Food safety training is essential to ensure not only compliance with the law, but for food handlers and businesses to have a proper understanding of their responsibilities and to safeguard the health and safety of your customers and ensure a statutory requirement with regard to food handling and storage are met, it is essential that all staff whose work could affect the provision of food, understand the principles of safe food handling and basic food hygiene.
course.dc:subject: Supervisory Food, Safety, Intermediate, Catering, Hospitality, CIEH, city and guilds
Catering & Hospitality
course.dc:title: Supervising Food Safety in Catering CIEH Award Level 3
course.learningOutcome: You can progress onto the Advanced Food Safety qualification. You will have a recognised qualification demonstrating your competence that will be accepted in all catering operations.
course.mlo:objective:
You will cover all aspects in understanding responsibilities and managing food safety systems whilst gaining an insight into the new legislation and policies.  The aspects that you will cover are :

  Bacteriology
  Food Poisoning and food borne disease
  Physical contamination of food and its prevention
  Food storage and temperature control
  Food preservation
  Design and construction of food premises and equipment
  Cleaning and disinfection
  Pest control
  Personal hygiene
  Legislation - awareness of current legislation as it relates to the sale of food
  Supervisory management
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements however candidates attending this course should have the basic knowledge from the Level 2 Award in Food Safety or relevant industrial catering experience in food safety systems.
