course.dc:description:
This course is the first step for learners who are looking at starting a career in the Hairdressing industry.

You will learn the basic techniques of shampooing & conditioning, cutting, styling,  and / or colouring & perming alongside customer care, health & safety and retail product knowledge & sales.  
This hairdressing certificate gives you the basic techniques and experience to start a career in the hairdressing industry.

The study program will consist of practical salons and classroom based theory sessions. There will be theory written papers taken in exam conditions and practical assessments which are carried out during practical lessons on paying clients.
course.dc:subject: Hair & Beauty
course.dc:title: Women's Hairdressing CG Certificate Level 2
course.abstract: Hairdressing
course.learningOutcome:
A Hairdressing Certificate at Level 2 will give you the practical skills and knowledge to get your first job in the hairdressing industry. You could continue your studies with Cornwall College by upgrading to level 2, 3, and 4 qualifications in hair or diversify into beauty. Cornwall College offer pathways in hair and beauty, and you could choose to study, full time or as an apprentice.
Once you have the right set of qualifications, they could take you all over the world. Past students have gone on to manage their own salon, travel on cruise liners, work in the world of television or as session stylists at photographic shoots
course.mlo:objective:
Whichever Cornwall College you choose, you will be learning in purpose-built salons, open to the public and training in a fastpaced and creative environment.
Each of the salons are run by professional stylists and the lecturers are happy to share their expertise with you. You will develop your practical salon skills, from learning how to identify and carry out different cuts to learning how to achieve the latest looks through colouring and styling techniques. Enhance your skills in customer service and client care in the salon and at reception with making appointments and the promotion of retail products and services. Everything you need to know to begin your career as a hairdresser is covered on this course.
Assessments are carried out during practical lessons along with some on-line testing.
If you are 16-19 you will continue to develop your skills of Maths, English, Employability and Work Experience as a part of your study program.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
You will need to have a minimum of 2 GCSEs at grade c, in English and Maths or an equivalent qualification.

At Cornwall College, we recognise that applicants can often offer a high level of competence as well as life experience and we will therefore consider all applications on their merits alongside their qualifications.

If you are unsure as to whether or not you meet the requirements, please call the Hairdressing  Department and ask to speak to the course manager who will be happy to discuss it with you.

course.dc:description: This is a brand new qualification that has been developed with the aviation sector by NCFE.  It sets out to promote good practice in cabin crewing by setting a nationally recognised standard which is endorsed by Thomas Cook, Monarch and BMI.

This qualification  has been developed with the aviation sector by NCFE for those who wish to work as cabin crew.  Younger students are able to study the course but will need to be 18 before applying to work in the industry.

The course runs for 3hrs per week from October to June and makes use of our mock cabin, there will also be some full day workshops later in the course that will be organised in negotiation with your tutor.  During the course you will be expected to carry out a number of assessments that will include practical role plays, professional discussions, research and written assessments.  You will also be expected to carry out some research and assignments in your own time.
course.dc:subject: Cabin Crew Tourism Air Travel Transport
Travel & Tourism
course.dc:title: Introduction to Cabin Crew NCFE Certificate Level 2
course.abstract: This qualification has been developed with the aviation sector by NCFE
course.learningOutcome: NCFE have negotiated with a number of airlines to ensure that successful achievers are given the opportunity to be interviewed for positions available within the sector.
course.mlo:objective:
You will investigate the airline industry and the role of airline cabin crew and develop the necessary skills required to carry out the role of air cabin crew.

During the course you will be expected to carry out a number of assessments that will include practical role plays, professional discussions, research and written assessments.  You will also be expected to carry out some research and assignments in your own time.

The course content includes 6 units:

  • Working as cabin crew
  • Airline health, safety and security
  • Aircraft emergency situations
  • Dealing with passengers on board an aircraft
  • Cabin service - selling techniques
  • Making passenger announcements on board an aircraft
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no specific entry requirements but all candidates will be interviewed to ensure their are both committed and have a suitable level of language skills to be able to complete assessments to the required standard.  You must be at least 16 years of age.

CE:cost.dc:description: Please call our Enquiries Team for more details on this course.

course.dc:description:
This course is a 20 credit module (CORC156) from a Foundation Degree, awarded by Plymouth University.

Contact us for more information.
This course is ideal for anybody involved in planning, delivering or evaluating events; or for those aspiring to work as event managers or coordinators with no previous experience.
course.dc:subject: Event management, performance boosting, short course, performance boosting, short courses, degree level short course, planning marketing, dlsc event planning wedding planning managing an event
Catering & Hospitality
course.dc:title: Event Management (VC)
course.learningOutcome:
There are several flexible progression opportunities for delegates onto other degree level short courses, including: Effective marketing; Principles of event design & themes; Festivals and many more. Alternatively you may be interested in the full time FdA Event Management awarded by the University of Plymouth.

Training at all levels and in a range of subjects is available through Cornwall College Business.
course.mlo:objective:
You will gain a clear understanding of the core operational requirements of designing, planning and running events. Take away practical skills as well as your own bespoke event management guide which is developed during the sessions with the needs of your business at the centre.

The course includes:

  • Types of events
  • Event operations and procedures
  • Customer service
  • Selling
  • Sponsorship and funding
  • Managing event suppliers and contractors
  • Event safety
  • Quality in event production
  • Market size and structure
  • Industry background
  • Market trends.

Managing Event Operation is delivered through practical sessions, lectures, group discussions and site visits. Delegates will have access to online support materials and a designated tutor for learning support. Delegates will have to undertake an assignment to successfully past this course.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements for this course.

CE:cost.dc:description: Please call our Enquiries Team for more details on this course.

course.dc:description: Thomas Cook has recognised the NCFE Level 2 Award for Resort Representatives as an ideal qualification for potential overseas representatives.  They have endorsed the qualification by providing a guaranteed interview to learners who have successfully completed the qualification and meet their minimum requirements. Further information about this offer can be obtained from the course tutor.

This course is offered as part of our suite of professional travel and tourism qualifications.  In order to achieve the NCFE Award for Resort Representatives you must complete four mandatory units that explore employment opportunities, pre-season preparation, airport and transfer duties as well as resort duties.  You will also be required to complete an optional unit that will enable you to specialise on a particular area of the resort representative's role, this could be working with children or as part of the entertainment team.
course.dc:subject: Resort Representatives tourism tour operations travel
Travel & Tourism
course.dc:title: Resort Representatives NCFE Award Level 2
course.abstract: For anyone wishing to be a resort rep
course.learningOutcome: • On successful completion of the course you will be able to apply for positions as a resort representative or you may wish to consider broadening your knowledge of tourism by enrolling on the full-time programme in travel and tourism or another short course from the range available.
course.mlo:objective:
During the course you will be expected to carry out a number of assessments that will include practical role plays.  Role plays will include delivering  a welcome meeting, overseeing a coach transfer and resort based customer service.  You will also be expected to carry out some research and assignments in your own time.

The course content includes 4 mandatory units:

  • Investigate employment opportunites for resort representatives
  • Understand the role of a representative in a resort
  • Prepare for the start of the holiday season
  • Manage airport and transport duties

Plus one optional unit from:

  • Investigate the role of the childrens representative in a holiday resort
  • Investigate the role of the entertainment represenative in a holiday resort
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no specific entry requirements but all candidates will be interviewed to ensure they are both committed and have a suitable level of language skills to be able to complete assessments to the required standard.

Construction Trades
course.dc:title: Basic Lead Appreciation Course - Construction Planning and the Built Environment Vocational Short Course
course.learningOutcome: You may progress on to the basic welding and bossing course.
course.mlo:objective: Basic health and safety rules will be covered along with how lead sheet can be manipulated and formed to a variety of shapes used in roofing applications by using hand tools and cold working techniques.  On completion of the course students will know the health and safety procedures for working with lead sheet and be able to form lead work details by bossing lead sheet to shape.

course.dc:subject: welding, bossing, construction, building
Motor Vehicle
course.dc:title: Basic Welding and Bossing Course - Construction Planning and the Built Environment Vocational Short Course
course.learningOutcome: This course will progress on to Lead Welding Fabrication Course.
course.mlo:objective: Basic health and safety rules will be covered along with details about fitting lead sheet that requires the metal to be cut and welded to another sheet, perhaps to protect where there is a projection through a roof such as a pipe or chimney.  Lead sheets are welded together by the controlled melting of lead rods on to the join to bond the sheets together and provide a homogenous joint.  It is a relatively soft and very dense metal when compared to other metals used in roofing such as copper or zinc.
course.mlo:prerequisite: This course follows on from Basic Lead Appreciation Course.

course.dc:description:
Changes to ACS Gas Scheme

As from 1st February 2010 all engineers who undertake initial or re-assessment for Boilers (CEN1) or Fires (HTR1) must hold a valid Combustion Performance Analysers qualification (CPA1).

Engineers who currently hold valid certificates for Boilers (CEN1) or Fires (HTR1) have until 1st April 2012 to obtain the Combustion Performance Analysers qualification (CPA1).

If a Combustion Performance Analyses qualification (CPA1) is not held after this date the Gas Safe Register will be suspended.

Therefore, all candidates who wish to attend the ACS Gas assessments must provide a copy of their current/expired Domestic and CPA1 qualification.
This course is for qualified gas engineers wishing to renew or extend their qualifications and also for new entrants to gain their qualification on domestic gas fires.
You will be assessed at Cornwall College Saltash.

Construction Trades

Successful completion of this course will enable you to install, service and maintain domestic gas fires.

Candidates can then apply for:

  • Central Heating - CEN1
  •  Water Heaters - WAT1
  •  Cookers- CKR1
  • Meters – MET1
  • Combustion performance Analysers – CPA1
  • Energy Efficiency - EE1
  • LPG Changeover from Natural Gas – CoNGLP1
  • Residential Park Homes – CoNGLP1/RPH
  • Leisure Activity Vehicles/Widney Fires – CoNGLP1/LAV and HTRLP2
  • Boats – CoNGLP1/B
course.mlo:objective:
You will undertake both theoretical and practical assessments of competency.

The Assessment which will be taken are:
HTR1 - Fires
course.mlo:prerequisite: You must already be a qualified gas engineer who currently hold CCN1 and CPA1 analysers.

course.dc:description:
Changes to ACS Gas Scheme

As from 1st February 2010 all engineers who undertake initial or re-assessment for Boilers (CEN1) or Fires (HTR1) must hold a valid Combustion Performance Analysers qualification (CPA1).

Engineers who currently hold valid certificates for Boilers (CEN1) or Fires (HTR1) have until 1st April 2012 to obtain the Combustion Performance Analysers qualification (CPA1).

If a Combustion Performance Analyses qualification (CPA1) is not held after this date the Gas Safe Register will be suspended.

Therefore, all candidates who wish to attend the ACS Gas assessments must provide a copy of their current/expired Domestic and CPA1 qualification.

This course is for qualified gas installation engineers/plumbers seeking re-certification of expired qualifications.  This is also suitable for engineers wanting to be gas qualified for the first time but must have a minimum of NVQ level-2 plumbing with experience of working alongside a qualified gas engineer.

Candidates can then apply for:

  • Combustion performance Analysers - CPA1 (can taken during this course is required)
  • Meters - MET1

  • LPG Changeover from Natural Gas - CoNGLP1
  • Residential Park Homes - CoNGLP1/RPH

  • Boats - CoNGLP1/B
course.mlo:objective:
You will undertake both theoretical and practical assessments of competency.  Training guidance prior to undertaking the assessments is available if required and the candidate must demonstrate competence in Core Gas Safety before proceeding to appliance assessments.   Assessments are carried out by multiple choice papers and practical assessments.  The Assessments which will be taken are:

 

CCN1 - Core Gas Safety (Natural Gas)

CENWAT - Central Heating Boilers & Water Heaters

HTR1 - Space Heaters (Fires)

CKR1 - Cookers
course.mlo:prerequisite: For these courses you will need an existing ACOP's or ACS qualification alternatively a minimum of NVQ level-2 in plumbing with relevant on-site experience. Evidence of qualifications and work experience must be provided prior to undertaking assessments. Please enquire if you are at all unsure as to your suitability for this course and the programme manager will be able to discuss this with you.

course.dc:description: Following the revised Building Regulations published April 2005, from April 2006, all installers wishing to certify their own work under Gas Safe Registration legislation, (rather than call Local Authority Building Control) must hold a certificate in Energy Efficiency for Domestic Heating. This course can help you deliver your responsibilities under the Home Energy Conservation Act.  This course is also suitable for engineers working on renewable energies and wish to be registered under the NICEIC MCS Micro Certification Scheme.

The training is aimed at both experienced and new installers, and consists of a daylong workshop covering a range of topics, including the new building regulations, climate change and High Efficiency Condensing boilers. This is followed by a simple 90-minute multiple-choice test, which if you pass, gives you the new certificate. Candidates shall receive training material three weeks before the training for self study.
course.dc:subject: EE1 Energy Efficiency gas domestic
Construction Trades
course.dc:title: Energy Efficiency Building Regulations L1 NICEIC
course.learningOutcome: You will be able to certify you own work under Gas Safe Register.
course.mlo:objective: This is a one day course and the content includes topics such as: Benefits of efficient heating and hot water, Energy efficiency and the building regulations, The importance of boiler efficiency, The importance of an efficient hot water cylinder, Domestic heating and hot water controls and Commissioning. It is for registered engineers who intend to provide energy advice in the home, develop additional energy advice-giving skills, understand fuel poverty, understand the importance of energy efficiency and how to refer householders for additional assistance.
course.mlo:prerequisite: Candidates must have one of the following qualifications; Appropriate NVQ Level 3/BTEC or equivalent Appropriate industry registration scheme: e.g. Gas Safe Register or OFTEC-105E or equivalent. At least two years industry experience of installation of domestic heating and hot water systems currently un-certificated skills equivalent NVQ Level 3. At least two years industry experience of design and advice services of domestic heating and hot water systems at NVQ Level 3 or equivalent. Please enquire if you are at all unsure as to your suitability on 01209 616349 and we will be happy to discuss the course with you.

The PASMA photocard provides proof that you have undergone and successfully completed training to a nationally recognised standard.  Many workplaces will insist on seeing your PASMA photo card before you will be allowed to assemble, alter or dismantle mobile access towers, so it should be retained with you at all times and presented for inspection by anyone in authority.

Contact us for more information.
Anyone who assembles, dismantles or alters a mobile tower.   Or anyone wishing to go into this field.
course.dc:subject: tower scaffolding, height, construction, PASMA, towers, advanced, guardrail, system, AGS
course.dc:title: Tower Scaffolding Level 1
course.mlo:objective:
This is mainly a practical course, with classroom based tutorials and the use of  DVDs and group participation combined with practical exercises. Delegates must successfully pass both sections - firstly a practical session looking at the assembly of a tower as well as carrying out specific inspections and including a safe dismantling of a structure. The theory includes the work at height regulations, site inspections and procedures.

Introduction to Mobile Access Towers
2. Tower Assembly
3. Stability
4. Safe Use of Towers
5. Repositioning Towers
6. Tower Inspection
7. Care & Maintenance
8. Tower Dismantle
9. Regulations and Standards

Health & Safety legislation & regulations.
PASMA Code of Practise.
Safe working at heights.
Identifying mobile access tower equipment.
Manufactures Instruction Manuals.
Ground and site conditions.
Sequence of erecting and dismantling mobile access towers.
Use of stabilisers, outriggers, sole pads and ties.
Moving and repositioning erected towers.
Inspection report procedure.
Multi choice test paper.
Advanced Guardrails and Through the Trap erection.
Practical erection, moving, inspection and dismantling
course.mlo:prerequisite: As this can be physically demanding applicants need to be fit and able to work at heights.

This course is suitable for all plumbers and engineers involved in the installation, commissioning, service and repair of hot water systems, solar thermal hot water systems or air source/ground source heat pumps.

Candidates will learn the requirements of the Water Regulations and its effects on water supply organisations and individuals.

You will be provided with a comprehensive learning package followed by a 1-day assessment. The course is available throughout the year, please contact the college on 01752 850250 for further information regarding dates and times.
course.dc:subject: Water Regulations, WRAS, WRO1, plumbing, construction, NICEIC
Construction Trades
course.dc:title: Water Regulations NICEIC - WR01
course.learningOutcome: Upon successful completion, candidates will have sufficient knowledge of the Water Regulations to ensure that all installation work is carried out in accordance with the current legislation. Candidates will be able to self certify their own work within the Water Industry.
course.mlo:objective:
During this course, you will gain up to date knowledge of current Water Regulations:

  • Water Regulations 1999
  • Pipework and fittings
  • Tightness testing
  • Cleansing and flushing of water systems
  • Commissioning
  • Maintenance and repair

Water Regulations prevent misuse, waste, undue consumption or erroneous measurement of water and, most importantly, to prevent contamination of drinking water.

You will be provided with a comprehensive learning package followed by a 1/2-day assessment.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements for this course, however you must have experience at working on domestic unvented hot or cold water systems.

course.dc:description:
Boost your career, start to learn a new trade or just pick up some handy DIY skills.

This course will allow you to build your skills CV and gain a recognised qualification while training around work and family commitments at the weekend.

Learn practical skills in the workshops at Cornwall College Camborne and work with experienced tutors to achieve a new qualification.

Each course is the equivalent of one unit of the City and Guilds qualification and is the ideal length for you to get a real taste of college life, while working on projects ranging from building chimneys and tiling roofs, to creating your very own piece of furniture.

Call us now on 0800 731 7594 to find out how to book your place.
course.dc:subject: Construction Trades
course.dc:title: Developing Blockwork Skills City & Guilds Unit Level 1
course.abstract: Saturday Skills course in Blockwork skills
course.learningOutcome: After completing Saturday Skills you may wish to continue on another part-time or full-time course, or put your skills into practice in the workplace.
course.mlo:objective:
During the ten weeks you will learn the basic skills in your chosen craft as well as health and safety practices in the workshop.

Areas you will cover include:

  • Knowing your blocklaying tools and how to use them correctly
  • Learning how to mix mortar and at what ratios
  • The fundamentals of blocklaying gauge, level, plumb and range
  • How to set out our spot board and stack our bricks ready for bricklaying
  • How to spread and roll mortar
  • How to build a series of brick corners
  • Setting out and working to measurements
  • How to set out large lengths of blockwork using dead mens corners
  • How to build a conservatory base with cavity wall to a building drawing
  • How to build a block pillar using d.p.c and various pointing methods
  • How to use various lintels

presentation.dc:title: Developing Blockwork Skills City & Guilds Unit Level 1 (Evenings & Weekend)

course.dc:description:
This course is intended to be delivered  as part of the suite of qualifications in Environmental Technologies and is free of charge to those who enrol also onto any of the following

 

Level 3 Award in the Installation and Maintenance of Solar Thermal Hot Water Systems 

Level 3 Award in the Installation and Maintenance of Heat Pump Systems (Non-refrigerant circuits) 

Level 3 Award in the Installation and Maintenance of Water Harvesting and Re-use Systems 

However this Award needs to be completed prior to enrolling onto the above

This course is ideal if you wish to have a career within the environmental technology sector.  It will provide you with a breadth of knowledge enabling you to move on to complete qualifications in a range of renewable energy technologies. It is important to note that you must complete this foundation module to be able to progress onto any of the following:

  • Solar Thermal Hot Water Systems
  • Heat Pump Systems
  • Water Harvesting and Re-use Systems
course.dc:subject: environmental technology systems awareness construction built building renewable
Engineering
course.dc:title: Environmental Technology Systems Awareness City & Guilds Award Level 3 (QCF)
course.abstract: A wide ranging course that will introduce you to a range of technologies
course.learningOutcome: On successfully completing the course you will be able to continue to gain more qualifications in specific areas of environmental technologies.
course.mlo:objective:
This course is designed to develop a broad understanding of environmental technologies. It will arm you with the knowledge and theory to give advice to customers on suitable environmental technology systems. You will learn about:

 1. Solar Thermal

2. Ground Source Heat Pumps

3. Air Source Heat Pumps

4. Biomass

5. Solar PV

6. Micro Wind

7. Micro Hydro

8. Combined Heat & Power (CHP)

9. Rainwater Harvesting

10. Greywater Use

This course is delivered over 1 day with an on-line exam at the end
course.mlo:prerequisite:
It is likely that you will be a qualified plumber, electrician or a practicing domestic installer or Domestic Energy Assessor / Home Energy Advisor or equivalent.

It is possible to take this course if you are not an established professional; however you will need to gain competence gas engineer or a plumber before you can complete some of the latter modules and gain a full qualification.

However if you are simply looking for a strong grounding in this industry and its principle technologies then this course could be ideal.

course.dc:description:
On-Site Assessment and Training (OSAT) helps experienced workers get the qualifications to prove they can do the job. It turns their existing skills and experience into a nationally recognised qualification such as an NVQ or SVQ. Having these qualifications also helps qualify them for a Construction Skills Certification Scheme (CSCS) card

On-site Assessment and Training (OSAT) is a method of assessing the skills and knowledge of people in the workplace and helps turns their existing skills and experience into a NVQ

The OSAT method involves a Construction assessor visiting the learner's place of work or site and working with them to build up a portfolio of evidence that prove their skills and knowledge. This route generally takes four or five visits over a period of approximately 6 to 12 months dependent on experience

OSAT training is ideal for learners who have some experience of their trade or profession and wish to gain a qualification to support their experience.

course.dc:description: It is aimed at practising electricians who have not carried out inspection and testing since qualifying or who require some update training before going on to achieve the City & Guilds Level 3 Certificate in inspection, testing and certification of electrical installations (2391-10). It is also suitable for those with limited experience of inspection and testing of electrical installations, such as those:, Entering the industry from other engineering disciplines, Working in allied trades
You will study this course by attending College for three hours each week, for duration of ten weeks.
course.dc:subject: Fundamental Inspection Testing Initial Verification 2392 Electrical
Engineering
course.dc:title: Fundamental Inspection, Testing and Initial Verification City & Guilds Certificate Level 2
course.learningOutcome: You will be able to go on to achieve the City & Guilds Level 3 Certificate in inspection and testing of electrical installations (2391-10).
course.mlo:objective: You will prepare for two examinations, one on-line exam and one practical assessment. Topics covered will be:, Using test instruments and interpreting results. Completing test certificates including inspection and result schedules. Different types of earthing arrangements. Use of human senses. The requirements of EAWR 1989. The relationship between conductor length, cross sectional area (csa), and the effect of temperature on conductor resistance.
course.mlo:prerequisite: It would be expected that candidates have a basic knowledge and understanding of electrical science and principles and experience of electrical installation work either within the electrical contracting industry or allied trades.

course.dc:description:
The BTEC Extended Diploma is a full-time programme, suitable for people who wish to become engineers or technicians within the aeronautical or service community around the world.

It will give you a sound basis to move onto further education at university level or provide employment opportunities that might include eeronautical engineering in any of the armed forces, working as an aircraft technician in the civil aircraft industry or progressing on to become a European Safety Agency licenced aircraft engineer.
course.dc:subject: aeronautical btec level 3 engineering
Engineering
course.dc:title: Aeronautical Engineering EDEXCEL Extended Diploma Level 3
course.abstract: Aeronautical Engineering Level 3
course.learningOutcome: On completing this course you will have the skills to go on to university and continue your education to degree level.  You will also have a sound basis should you wish to go into employment as an engineer or technician within the aeronautical or service community around the world.  You may also wish to progress to aeronautical engineering in the armed forces, or to become a European Safety Agency licenced aircraft engineer.
course.mlo:objective:
The BTEC Extended Diploma requires the completion of 16 units of study. The programme comprises four core units;

  • Theory of Flight
  • Principles and Applications of Aircraft Mechanical Science
  • Mathematics for Engineering Technicians
  • Engineering Project

There are also a range of 12 additional units, which may include:

  • Aircraft Propulsion System
  • Airframe Systems
  • Aircraft Materials and Hardware
  • Aircraft Gas Turbine Engines
  • Business Operations in Engineering. 

The course does cover some practical work in airframe repairs and the removal inspection repair and installation of components. Covering in detail many of the systems installed in todays' aircraft, big and small.

The course also looks at legislation, documentation, human factors related to aviation but at the same time many of the individual topics are readily transferrable skills that are recognised by other engineering disciplines.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
You will normally need to have at least one of the following:

  • a BTEC First Certificate or Diploma in a related subject
  • City & Guilds Level 2 Certificate in Aeronautical Engineering
  • an Intermediate GNVQ in a related subject (Merit is desirable)
  • at least four GCSEs at grades A - C including mathematics, English and science.

presentation.dc:subject: Engineering
presentation.dc:title: Aeronautical Engineering EDEXCEL Extended Diploma Level 3

course.dc:description: Bursaries are available for full-time students.

UCAS Code: H100
Institution Code: CORN C78

This course is for anyone looking to seek a career or indeed has an interest within one of the specialist modules which are covered in this course and lead into specific areas of interest. It will provide a challenging programme of study that will enable learners to develop the concepts, knowledge, skills and techniques required for today's engineering industry. Specialised modules relevant to the engineering industry in which learners are employed, and a platform for a successful career development will be covered also. This course will provide students with a qualification that will allow progression to honours degree programmes.

Year 1

  • Business Management Techniques (10 credits)
  • Computer Aided Design (10 credits)
  • Electronics 1 (20 credits)
  • Analytical Methods for Engineers 1 (20 credits)
  • Engineering Science 1 (20 credits)
  • Communications & Electrical Principles 1 (20 credits)
  • Personal & Employability Skills Development (20 credits)

 

Year 2

Core

  • Analytical Methods for Engineers 2 (10 credits)
  • Electronics 2 (10 credits)
  • Engineering Science 2 (10 credits)
  • Hydraulic & Pneumatic Principles (10 credits)
  • Manufacture & Materials 1 (20 credits)
  • Project Management (10 credits)
  • Project (20 credits)
  • Control & Interfacing (20 credits)

 

Optional Modules (choose one)

  • Utilisation of Electrical Power (10 credits)
  • Rapid Product Development (10 credits)
course.dc:subject: FdSc, engine, electrical, technology, mechanical engineer, design engineer, automotive engineer, aerospace engineer, science, computer aided design, CAD, hydraulics, pneumatics, energy, manufacture, manufacturing, motor vehicle, welding, installation, fabrication
Engineering
course.dc:title: FdSc Engineering
course.abstract: FdSc Engineering
course.learningOutcome:
Foundation degree graduates have a wide choice of career opportunities throughout the private and public sectors, both in the United Kingdom and abroad. There is a range of opportunities within industrial and commercial organisations where a broad-based and work-related education is desirable.

 

Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression.

 

Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm)

Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
The foundation degree is designed to meet the requirements of industry, reflecting the need to add skills to current employees and to provide skilled new employees who can respond to current industry needs. It places emphasis on transferable skills as well as knowledge of engineering principles.

The programme brings together the requirement for engineering employees to be well versed in both electrical and mechanical areas of engineering and to have a greater depth of knowledge in the control engineering field. Completing the programme will make you more versatile and multi-skilled.

A variety of teaching styles allow you to learn in an effective manner and will also provide you with communication, team working and time management skills that will help you become a more effective student and employee.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level, preferably in a science subject) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - PPP Grades required, specific unit grades may be required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3, or NVQ Level 3 Mechanical Engineering or equivalent.  Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language, mathematics and a science: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 0845 22 32 567 or email enquiries@cornwall.ac.uk.

CE:cost.dc:description: This fees for this course may be met through an HE Loan.

CE:FundingCriteria.CE:criteria: You have achieved a Full Level 3 (A-Levels, NVQ Level 3, Etc) qualification.
You must have been ordinarily resident in the UK or the European Union (EU) or the European Economic Area (EEA) continuously for at least the previous three years on 31st July 2013.

course.dc:description: This course is for people wishing to go into the electrical installation industry and are able to attend classes part time over two years. It will provide the essential underpinning knowledge necessary for the National Occupational Standards. The aims of the course are to provide knowledge and awareness of the techniques, craft skills, technology and related science required for electrical installation work. The course will also provide an understanding of the regulations and health and safety requirements governing electrical installation processes and knowledge of the organisation and structure of the industry within which these activities are carried out. This course is designed for people who wish to train in Electrical Installation and mainly focuses on Installation of Electrical Equipment in Commercial, Domestic and Industrial premises.
course.dc:subject: eal, level 3, eletrotechnical systems, installing, Electrician, electric, EMTA, NVQ
Engineering
course.dc:title: Installing Electrotechnical Systems and Equipment EMTA NVQ Diploma Level 3 (Buildings, Structures and the Environment)
course.learningOutcome: This will give the students a valuable, intermediate qualification, which may enhance their employment possibilities, potentially making them more desirable to prospective employees.
course.mlo:objective:
The qualification covers areas including environmental technology systems, preparing and installing electrical systems and equipment, terminating and connecting conductors, cables and flexible cords, and inspecting, testing, commissioning and fault diagnosis and correction.

The course is approximately half classroom work and half workshop/laboratory work and is made up of four units:
1) Working effectively and safely in an electrotechnical environment (Stage 1)
2) Principles of electrotechnology (Stage 1)
3) Application of health and safety and electrical principles (Stage 2)

Learners must complete the relevant knowledge units before the performance units, and finish with the Electrotechnical Occupational Competence Unit which is assessed by the AM2 test.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
For under 19s, a minimum of 4 GCSE passes at Grade C or above in Maths, English and Science are required.  Mature applicants without formal qualifications but with experience in work-related areas are encouraged to apply and will be assessed at interview.

Students will need to find a work placement alongside a registered electrician. 2 days′ placement a week is sufficient experience in the first year and you may need to work alongside an electrician on a full-time basis in your second year to satisfy the necesary requirements.

Please enquire if you are unsure of your suitability for this course and the department will be happy to discuss this with you.

course.dc:description:
Ideal if: you are starting out in the industry or have an interest in developing your welding skills

You'll need: a good level of hand eye coordination

You'll learn: how to weld joints on varying thickness of metal, and cover a variety of welding principles along with the relevant health and safety procedures

Expect: to be assessed through a range of practical tests and an open book question paper

You'll love: studying with our expert tutors in industry standard workshops,

You'll go onto: further training such as one of our level 2 courses, or employment.

 

This is a ten week course which will run on Monday afternoons at Cornwall College Camborne.

course.mlo:objective: You will spend your time in our workshops on campus, learning to weld on metals of different thicknesses.  You will also gain knowledge of the health and safety practices related to welding.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements for this course, you just need good hand eye coordination.

The course is for students who wish to develop the skills required in the use of a computer aided drawing package and wish to obtain the City & Guilds Level 2 qualification in Computer-Aided Draughting with Autocad. The course is delivered by the use of the AutoCAD software programme.
course.dc:subject: Computer Aided Design CAD Design Marine Engineering Boat building Yacht
Information & Communication Technology
Engineering
course.dc:title: Parametric Modelling CG Award Level 2
course.learningOutcome: Learners have the opportunity to progress to the 2D and the 3D level 3 qualifications.
course.mlo:objective:
The course assumes limited or no previous knowledge and instructs the student in the uses of the following commands:

Draw        -  Line, Arc, Circles, Polygon etc.

Display   -  Zoom, Pan, Viewports etc.

Edit         -  Move, Copy, Fillet, Array, Mirror, Scale etc.

Settings  -  Grid, Snap, Limits, Linetypes, Colour, UCS etc.

Additional Commands:-  Dimensioning, Text, Blocks, Attribute  Definition, Save, Inquiry, Plotting.

Students will be taught at the computer using a range of prepared material.  They work at their own speed with the assistance of the lecturer.

The student will need to complete two assessed drawings over the period of the course, followed by an on-line multi-choice test set by City and Guilds.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements other than the ability to use a computer and Windows based software

Learners wanting to progress in the building services sector to work with environmental technologies, and qualified and competent practitioners looking to  upskill in the renewables sector via the installation of small scale solar photovoltaic (PV) systems. These systems generate and store electricity from the sun and are designed to help reduce CO² emissions, targeted under the Climate Change Act 2008. 

Learners wanting to progress in the building services sector to work with environmental technologies, and qualified and competent practitioners looking to  upskill in the renewables sector via the installation of small scale solar photovoltaic (PV) systems. These systems generate and store electricity from the sun and are designed to help reduce CO² emissions, targeted under the Climate Change Act 2008.
course.dc:subject: small scale, solar, photovoltaic, pv, renewable, construction, technology, energy, green, inspection, installation, EAl, maintanace, systems
EngineeringConstruction Trades
course.dc:title: Installation and Maintenance of Small Scale Solar Photovoltaic Systems EMTA Award Level 3
course.abstract: Learners wanting to progress in the building services sector to work with environmental technologies
course.learningOutcome: You will enhance your career development and employment opportunities with industry-recognised qualifications.
course.mlo:objective:
The course is structured to facilitate practicing electricians and covers both theoretical and practical applications which are designed to replicate real circumstances. Learners begin by covering The fundamental principles and requirements of environmental technologies are covered first before candidates focus on the installation of small scale solar photovoltaic systems.

The course is  delivered within internal and external workshops. There is also a required element of  independent learning which enables learners to expand on the taught elements of the course.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
• EAL Level 3 award Understanding the fundamental principles and requirements of environmental technology systems + C&G 2356-31 Level 3 NVQ Installation of Electro technical Systems + C&G 2391 Level 3 Inspection & Testing + C&G 2382-10 (full) 17th Edition (BS7671:2008) or C&G 2382-20 (short, 2011 amendment)
OR
• 17th Edition (BS 7671:2008) + Membership of approved bodies, NICEIC; NAPIT or ELECSA
OR
• 17th Edition (BS 7671:2008) + practising domestic installer qualifying, testing and commission of own work.

The City and Guilds Level 3 Certificate in Introductory Dog Grooming is a course for those who have already achieved the City and Guilds Level 2 Certificate for Dog Grooming Assistants or the Level 2 College Certificate in Dog Grooming, or for those who already have a high level of experience within the dog grooming industry, wishing to gain a nationally-recognised qualification.
course.dc:subject: dogs animals
Animal Management & Veterinary Nursing
course.dc:title: Introductory Dog Grooming City & Guilds (NPTC) Certificate Level 3
course.abstract: Level 3 Certificate in Introductory Dog Grooming
course.learningOutcome:
The Level 3 Certificate for Introductory Dog Grooming will give you the skills to work in the grooming industry and possibly set up your own business.


You can progress onto the Level 3 Diploma for Professional Dog Stylists which would require a further 100 hours of study at College plus a substantial amount of practical experience in industry to enable you to pass the practical examinations.  The Level 3 Diploma gives you tuition and experience in hand-stripping and also styling and trimming of spaniels, short and long-legged terriers, Schnauzers and poodles to show standards.  There are additional fees for undertaking the externally set Practical Examinations.
course.mlo:objective:
This course is taught in the spacious new Dog Grooming area at Duchy College Rosewarne, where there is up-to-date equipment and plenty of opportunity to practise your skills on a range of different dog breeds to prepare you for the practical assessments.  You will also learn the underpinning theory, which includes the completion of written assignments and two externally set written exam papers


The course is part-time, running one day per week(6 hours per day)over 30 weeks and includes the following units:



    • Carry out the styling and finishing of dogs

    • Assessment and planning of dog grooming work

    • Promote and maintain the health and wellbeing of animals

    • Health checking a dog by a dog groomer


There are also a number of optional units:



    • Welcome, receive and care for visitors

    • Promote, monitor and maintain health, safety and security

    • Moving animals between locations

    • Handle payments from clients

    • Keep stock to required levels in the retail environment.
course.mlo:prerequisite: You will need to be working within the dog grooming industry (either as a volunteer or in paid employment) to enable you to practise the grooming skills on a range of dog breeds with different coat types.  You also need to have a good level of literacy to enable you to complete the assignment work and written exams.

course.dc:description:
This programme is fully approved by the RCVS and graduates of the FdSc Veterinary Nursing  programme are able to register with the RCVS as Registered Veterinary Nurses on successful completion of the programme.

RCVS fees include:
RCVS enrolment as a Student Veterinary Nurse: £199 (subject to change)

Bursaries available - see student finance / tuition fees pages of our website for details.

Anyone wishing to take a HE qualification in Veterinary Nursing, to gain professional accreditation with the RCVS,  and qualified Veterinary Nurses who wish to take HE modules as Continuing Professional Development. The course offers a wide range of modules providing development of skills in many areas from laboratory techniques to large animal nursing providing graduates with the opportunity to consider a range of progression and employment options.

UCAS Code: D311
Institution Code: DUCHY D55

Anyone wishing to take a HE qualification in Veterinary Nursing, to gain professional accreditation with the RCVS,  and qualified Veterinary Nurses who wish to take HE modules as Continuing Professional Development. The course offers a wide range of modules providing development of skills in many areas from laboratory techniques to large animal nursing providing graduates with the opportunity to consider a range of progression and employment options.

Year 1                
  •  Maintaining Animal Health (20 credits)
  • Essential Veterinary Nursing Skills (20 credits)
  • Functional Anatomy (20 credits)
  • Application of Veterinary Nursing Care (20 credits)
  • Care & Rehabilitation (10 credits)
  • Introduction to Animal Behaviour (10 credits)
  • Personal & Employability Skills Development (20 credits)
 
Year 2
 
  • Theatre Practice & Anaesthesia (20 credits)
  • Pharmacy (10 credits)
  • Diagnostic Methods (20 credits)
  • Animal Nutrition (10 credits)
  • Large Animal Health & Disease (10 credits) 
  • Current Practice in Veterinary Nursing (10 credits)
 
Years 2 & 3
 
  • Research Project (20 credits) 
  • Veterinary Placement (20 credits)
  • Veterinary Work Experience (0 credits - see below*)
*Although this module has no credits allocated it contains the requirement of a number of days in the industry and the completion of the nursing progress log. It also satisfies other requirements in order to enable you to graduate as FdSc Veterinary Nursing and register as a professional veterinary nurse with the RCVS.
course.dc:subject: FdSc, vet nurse, vets, vet, animals, animal care, animal nursing, animal management, veterinary practise, veterinary surgeons, animal scientists, zoologists, animal nutrition, animal diseases.
Animal Management & Veterinary Nursing
course.dc:title: FdSc Veterinary Nursing
course.abstract: FdSc Veterinary Nursing
course.learningOutcome:
The foundation degree enables you to become a Registered Veterinary Nurse. It offers a higher education qualification that can be useful if you wish to continue studying, enter practice management or enter other aspects of the veterinary industry such as research, teaching and pharmaceuticals. Former graduates currently work as veterinary nurses, in bird parks, in the pet store industry, in zoos and wildlife trusts, as police dog handlers or have gone on to teach in further education.
 
Possible careers include:
 
  • Veterinary nurse
  • Veterinary practice manager
  • Pharmaceutical position
  • Veterinary nursing educator or instructor
  • Pet food representative
Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression. Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm) Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
The modules offered provide a broad education in the veterinary nursing of small animals (covering all of the requirements necessary to register as a Registered Veterinary Nurse) as well as modules in additional areas such as animal behaviour, care and rehabilitation and animal nutrition. You will be taught by specialist staff including veterinary surgeons, veterinary nurses, animal scientists and zoologists.
 
There is also the opportunity to explore current issues and developing concepts in the industry and you are encouraged to investigate areas of individual interest for your research project. 
 
The programme is delivered by a team of specialists including veterinary surgeons, veterinary nurses, animal scientists and zoologists, all of whom have practical industry experience. 
 
This foundation degree has been developed over several years using our strong links with the veterinary industry in Cornwall and Devon.
 
In your first and second years,  your time will be divided equally between college and a veterinary placement.  A veterinary nursing placement must be confirmed to be admitted onto the programme.  Please contact the Programme Manager if you wish to discuss placements further.  We are happy to advise and answer any questions you may have at any stage through the academic year.
 
Most modules are taught for two to three hours per week through the year; short modules are taught for only half a year. 
 
Your third year is spent full-time in a veterinary practice, to ensure that the required 60 weeks of veterinary nursing placement is completed and you will return to college throughout the year and for the final month to complete your research project and final examinations. 
 
Throughout the programme there will be many opportunities for you to benefit from the expertise of external speakers from the industry such as farm and equine vets. 
 
Assessment will take place via a combination of assignments, completion of an online nursing progress log and written and practical examinations. To graduate and then register as a veterinary nurse, all assessment requirements included in the programme must be fulfilled.
 
You will sit foundation degree exams at the end of each year and an online nursing progress log and 60 weeks of veterinary nursing placement must be successfully completed in order to be awarded the FdSc Veterinary Nursing. 
 
The programme is awarded by Plymouth University and approved by the Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons (RCVS). Successful completion will allow you to register with the RCVS as a Registered Veterinary Nurse (RVN).
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e.  National Diploma/ Extended Diploma - PPP Grades required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3.  Plus at least 5  GCSEs at grade C or above,  including English language,  mathematics and science:  alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

Each candidate should have at least 4 weeks of Veterinary Practice work experience in a Small Animal or mixed Veterinary Practice.  At least 2 weeks of the work experience must be completed prior to interview and at least a further 2 weeks of work experience should be completed prior to the 1st August in the year of application.

The work experience should be completed in the 18 months prior to the start of the programme. References will be required for the 4 weeks of work experience.

A Veterinary Nursing Placement is required for admittance onto the programme.  Before enrolling you must attend an interview at Duchy College.

If you are unsure of your suitability please call us on 0845 60 50 455 or email enquiries@duchy.ac.uk.

course.dc:description: This is a part-time course, running one day per week over 15 weeks.  The cost of the course is £675 and there is no fee remission available.  You will be required to purchase your own grooming tunic (approximately £28) and you  may wish to purchase your own grooming kit, although all the equipment is provided within the Grooming Unit.

This College Cerificate course is for those wishing to gain basic skills in dog grooming and bathing, in preparation for the City and Guilds Level 3 Diploma for Professional Dog Stylists.  It will not give you the qualifications required to work as a professional groomer, but it will give you the experience and skills necessary to progress to Level 3.
course.dc:subject: dog, dog grooming, dog groomer, dogs hair, fur, dog styling
Animal Management & Veterinary Nursing
course.dc:title: Dog Grooming College Certificate Level 2
course.learningOutcome:
The Level 2 College Certificate in Dog Grooming will give you the knowledge and skills to work as a grooming assistant within the grooming industry.

If you wish to work as a professional dog groomer, you would need to progress onto the nationally- recognised Level 3 Certificate for Introductory Dog Grooming and then the Level 3 Diploma for Professional Dog Stylists which would require further study at College plus a substantial amount of practical experience in industry to enable you to pass the practical examinations.  The Level 3 Diploma gives you tuition and experience in hand-stripping and also styling and trimming of spaniels, short and long-legged terriers, Schnauzers and poodles to show standards.
course.mlo:objective:
You will have the opportunity to spend time working within the newly designed, well-equipped Dog Grooming Unit at Duchy College Rosewarne.  Here you can practise your skills in bathing and preparing a range of dogs with different coat types for the grooming process and you will also learn some basic trimming techniques.  You will learn the underpinning theory and assessment is via the completion of written assignments and practical assessments. There are no examinations.  The course covers the following units:

  • Approaching dogs, handling, correct control and restraint techniques
  • Health checks and recognising ill-health
  • Preparation and grooming of dogs prior to bathing
  • Correct bathing and cleaning techniques
  • Dry dogs and prepare their coats for styling
  • Basic trimming of a dog’s coat
  • Equipment for grooming – how it is used and maintained
  • Health and safety in the dog grooming environment
  • Dealing with clients
course.mlo:prerequisite: To do this course, you will find it advantageous to be working within the dog grooming industry (either as a volunteer or in paid employment) but this is not essential.  You also need to have a good level of literacy to enable you to complete the assignment work.

CE:cost.dc:description: Please call our Enquiries Team for more details on this course.

course.dc:description: This course is part-time, running one day per week (6 hours per day) over 36 weeks commencing in September 2011. You will need to have purchased you own set of grooming equipment and a grooming tunic.  We can advise you about this when you start the course.

The City and Guilds Level 3 Certificate for Professional Dog Stylists is a course for those who already have a high level of experience within the dog grooming industry, wishing to gain a nationally-recognised qualification to practise as a professional dog groomer. You will need to be working within the dog grooming industry (either as a volunteer or in paid employment) to enable you to practise the grooming skills on a range of dog breeds with different coat types
course.dc:subject: dog, dog grooming, dog groomer, dogs hair, fur, dog styling
Animal Management & Veterinary Nursing
course.dc:title: Professional Dog Stylists City & Guilds (NPTC) Diploma Level 3
course.learningOutcome: The Level 3 Diploma for Professional Dog Stylists will give you the skills to work in the grooming industry and possibly set up your own business. Alternatively you may wish to progress to the Higher Diploma.
course.mlo:objective:
The course requires you to complete a total of 44 credits and includes the following units:

  • Carry out the styling and finishing of dogs (6 credits)
  • Assessment and planning of dog grooming work (4 credits)
  • Promote and maintain the health & wellbeing of animals (4 credits)
  • Health checking a dog by a dog groomer (4 credits)
  • Hand stripping a dog’s coat (6 credits)
  • Style and trim a spaniel’s coat (6 credits)
  • Style and trim a short-legged terrier’s coat (6 credits)

There are also a number of optional units:   Optional Group A (you have to complete a minimum of 2 credits from this group):

  • Welcome, receive and care for visitors (3 credits)
  • Promote, monitor & maintain health, safety & security (6 credits)
  • Moving animals between locations (2 credits)
  • Handle payments from clients (2 credits)
  • Keep stock on sale at required levels in a retail environment (3 credits)

Optional Group B (you have to complete one of the units, worth  6 credits,  from this group):

  • Style and trim a poodle’s coat (6 credits)
  • Style and trim a long-legged terrier or Schnauzer’s coat (6 credits)
course.mlo:prerequisite: You will need to have completed either the City and Guilds Level 2 Certificate for Dog Grooming Assistants or the Level 2 College Certificate in Dog Grooming and have attained a good level of literacy to enable you to complete the assignment work and written exams.  You will also need to be working within the dog grooming industry to be able to gain sufficient experience of grooming and clipping dogs of a range of breeds at industry speed.

course.dc:description: The cost of this one day Taster course is £35.  The course runs from 9.30am until 4.00pm each day and you will need to wear sensible clothing (that you don't mind getting hairy!) and trainers/flat shoes (not flip flops).  You will also need to bring your own lunch, or you can purchase lunch in our cafe at Rosewarne.

This course is ideal if you are interested in finding out more about a career in dog grooming or wanting to learn some basic bathing and grooming techniques for your pet dog.  It will not give you the skills to start up a business as a Dog Groomer but will give you a taster of what this might involve.

course.dc:title: Dog Grooming Taster
course.abstract: Find out more about a career in dog grooming with this Taster course.
course.learningOutcome: Having completed this one day Taster course, you may wish to progress to the Level 2 College Certificate in Dog Grooming (one day per week over 12 weeks).  To gain your professional dog grooming qualifications you will need to progress to the City and Guilds Level 3 Certificate in Introductory Dog Grooming (one day per week over 30 weeks) and the Level 3 Diploma for Professional Dog Stylists.
course.mlo:objective:
This one day (6 hour) course will introduce you to the basics of bathing and grooming dogs in our state-of-the-art Dog Grooming Room at the Animal Management Centre at Duchy College Rosewarne.  It is an excellent starting point for progression to the Level 2 College Certificate in Dog Grooming, after which you can carry on to gain the professional City and Guilds Dog Grooming qualifications at Level 3.

The course covers:

  • Safe working techniques in the grooming salon
  • Approach, handling and restraint of dogs
  • Basic health checks prior to grooming
  • Grooming the coat in preparation for bathing
  • Bathing and cleaning techniques
  • Drying the coat and preparation for styling
  • Grooming equipment and its uses

There are four dates available:  Tuesday 16th June, Tuesday 23rd June, Tuesday 30th June and Tuesday 7th July 2015.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no specific entry requirements, although you will need to be over the age of 16.

course.dc:title: Canine First Aid
course.abstract: A 1 day canine first aid course.
course.learningOutcome: Working with animals means that you need to be prepared, and having basic first aid knowledge could save a life.  As well as giving you more confidence in your current job role, having basic first aid skills could also make you more employable in the future.
course.mlo:objective:
The course covers some common first aid problems that you may come across when working with canines, and includes both theory and practical elements. There will be a presentation, a workbook to complete and some practical sessions which will help you to administer basic first aid.

The modules include:

  • Principles of first aid, including legal requirements and limitations

  • The first aid kit, including customizations

  • Approach and assessment of the situation

  • Common emergencies including shock, seizures electrocution, dislocation/fractures and haemorrhage

  • Common problems with geriatric dogs

course.dc:description:
This course is offered at various sites across Cornwall and Devon.

  • Occombe Farm, Paignton, South Devon. The course is centred around sustainable production of a range of food crops where you will cover all aspects of production under cover (Polytunnels), in raised beds and outdoor production.
  • Duchy College,Rosewarne  (Green Fingers) where you will work within the extensive grounds, glasshouses and polytunnels and the Nursery and within the local community.
  • Heaven Scent, Wheel Martyn, St Austell within the Nursery and surrounding grounds.

Ideal if: you would like to improve your horticultural skills and knowledge, whilst gaining a nationally-recognised qualification.

You'll need: at least a GCSE at grade E or above in English and Mathematics, or an equivalent qualification. You will also need to have a keen interest in gardening and the environment.

You'll learn: about propagation, establishing plants, identification of plants, care and maintenance of plants, understanding the growing environment for plants and an introduction to common pests, diseases and their control.

Expect: your assignments and projects to be assessed throughout the course, and of course to get your hands dirty!

You'll love: learning about all aspects of production including polytunnels, raised beds and outdoors.

You'll go onto: a Level 2 Horticulture Apprenticeship or Diploma in which there is the opportunity to specialise in a particular area of horticulture if you so wish.

Animal Management & Veterinary Nursing
course.dc:title: Bee Keeping Introduction
course.abstract: An introduction to bee keeping
course.learningOutcome: The course is an excellent grounding for those wishing to keep bees and involves lectures, practical demonstrations, sharing of experiences along with answers to those unsure of whether to keep bees or not.
course.mlo:objective: The Basic Bee Keeping Part 1 is a 2 term course of 36 hours providing a grounding in beekeeping. This course aims to get you started before getting your bees. Practical sessions will take place from the end of April on Thursday evenings or Saturday afternoons. The course is an excellent grounding for those wishing to keep bees and involves lectures, practical demonstrations, sharing of experiences along with answers to those unsure of whether to keep bees or not. All teaching takes place at Rosewarne where West Cornwall Beekeepers Association has an outdoor apiary. The Basic Bee Keeping Part 2 is a follow on for those who have done part 1 and have at least a years' experience of keeping bees. On this course you will deal with preparation for the basic exam and reinforce your knowledge of diseases, husbandry skills, swarming and manipulation of the bees, honey extraction and legal requirements.

course.dc:description:
For more information, please call 01579 372327 or email uni@duchy.ac.uk
* Price is for 2010/11 entry.
Bursaries available - see student finance / tuition fees pages of our website for details.

This course is approved by the University of Plymouth

The college has details of a number of bursaries that may be suitable for applicants.

Click here to hear about how students from this course achieved royal success!

It is for anyone with the relevant background who wants undertake a further year of study to gain a full BSc (Hons) Degree.  It is designed for students who have already taken a Foundation Degree or HND in any land based and business subject. The subjects can be from the areas of agriculture, agri-food, equine, estate, animal management, environmental management or leisure. This course could also be of interest to those who already working in the industry but looking to progress and develop higher level skills.

UCAS Code: DN4G
Institution Code: DUCHY D55

 This programme will develop the student's existing knowledge to encompass the planning and management skills required to run a successful enterprise.   It is based on an analytical approach to problem solving and communication. The programme is highly flexible, allowing the students to study in detail a chosen topic through a research project and a selection of modules which are available in response to student demand. In some of the modules there will be opportunities for students to work closely with rural industry, businesses including the Rural Business School and organisations.  Past examples include Dartmoor Farmers, St Mellion International Resorts and The Wonderful Bear Emporium.  

Changes and developments in today's business environment mean there are more opportunities to gain projects and effectively run them. Being aware of how to make a business flexible, manage the changes and develop creative ideas to make business sustainable will offer a great experience to enhance future careers.

Modules

Core

  • Honours Project (40 credits)
  • Strategic Management Issues (20 credits) 
  • Marketing (20 credits)

 Optional (choose two)

  • Agricultural Technology (20 credits)
  • Environmental Management (20 credits)
  • Funding & Developing Rural Projects (20 credits)
  • Managing Animal Performance (20 credits)          
  • Food Processing Systems (20 credits)      
  • Controversial Issues in the Food Industry (20 credits)   
  • Personal Development Planning (20 credits)
  • Business on the Golf Course (20 credits)
  • Managing Leisure (20 credits)
  • Technological Development for Golf (20 credits)
  • International Rural Development (20 credits)
course.dc:subject: Agriculture, BSc, enterprise, consultant, consultancy, farm manager, estate manager, agricultural, estate, estate manager, environment, farm
Business
course.dc:title: BSc (Hons) Rural Business Management
course.abstract: This programme will develop your existing knowledge to encompass the planning and management skills required to run a successful enterprise
course.mlo:assessment:
Assessment Methods

The programme is assessed in a variety of modes such as presentations, consultancy reports and practical case studies.
course.learningOutcome:
Having completed the BSc (Hons) in Rural Business Management the majority of students are expected to work within their industry. The qualification equips students with the range of skills required for a career in land and farm management. It also prepares students to progress to further education at masters or doctorate levels should they wish to do so.  This progression to honours year allows students to either specialise or be more generic in their studies. Either way the support from a group of highly experienced staff will help the students' development and advance their business skills.

The course aims to give students a wide range of academic, personal and transferable skills which enable them to be effective in various areas of employment including running their own business. On successful completion of the course, students could progress to careers such as:

  • Business consultant
  • Farm manager
  • Estate manager
  • Supply trade manager
  • Retail manager
  • Lecturer
  • Sales and marketing
  • Government and policy development in the rural sector
  • Project manager
  • Graduate trainee

As an honours graduate, the student will have a wide choice of career opportunities throughout the private and public sectors, both in the United Kingdom and abroad.

Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression. Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm) Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
This is a one year, full-time, modular programme. Attendance is two days per week, allowing the students to undertake part-time work to fund their studies.  Students must complete three compulsory modules: Strategic Management Issues, Marketing and an Honours Project, plus two optional modules.

The Strategic Management Issues module will help develop the understanding of different approaches to thinking and developing strategy. It has a large industry based element working with organisations. The Marketing module is designed to illustrate the dynamic influences on a business and the need for a planned approach to marketing through marketing management. The Honours Project module is a major piece of investigative research (twice the size of other modules in the programme) that students will undertake under the supervision of a personal supervisor. It will be in a subject that is of interest to the student personally, relevant to the course and has been agreed with the programme manager. It can also be a project that is developed with and of benefit to an industry or organisation. 

There will be a natural progression and evolution of knowledge and understanding through the two selected optional modules of the student's choice.   There will also be an opportunity for the students to extend their scope of knowledge through some of the optional modules.  For examples, the Funding and Developing Rural Projects aims to identify funding routes with the rural sectors including both statutory and non-statutory organisations as well as the role and funding routes of Non-Governmental Organisations (NGOs).  It identifies projects, potential funding routes and builds up project bids.   The Personal Development Planning module will allow students to focus on their own personal journey or aspiration or career development where the students will determine how they will be assessed with the support from specialist tutors.   This includes writing their own assignment briefs. 

There is also the possibility of combining some assessments with Chartered Management Institute qualifications, giving the students the chance to stand out from the competition.  There would be an additional cost.

Teaching & Learning

The course will be taught at Duchy College Stoke Climsland, industrial experience has been built in. Dedicated programme staff will deliver the course through lectures, which also have guest speakers, field trips and tutorials.
course.mlo:prerequisite: 240 credits at Level 5 from a Foundation Degree or HND in a relevant subject.

The agriculture programme at Duchy College is designed for those who would like to widen their knowledge of the agricultural industry with a view to managing agricultural operations after graduation. The course provides a thorough understanding of modern farming production systems and an in-depth knowledge of the underlying scientific and technological principles.

UCAS Code: D401
Institution Code: Duchy D55

Modules
Year 1
 
  • Personal & Employability Skills Development (20 credits)
  • Research Skills (10 credits)
  • Livestock Production (20 credits)
  • Farm Mechanisation & Postharvest Management (20 credits) 
  • Understanding the Farm Business (20 credits)
  • Crop Production & Soil Science (20 credits)
  • Agriculture & the Food Chain (10 credits)
 
Year 2
Core
  • Research Project (20 credits)
  • Business Planning (20 credits)
  • Contemporary Issues (20 credits)
  • Strategic Development (20 credits)
 
Optional (choose two)
  • Plant Legislation, Technology & Marketing (20 credits) 
  • Analysis & Development of Livestock Enterprises (20 credits)
  • Effective Leadership (20 credits)

course.abstract: FdSc Agriculture
course.mlo:assessment:
Assessment methods

A combination of assessment methods is used: assignments, seminars, presentations, case studies, practicals, tests and examinations. Work-related learning is embedded throughout the course.
course.learningOutcome:
As a graduate of this programme you will have acquired significant practical skills and scientific knowledge. You may wish to consider continuing your studies or you may choose to go straight into employment. Careers opportunities are plentiful for example
•    Farm manager
•    Farm consultant,
•    Agronomist
•    Agricultural related financial management
•    Technical advisor
•    Land manager
•    Nutritionist
•    Estate manager

Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression. Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm) Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
This full-time course last two years. Each year has two semesters and you will cover six modules per semester. A semester lasts 15 weeks.

If you study part-time you will be able to continue to work, perhaps on the family farm, run your own enterprises or work part-time during your studies. Part-time students will be able to study selected modules.

A wide range of delivery modes are used both within and outside of the College. Industry wide expertise is available and supports the programme, including project staff from the Rural Business School, the College farm, local employers and advisory personnel.

You can focus on chosen subject areas, including the science and technology behind livestock and crop production and management.

Additionally you will gain a comprehensive understanding of modern farming systems and the wider issues facing the agricultural industry, including the key areas of sustainable food production and the impact of climate change.

Underpinning science and academic knowledge is integral; however the programme also maintains a considerable amount of practical farm management.

We can also provide you with the support and opportunities to take further qualifications alongside your degree, for example:

  • Transporting livestock
  • Telehandler
  • Chainsaw
  • Veterinary Medicine 
  • PA1 PA2 PA6 Spraying Certificate
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - PPP Grades required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3.  Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language and mathematics: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

If you are unsure of your suitability please call us on 0845 60 50 455 or email enquiries@duchy.ac.uk.

You’ll need: four GCSEs at grade D or above including English and mathematics, or equivalent qualifications, and a keen interest in conservation.

You’ll learn: a range of skills while working as part of a team surveying and monitoring a range of habitats and working with conservation and environmental groups.

You’ll love: working on projects in partnership with leading conservation organisations in Cornwall and Devon.

You’ll go onto: employment in environmental conservation or further study on our Countryside and Wildlife Management Extended Diploma.
