course.dc:description:
This is a Level 4 qualification where each module attracts credits towards a City & Guilds Level 4 Diploma in Agricultural Business Management (12 in total).

On the technical side the programme focuses on dairy cows, beef and sheep, the business and finance skills could be applied to any type of farm business.

This flexible programme is designed to fit around your current business activities and work commitments. Each module is delivered in 3 or 4 days. This is supported by considerable study on the farm – putting your theory into practice i.e. application and drawing on the knowledge pool. This approach minimises the impact on your ‘day job’. All modules are delivered by industry and academic experts and supplemented by study materials and online resources for you to use on a day-to-day basis.
course.dc:subject: Agriculture
course.dc:title: Work-Based Agricultural Business Management City & Guilds Diploma Level 4 (QCF)
course.abstract: This programme focuses on dairy cows, beef and sheep, the business and finance skills could be applied to any farm business.
course.mlo:assessment: Assessments are predominantly farm based and will focus on knowledge/understanding, appraisal, planning for improvement, implementation, monitoring and evaluation. Thus students apply what they have studied to their own situation.
course.learningOutcome: You could go on to study our FdSc Agriculture (Level 5) or seek employment progression as a result of successful completion.
course.mlo:objective:
Our innovative and flexible approach aims to minimise the time spent away from your job – so you can apply your learning back in the workplace immediately.

It is planned that all of the above modules would be offered to participants over a 24 month period with a further 6 months required for the completion of assessment.

The programme will commence In September 2015 and run for 20 to 25 days over two winters. Attendance will be one day per week, running until Easter time.

Assessment will be mainly farm based and ongoing throughout the two years. A specialist assessor will visit the farm on a regular basis to collect evidence. This will comprise farm documentation (hard or on screen), professional discussion, written supporting and explanatory evidence, observation and witness/personal statements. There are no examinations or written tests in the Diploma.

The programme will run from Stoke Climsland and subject to numbers also from Rosewarne

Standard training days will be 9.30am to 4.30pm.

Delivery will be very much along the lines of a discussion group led much of the time by a specialist speaker from Industry.

Note for those doing the Apprenticeships there will be a need to do some additional qualifications including Functional Skills at Level 2 in Literacy and Numeracy (unless these have already been achieved).
course.mlo:prerequisite:
The course is aimed at those:

  • Who have achieved a Level 3 Diploma / Extended Diploma in Agriculture (formerly the National Certificate / Diploma) or a Level 3 Work-based Diploma in Agriculture (formerly NVQ Level 3), or similar, and are now working in the agricultural industry and aiming to take on more responsibility, or those that need to develop higher level skills in post.
  • Individuals who have obtained a HND or degree will benefit considerably from the applied nature of this programme and are eligible for entry.

For those without the qualifications above please contact us to discuss your eligibility.

course.abstract: The Research Masters is a Masters-level degree
course.learningOutcome:
Possible Careers

  • Advisor
  • High-level Manager
  • Academic
  • Researcher
  • Industry Consultant

Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression. 

Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm)

Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
This programme offers you the opportunity to study a specific area of agriculture and food, biological science or equitation science in detail and depth. It is a higher-level qualification that allows those with a good understanding of agriculture and food science to further develop and focus their skills.

There is an increasing need for highly trained and skilled scientists to assist in the development and understanding of agriculture and food, biological and equine sciences.

Graduates from this programme of study will help to meet this need.

The Research Masters will develop and advance your knowledge of the science underpinning agriculture and food. You will quickly develop an understanding of the importance of the multidisciplinary approach to this diverse and complex area.

The Research Masters incorporates both taught and research elements and can be completed either on a full or part-time basis.

You will undertake two taught modules which will make up 40 credits in total. These modules typically focus on research methods and contemporary issues but may vary according to your subject area.   You will then undertake a substantial research project under the supervision of a team of subject experts.

Whilst undertaking the ResM you will be supported by two supervisors (the Director of Studies based at Duchy working with a member of staff from Plymouth University) who will assist you with the selection of your optional module. Your supervisor will also guide you on the extended research project which is expected to take 12 months to complete. The research project is examined by means of thesis and viva voce.

This programme offers you the opportunity to study a subject that truly inspires and engages you. You will advance and expand your skills in a supportive and personal environment. Whilst our staff are

academically acclaimed they are also accessible and genuinely interested in helping you to develop your potential. All this in an environment that is both intellectually stimulating and visually outstanding.
course.mlo:prerequisite: 2:1 in a biological or related science BSc (Hons) degree with a 2:1 grade for the honours project element

This exciting new programme has been specifically designed for students who wish to gain a sound understanding of issues surrounding animal health, including diagnosis of disease, causes of ill health and modern advances in treatment, and the management of a wide variety of species.  Making use of our excellent practical facilities, building on links with the Rural Business School, Dartmoor Zoological Park and more than 40 Veterinary practices across Cornwall and Devon, we can ensure that students have excellent access to hands-on experience and the benefit of up-to-date Veterinary knowledge.

Modules 
Year 1
 
  • Functional Anatomy (20 credits)
  • Introduction to Animal Health (10 credits)
  • Research Skills (10 credits)
  • Practical Animal Health & Management (20 credits)
  • Animal Behaviour (20 credits)
  • The Animal Health Industry (20 credits)
  • Personal & Employability Skills Development (20 credits)
Year 2
Core
  • Research Skills (20 credits)
  • Contemporary Issues in Animal Health (20 credits)
  • Applied Animal Nutrition (20 credits)
  • Animal Health & Disease (20 credits)
  • Animal Health Planning (20 credits)
 
Optional (choose one)
  • Welfare, Care & Rehabilitation (20 credits)
  • Pharmacy & Diagnostics (20 credits)
course.dc:subject: vet, veterinary, animal behaviour, animal training, animal, animals,animal courses, conservation, zoo, behavioural ecology, animal management, animal therapy, applied psychology, dogs, cats, primate, monkey, Screech, Paradise Park, Newquay, Cornwall
Animal Management & Veterinary Nursing
course.dc:title: FdSc Animal Health and Management
course.abstract: This new programme has been designed for students who wish to gain an understanding of issues surrounding animal health and management.
course.mlo:assessment: Assessment is via a range of written assignments and practical assessments, reports, in-class tests, presentations and group discussions. You will compile a portfolio of skills developed during practical sessions.
course.learningOutcome:
You may wish to continue your studies or will be well equipped to move into employment, perhaps in animal nutrition, health or welfare; epidemiology; veterinary pharmacology or practice management; wildlife biology; zoo keeping, curating or managing.
 
Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression.  Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm) Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
Aspects of animal health and management are studied through a range of interrelated modules, giving you a solid grounding in this specialist area. 
 
This foundation degree can be studied full-time or part-time. Either route will give you amazing opportunities to develop your knowledge of health and husbandry, and work with a wide range of species within our Animal Management Centres at our Stoke Climsland and Rosewarne campuses (where the creation of a brand new state-of-the-art facility is currently underway).
 
You will also have regular access to our Equine Yard and the Duchy College Home Farm (where there are plans for a new hi-tech dairy unit). Links with Dartmoor Zoological Park have developed in the past year and there are sound opportunities to enable you to broaden your experience with a wider range of exotic species, including big cats, wolves, monkeys, capybara, reindeer, tapirs and wallabies.
 
The teaching programme makes good use of the excellent links we have with veterinary practices across the South West, through the work of our Veterinary Nursing Centre and the Rural Business School. 
 
Study tours will give you the opportunity to gain first-hand experience of the animal health industry, both nationally and internationally.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points. Applications are welcomed from students returning to education and students with a non-biological background.
 
Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 0845 60 50 455 or email enquiries@duchy.ac.uk.

course.dc:description: The level 3 training will enable you to run a Forest school in partnership with local schools and pre schools, delivering an alternative complimentary curriculum to Foundation Stage, Primary or Secondary school children. You may also offer Family Fun Forest School events or similar.
This course is designed to meet the needs of Teachers, Teaching Assistants, Early Years Educators, Youth Workers, Play Workers and other professionals in training as a Forest School Leader.

course.dc:title: Forest School Programme Leadership AptEd Certificate Level 3
course.abstract: The training is suitable for teachers, play workers, early years professionals, early years workers, forest school childcare early duchy
course.learningOutcome: Successful candidates can seek employment within the children's workforce as a Forest School Leader or become a self-employed provider of Forest School.
course.mlo:objective:
This course enables learners to gain the skills and knowledge required to plan and lead groups in Forest School Programmes and activities.  The course consists of taught theory and practical elements as well as coursework to be completed during and after initial training. You will complete 5 units linked to learning outcomes:

  • Delivery of Forest School - this includes planning, leading and evaluating a pilot programme of a minimum of 6 sessions with your client group.
  • Forest School Practical Skills
  • Forest School and the Woodland Environment
  • Learning and Development at Forest School
  • Planning Forest School

Duration: one day every other week for 8 weeks (no session during school half term) plus around 110 hours of self-study supported by extensive resources in our virtual learning environment. In person, email and telephone tutorial support is available by arrangement with the course tutor. All enrolled students have access to the learning resource centres on all Cornwall College campuses for one year. Learners are expected to submit completed portfolios of work 10 months from the date of enrolment.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
• Age 21 years or over
  • Have a level 3 or above qualification ( NNEB, Teacher, Play worker or Youth worker (to level 3 or equivalent) OR level 2 with a portfolio of at least 2 years experience of working with children/young people in a leadership capacity
  • Have considerable experience of working with young people
  • Before leading sessions, learners must ensure that they have a valid DBS check, first aid provision and appropriate insurance and site permissions.
  • By the end of the course you will need to complete a 2 day certificated course in Outdoor First Aid for the Forest School practitioner.  Details of trainers in the area can be provided.

You will be required to be in practice whether paid or voluntary for at least 1 day a week throughout the duration of your course. Your setting will need to provide you with a letter of support whilst you undertake the Foundation Degree or HNC

Bursaries are available subject to status - please see Student Finance on website for details.  This course is approved by the University of Plymouth.

This foundation degree has been designed to meet the developing roles within the sector for those working with children, young people and their families. It is anticipated that applicants will be developing careers within the children's workforce and seeking a qualification which will facilitate the opportunity to explore a wide range of career directions, which may include those in Nursery or Primary education, care, special needs, family support, outdoor learning, Youth Work or play, among others. It may be of particular interest to practitioners already in employment who would like to study in college on one day a week and undertake their research and self study in their work or home environments.  The successful completion of this course qualifies you to level 5.  You may then if you wish continue with a top up course to obtain a full Honours degree at level 6.

Modules

Year 1 Core

  • Reflective Practice (20 credits)
  • Interpersonal & Communication Skills (20 credits)
  • Safeguarding Children & Young People (20 credits)
  • Developmental Perspectives (20 credits)
  • Personal & Employability Skills Development (20 credits)

Optional (choose one)

  • Constructions of Childhood & Youth (20 credits)
  • Working with children & Families (20 credits)
  • Forest School (20 credits)
  • Risk Versus Challenge in the Outdoors (20 credits)
  • Sport & Young People (20 credits)
  • Supporting Learners Learning (20 credits)
  • Curriculum Issues (20 credits)
  • New Learning Technologies (20 credits)
  • Behaviour for Learning (20 credits)
  • Special Study (1) (20 credits)
  • The Third Sector (20 credits)
  • Supporting Special Educational Needs (20 credits)
  • Entrepreneurship & Applied Practice (20 credits)

Year 2 Core

  • Supporting Transitions (20 credits)
  • Multi-agency Collaboration (20 credits)
  • Inclusive Practice (20 credits)
  • Applied Research Practice Project (20 credits)

Optional (choose two)

  • Outdoor Experiential Learning (20 credits)
  • Crime, Young People & the Law (20 credits)
  • The Lead Professional (20 credits)
  • Working with Disaffected Young People (20 credits)
  • The Learning Mentor Role in Schools (20 credits)
  • Role of the Play-based Curriculum (20 credits)
  • Psychology of Learning & Teaching (20 credits)

course.dc:description: This training will enable you to assist a qualified Forest School Leader to deliver an alternative complementary outdoor learning programme.

This course is designed for those who wish to assist a qualified Level 3 Forest School Leader in running Forest School programmes. It is suitable for Teaching Assistants, Nursery/Pre-School practitioners, Youth Workers, Play Workers and Outdoor Adventure Play practitioners and is an ideal start for practitioners in building confidence in Forest School.
course.dc:subject: Early Years, Playwork & Forest School
course.dc:title: Forest School Programme Support apt awards Award Level 2
course.abstract: The Forest School Assistant level 2 is an ideal start for practitioners in building confidence in Forest School activities
course.learningOutcome: Successful candidates can seek employment within the children’s workforce in a supporting role or progress to the Level 3 course if seeking greater responsibility.
course.mlo:objective:
This course enables learners to gain the skills and knowledge required to qualify and become a Forest School Assistant, enabling them to take a proactive role in helping the Forest School Leader plan and deliver the Forest School programme and support learners. Delivery will comprise both indoor and outdoor activities, practical and theory. Assessment is by observation and a portfolio of evidence.

 You will complete 2 units linked to learning outcomes:

  • Skills for the Forest School Programme Assistant. This unit will introduce you to sustainable woodland management in the context of learning activities, risk management as well as training in use of fire and tools with client groups.
  • Supporting Learning and Development at a Forest School programme. This unit explores the topics of holistic development and learning through play, promoting positive behaviour and also will involve the student assisting with planning and delivery of 3 sessions in a Forest School Programme (students will need to arrange their own placement).

Duration: one day per week for 5 weeks (no session during school half term) plus around 20 hours of self-study supported by extensive resources in our virtual learning environment. In person, email and telephone tutorial support is available by arrangement with the course tutor. All enrolled students have access to the learning resource centres on all Cornwall College campuses for one year. Learners are expected to submit completed portfolios of work 10 months from the date of enrolment.
course.mlo:prerequisite: Applicants should hold a relevant qualification equivalent to a level 1 or some experience of working with children/young people, have a current DBS disclosure and be aged 18 and over.

For more information, please call 01579 372327 or email uni@duchy.ac.uk

Bursaries available - see student finance / tuition fees pages of our website for details.

This degree top-up course is designed for anyone who wishes to work with horses, bridging the gap between the academic study of behaviour and its practical application in training. This programme focuses on the new and exciting area of equitation science and is designed for those who have completed an equine-related foundation degree or equivalent, and would like to top up to full honours degree. You will investigate aspects of equitation that have been taken for granted for many years, applying theory to practice, making substantial use of industry scenarios and realistic case studies throughout.

The BSc (Hons) Applied Equitation Science progression to honours year delivers a contemporary curriculum based on modern research findings. The programme relies on the application of a multifaceted approach to equitation. Graduates of this BSc will be able to promote and encourage the application of objective research and advanced practice which will ultimately improve the welfare of horses in their associations with humans.

This course is a progression to honours year. It has been developed for students who already hold a Foundation Degree or HND in a relevant subject.

UCAS Code: D427
Institution Code: DUCHY D55

Core Modules
 
  • Honours Project (40 credits)
  • Equitation Science (20 credits) 
  • Veterinary Issues in Equine Science (20 credits)
 
Optional modules (choose two)
 
  • Applied Rider Performance  (20 credits) 
  • Applied Equine Learning and Psychology (20 credits)
  • Managing Equine Performance (20 credits)

Equine
course.dc:title: BSc (Hons) Applied Equitation Science (Top Up)
course.abstract: A course for anyone wishing to understand horse training and welfare
course.mlo:assessment: The course uses a wide range of assessment modes that are relevent to industry and enhance student employability.  The external examiners of the course commend the use of innovative and relevant assessment year on year.
course.learningOutcome:
The programme allows you to develop a wide range of academic, personal and transferable skills which enable you to be effective in various areas of employment. On graduating you will have gained a comprehensive knowledge of the principles of equitation science. You will be confident in the application of these principles in order to effectively facilitate the management of horses and humans in both performance and non-performance capacities.
 
Possible careers include:
 
  • Equine behaviour consultant
  • Equine industry advisor
  • Equine management
  • Lecturer/Teacher
  • Trainer
  • Researcher
  • Welfare organisation
  • Equine charity
  • Equine competition
  • Equine management
  • Training and rehabilitiation
  • Working alongside veterinary professionals
Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression. Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm) Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
The course focuses on the brand new, unique and exciting area of equitation science. On this course you will investigate aspects of equitation that have been taken for granted for many years. Throughout the course academic theory will be applied to practice. This course will enable you to further develop existing knowledge to enable dissemination of emerging findings to the industry for the development, education and enhancement of horses and their owners. The knowledge gained on this course will be applicable to horses and owners operating at both leisure and competitive levels at all levels. 
 
The course includes a substantial honours project in which you will be able to investigate in detail a subject of your choice within the equitation science discipline. Other areas covered include equitation science, contemporary issues in equine science, equine learning and psychology and equine and rider performance. Throughout the programme you will also have the opportunity to become involved in applied research identified by the International Society for Equitation Science.
 
You will be given the opportunity to engage in field work and data collection to support the theory learnt and also to put theory into practice. This may involve the collection of live data on the Duchy College Equestrian Centre or elsewhere. Every opportunity will be taken to expose you to emerging technologies within the rapidly evolving discipline of equitation science. There will be lectures,  seminars and presentations from industry professionals, veterinary physiotherapists, performance specialists, equine trainers and animal welfare scientists.    You will also benefit from strong links between the International Society for Equitation Science and the programme teaching staff.
course.mlo:prerequisite: 240 credits at Level 5 from an equine-related foundation degree or equivalent.

presentation.dc:subject: Equine
presentation.dc:title: BSc (Hons) Applied Equitation Science (Full Time Top-up)
presentation.mlo:assessment: The course uses a wide range of assessment modes that are relevent to industry and enhance student employability.  The external examiners of the course commend the use of innovative and relevant assessment year on year.

course.dc:description:
This course has been designed for anyone from undergraduates to mature students who are interested in the training, behaviour and welfare of horses used for a wide range of purposes, from leisure to international competition.  Delivery by an established team of world-leading professionals ensures that content is contemporary and encompasses recent advances within allied industries and allows exploration of traditional and emerging equestrian disciplines alike.

This FdSc Equitation, Training & Behaviour is the only bespoke programme in the UK at this level which allows you to concentrate your study on the science that underpins equitation.

 

UCAS Code: D422
Institution Code: DUCHY D55

Modules

Year 1

  • Introduction to Equine Science (20 credits)
  • Equine Industry, Practice & Welfare (20 credits)
  • Principles of Training (20 credits)
  • Equine Systems (10 credits)
  • Research Skills (10 credits)
  • Equine Business Management (10 credits)
  • Equid Structure & Function (10 credits)
  • Personal & Employability Skills Development (20 credits)

Year 2

  • Research Project (20 credits)
  • Applied Equine Science (20 credits)
  • Principles of Equitation Science (20 credits)
  • Application of Training Principles (20 credits)
  • Contemporary Issues in Equestrianism (20 credits)
  • Physical & Psychological Management of the Horse (20 credits)
course.dc:subject: equine horse horse management horse behaviour equitation equitation science foundation degree, FdSc
Equine
course.dc:title: FdSc Equitation Training and Behaviour
course.abstract: A course designed to support the welfare of the horse in the many aspects of equestrainism today through research and education
course.learningOutcome:
On successful completion you will be able to go on to take the BSc (Hons) Equitation Science honours year and from there you will be able to progress to Master's level. Alternatively you may go straight into employment, as many of our previous graduates have done and are now working as consultants, lecturers, researchers and as professionals in equine ancillary industries.

Possible careers include:

  • Equine Behaviour Consultant
  • Trainer
  • Equine Industry Advisor
  • Equine Management
  • Lecturer
  • Researcher
  • Welfare Organisation
  • Equine Charity
course.mlo:objective:
The programme is underpinned by three fundamental themes and on successful completion of the programme you will be able to justify the use of horses for a range of purposes within the industry.

During Year 1 you will gain a detailed understanding of the underpinning biology and psychology of the equid. You will also develop a comprehensive appreciation of the wider horse industry and essential business aspects. You will be supported in reaching informed decisions regarding the well being of equids and begin to understand the complexities of working in an area in which there are two or three sentient beings (trainer, equestrian and horse).

During Year 2 you will continue to develop your analytical skills through the application of theory to practice. You will be given opportunities to assess and improve not only your individual equitation skills but that of others too, resulting in measurable improvements. During this year you will also undertake a research project in which you will conduct an independent piece of research in an area of your choice within equitation science.

During the programme you have to complete a minimum of two weeks of work related experience related to module assessments.

There are also two study tours organised by the College during the programme to further enhance your education; national in Year 1 and International in Year 2.

The programme contains a coherent mixture of theory and application. Delivery methods include practical application from the commencement of the programmes, in terms of using live horses in real life situations, in addition to workshops and discussion groups. Other methods include lectures, group classroom delivery, student and staff led seminars, structured visits and visiting speakers. The programme is delivered by internationally recognised equine scientists and Olympic-level trainers.

Assessments for this programme will include a small number of examinations and traditional coursework (typically essays and reports). Reflective practice presentations, Dragons' Den style sessions,  practicals and portfolios are also assessment methods. This mixture will enable you to develop theoretical, practical, analytical and application skills expanding your professional development supported with the 3-4 weeks of work-related activity.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - PPP Grades required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3.  Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language and mathematics: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

Level 3 equine students are encouraged to apply.

If you are unsure of your suitability please call us on 0845 60 50 455 or email: enquiries@duchy.ac.uk.

Possible Careers

  • Advisor
  • High-level Manager

Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression.

course.mlo:objective:
This programme offers you the opportunity to study a specific area of agriculture and food, biological science or equitation science in detail and depth. It is a higher-level qualification that allows those with a good understanding of agriculture and food science to further develop and focus their skills.

There is an increasing need for highly trained and skilled scientists to assist in the development and understanding of agriculture and food, biological and equine sciences.

Graduates from this programme of study will help to meet this need.

The Research Masters will develop and advance your knowledge of the science underpinning agriculture and food. You will quickly develop an understanding of the importance of the multidisciplinary approach to this diverse and complex area.

The Research Masters incorporates both taught and research elements and can be completed either on a full or part-time basis.

You will undertake two taught modules which will make up 40 credits in total. These modules typically focus on research methods and contemporary issues but may vary according to your subject area.   You will then undertake a substantial research project under the supervision of a team of subject experts.

Whilst undertaking the ResM you will be supported by two supervisors (the Director of Studies based at Duchy working with a member of staff from Plymouth University) who will assist you with the selection of your optional module. Your supervisor will also guide you on the extended research project which is expected to take 12 months to complete. The research project is examined by means of thesis and viva voce.

This programme offers you the opportunity to study a subject that truly inspires and engages you. You will advance and expand your skills in a supportive and personal environment. Whilst our staff are

academically acclaimed they are also accessible and genuinely interested in helping you to develop your potential. All this in an environment that is both intellectually stimulating and visually outstanding.
course.mlo:prerequisite: 2:1 in a biological or related science BSc (Hons) degree with a 2:1 grade for the honours project element

The Certificate in Food Manufacturing Excellence is for those wishing to undertake a sustainable continuous improvement programme delivered entirely in the workplace, alongside appreciating the principles of working in food manufacture.  A practical combination of hygiene and food safety regulations, together with the application of continuous improvement techniques delivers many business benefits.
course.dc:subject: Food manufacturing, catering, food, food and drink, food and drink manufacturing, operations, food & drink, manufacturing, NVQ, proficiency in food, manufacturing excellence, fdq
Food Manufacturing & Technology
course.dc:title: Food Manufacturing Excellence FDQ Certificate for Proficiency Level 2
course.learningOutcome: Upon successful completion, learners may choose to progress to the next Level.
course.mlo:objective:
During this course, you will develop and demonstrate competence in a range of practical areas, which principally include:

  • Working together as a team
  • Product quality
  • Food safety
  • Health and safety
  • Resolution of problems through diagnosis
  • Continuous improvement
  • Development of standard operating procedures
  • HACCP
  • Waste identification
  • Risk management

These qualifications offer a mix of competence to suit the needs of the industry.  Essentially they contain a blend of change management, improvement tools and techniques and other supporting competences which endeavour to provide sustainability for lean culture and its application within the sector. 

This course is studied entirely in your work-place developing and adding knowledge and proficiency to your normal job of work. Assessments are through observations, discussions, questioning sessions and through the construction of a portfolio of evidence.

The duration of this programme is dependent on the business needs, but the average timescale is 12-16 weeks, with eight 1 day workshops included.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements, but you must be employed within the food industry.  It is also expected that a genuine interest is held in supporting discussions with our team of experts to ensure that the principles are being implemented and that change is happening.

course.mlo:objective:
During this course, you will complete 27 credits, which are made up from units drawn from 3 groups:

  • Change Management - these units enable learners to develop the competencies to engage and develop people during the change process
  • Tools and Techniques – the tools and techniques necessary to drive improvement in a food environment, including Kaizen and Six Sigma
  • Food Manufacturing Knowledge - these units underpin the tools and techniques.

The aims and objectives for this course are:

  • Sustainable development & performance improvement
  • Re-establish the basics
  • Establish competence and credibility for First Line Managers
  • Develop assessment skills to ensure learning is implemented
  • Engage all levels in the business in a problem solving culture
  • Establish a performance improvement culture
  • Reinforce key behaviours
  • Develop competence in Lean Management Tools & Techniques
  • Be a key part of your business’ future profitability.

Assessment is through means of observations, discussions, questioning sessions and through the construction of a portfolio of evidence.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements, but you must be employed within the food industry. A Level 2 Certificate is desirable, while it is expected that a genuine interest is held in supporting discussions with our team of experts to ensure that the principles are being implemented and that change is happening.

Great for anyone wishing to take an HE qualification specialising in the food industry. The course offers a wide series of modules to enable the development of practical and academic skills involved in human nutrition and dietary needs of the population providing graduates with the opportunity to consider a range of progression and employment options.

UCAS Code: D690
Institutiona Code: DUCHY D55

Year 1

course.dc:subject: FdSc, food, food manufacture, food studies, dairy, meat, product development, NPD, food technology, science, food tech,
Food Manufacturing & Technology
course.dc:title: FdSc Food Studies
course.abstract: FdSc Food Studies
course.learningOutcome:
The theory and practical training you gain from this foundation degree gives you the opportunity to pursue a range of careers in the food and drink industry, for example: 

    • product development 
    • nutrition
    • quality assurance
    • production management
    • marketing 
    • sales and food technologist
Duchy College graduates have a high reputation within the regional industry, 100% of past students either progressed to a BSc Hons or started a career in the food industry. 
 
 
Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression. Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm) Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
The programme covers relevant subjects for the food technologist. This includes food safety, food quality, food processing and food science and nutrition. 
 
These subjects are studied in the context of a range of foods that are made in our state-of-the-art food processing facility: including cheese, bread, beer, sausages and so on. In addition to these practical based subjects you will investigate aspects of the agrifood industry as a whole, including supply and demand issues within the industry.
 
In your second year subjects learned in year one are further developed: managing quality and safety in the food industry, application of food science and nutrition and in the development of a new food product. 
 
At the end of this development process you will present your product to a panel of specialists from the food industry. 
 
Whilst at the College you will have regular practical sessions within either the food processing pilot plant or in the microbiology laboratory and will also visit a wide range of food producers in the region. You will also have the opportunity to ensure that products that you make are safe and legal for commercial sale. You are encouraged and supported to undertake a work placement activity, so you can put the theory into practice. 
 
The course is a mixture of practical or laboratory classes and classroom based learning. Visits to relevant food processing factories in the region further enhance the learning and your tutors and guest speakers are experts in their subject. 
 
You will be assessed by practical reports, essays, case studies, presentations, in-class tests, portfolios and there are only two exams, both in your final year.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - PPP Grades required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3.  Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language and mathematics: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

If you are unsure of your suitability please call us on 0845 60 50 455 or email enquiries@duchy.ac.uk.

course.dc:description: If you have a passion for food or science, or care about how your food is produced then the Level 3 Diploma in food Technology and Management is for you!  Food technology combines many aspects including a range of sciences, practical food production, design and technology so the course is challenging and stimulating.
course.dc:subject: food food technology meat dairy bakery processing science microbiology
Food Manufacturing & Technology
course.dc:title: Food Technology and Management FDQ Diploma Level 3
course.abstract: Have a passion for food or science, or care about how your food is produced?
course.learningOutcome:
Having completed the Diploma, you could start your career in the country's largest industry, working in dairy, meat, fish, bakery, fruit and vegetable or even the confectionery or beverage sectors.  You could chose to work in a laboratory or as a technical technologist or you might prefer to work in the production of foods.  The course aims to enable you to work at supervisor level although most companies will want you to undertake an induction before taking command of a production line.

Students who want to go on to higher education can continue their studies at Duchy College, by going on to the two year FdSc Food Studies and may, on successful completion, continue onto the final year of a relevant honours degree at the College.
course.mlo:objective:
During year one of the course you will study the production of a wide range of products including fruit and vegetable products, dairy products (cheese, cream, butter, yogurt and so on) and bakery products.  You will also study how to produce these foods safely, which will include microbiology and food safety issues.  Since we aim to be able to sell some of our produce you will learn about food labelling and packaging.  In year one you will also study the underpinning science behind food manufacturing.

In the second year of the course you will get the opportunity to learn about the production of meat and fish products which will give you a breadth of knowledge across the wider food sector.  You will also learn how to develop new products and will undertake a project linked to this, which may well be driven by one of our partner businesses.  During this second year you will learn some of the key management techniques so that you should be able to work at supervisor level and may work with year one students to supervise their work.

Throughout the course you will produce foods in our fantastic, registered food processing unit, where you will learn the importance of working to food industry standards.  You will also have the chance to visit a wide range of local food businesses to see how what you are learning is put into practise commercially.  Our friendly team of staff will help you develop your study skills so that you can achieve a high level if you choose.  This will also enable you to progress onto the Foundation Degree in Food Studies offered here at Duchy College.
course.mlo:prerequisite: To gain entry to the course you should have a suitable level 2 qualification.  These include, 4 GCSE at grade A-C or a level 2 NVQ.

course.dc:title: Principles of Leadership and Management ILM Certificate Level 3
course.learningOutcome:
This qualification will provide progression opportunities to a range of management subjects such as:

  • L3 Certificate in Leadership
  • L3 Certificate in Effective Management
  • L3 Certificates in Coaching and/or Mentoring
  • L4 Award in Leadership & Management
course.mlo:objective:
The course is held over 8 days and the workshops will involve group discussions, exercises, case studies and project work.

The programme will look to develop a full range of management skills including:

  • Day 1 - Introduction to leadership
  • Day 2 - Solving problems and making decisions
  • Day 3 - Leading a Team Effectively
  • Day 4 & 5 - Change Management
  • Day 6 to 8 - Management specialist subjects

Assessment is by completion of Reflective Reviews and project based assignments. Successful completion will lead to a nationally recognised Level 3 management qualification.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements, but participants will normally be either practising or aspiring first line managers on a  Senior Apprenticeship/Development programme.

Institution Code: DUCHY D55

 

The new FdSc Estate and Farm Enterprise Management Foundation degree will provide a challenging and exciting career for anyone interested in the broad range of enterprises associated with the land. The course comprises of the related enterprises which identify Farm estates. It encompasses farming enterprises and countryside management but also reviews Forestry, Game and Fisheries management as key enterprises. Knowledge of these aspects of the rural sector is enhanced with industry visits and work placement.
course.dc:subject: Countryside, Conservation & Gamekeeping
course.dc:title: FdSc Estate and Farm Enterprise Management
course.abstract: FdSc Estate and Farm Enterprise Management
course.mlo:assessment: A range of assessment techniques are utilised to ensure that individual learner's strengths are enhanced in addition to employability skills development.
course.learningOutcome: Duchy College has strong links with the Game and Wildlife Conservation Trust, British Association of Shooting and Conservation (BASC), National Gamekeepers Organisation (NGO), National Trust, RSPCA, Westcountry Rivers Trust, Linking Environment and Farming (LEAF) and the Royal Society for Protection of Birds (RSPB). We regularly work with Cornwall and Devon Wildlife Trust and Duchy Woodlands. This programme will provide students the opportunity to develop high level skills and training that the industry demands today and in the future.
course.mlo:objective:
The course covers whole farm reviews, building design and conversion, Land lord tenant issues, planning and development, integrated estate planning, the use of renewables, and access to the countryside. The Farm, equine stables, shooting estate and food technology resources are all used to gain skills and knowledge of running diverse enterprises. It also requires those with entrepreneurial and innovative skills to overcome the associated issues of food security, environmental management and climate change.

 

The course has the following modules:

Level 4 (Year 1)

Personal and Employability Skills Development (20 Credits)

Research Skills (10 Credits)

Soil - Plant - Animal Interactions (10 Credits)

Game and Fishery Management (20 Credits)

Agricultural Production Systems (20 Credits)

Woodland Management (20 Credits)

Understanding the Farm Business (20 Credits)


Level 5 (Year 2)

Research Project (20 Credits)

Rural Enterprise Diversification (20 Credits)

Habitat and Species Management (20 Credits)

Estate  Management (20 Credits)

Estate  and Farm Enterprise Management in Practice (40 Credits)

The course also includes the practicalities of rearing stock, crops, game birds, deer production, and the control; of pests and vermin. The course also reviews the estate and its role as a service industry, encompassing customer care and human resource management.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - PPP Grades required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3. Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language and mathematics: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

If you are unsure of your suitability please call us on 0845 60 50 455 or emailenquiries@duchy.ac.uk.

course.dc:description:
Ideal if: you are interested in working in countryside conservation, wildlife management, forestry, estates or river management.

You'll need: four GCSEs at grade D or above including English and mathematics, or equivalent qualifications, and a keen interest in the countryside.

You'll learn: conservation and wildlife habitat management at college and gain a variety of experience and skills including practical work on local sites and woodlands. You'll also learn valuable theory in subjects such as habitat management, estate maintenance, and livestock conservation management.

Expect: to undertake a work placementwithin the rural sector to build confidence, become adaptable in the work place and develop transferable skills.

You'll love: regularly conducting conservation work with Cornwall Wildlife Trust and Duchy Woodlands as well as our strong links with Cornwall County Council, The National Trust and RSPB.

You'll go onto: further study such as the BTEC Extended Diploma in Countryside Management. There are future job opportunities as Ranger, Woodland Manager, or Conservation Officer.

course.dc:description:
The purpose of this level 1 qualification in practical horticultural skills is to provide learners, industry and other stakeholders with the fundamental skills required in horticulture. It is a flexible system with a wide range of units in discrete horticultural skills, that can be built up into a full qualification or accessed as individual units, and, as such, it meets the needs of learners from a wide range of abilities and backgrounds.
The units cover a wide range of horticultural tasks and give great flexibility to the qualification. It is particularly suitable for entrants into all sectors of horticulture, including those who need to work up from lower levels and is suitable for anyone who requires training in fundamental practical horticulture skills. It has proved to be useful for entry into horticulture, leading on to higher qualifications.

You'll love: learning the skills necessary to gain the Construction Plant Competence Certificate (CPCS) operator's card

You'll go onto: employment, or an apprenticeship such as our level 3 Construction Plant Operations

Test Pieces

Beads on a Plate in the Flat Position

Lap weld in Horizontal Vertical Position

Tee Fillet in the Flat Position

Tee Fillet in the Horizontal Vertical Position

Corner Weld in the Flat Position

course.dc:description:
The course will cost £900 which will include access to:-

The student site of the College of Policing ‘Pre Join Domain,’ – which includes the following resources for up to 3 years.

All Pre-join related e-learning (approximately 30 short courses)
Fully maintained electronic version of the IPLDP QuickNotes
Fully maintained versions of Student Notes for all modules of the Pre-Join Curriculum
Fully maintained audio versions (in MP3 format) of Student Notes for all modules of the Pre-Join Curriculum.

Achievement of the Certificate in Knowledge in Policing (CKP) will help prepare those seeking recruitment to the Police Service as a Police Constable in England or Wales. The qualification is also relevant to other related roles within the Criminal Justice Sector.

The certificate is an important element of the Professional Entry into Policing Pre-Join Strategy, and accredits the knowledge and understanding which also forms part of the Diploma in Policing qualification. The Diploma in Policing is the minimum mandatory qualification which Regular Police Constables are required to achieve to be confirmed in rank and forms part of the Initial Police Learning and Development Programme (IPLDP). All those who achieve the Certificate in Knowledge of Policing through a provider approved by the College of Policing will be able to submit this as evidence of the knowledge component of the Diploma. All awarding organisations offering the Diploma in Policing recognise and accept the relationship between the CKP and Diploma in Policing.

Successful achievement of the Certificate in Knowledge of Policing does not in itself provide any guarantee of recruitment as a trainee Police Constable. Each police force within England and Wales sets out its own recruitment process and selection policy and entry requirements vary from force to force. Prospective students are therefore strongly advised to check the specific requirements of their chosen force prior to undertaking study.

It should be noted that all candidates need to pass medical and fitness tests as well as background and security checks and undertake a series of assessments, tests and an interview at a Police SEARCH® assessment centre.

The CKP will be delivered through a number of guided learning sessions and some directed study.  The students will be expected to study in their own time between sessions in order to successfully complete the course.
course.dc:subject: Police; Policing; Knowledge Certificate in Policing; Police pre-join certificate, specials, law enforcing, constable
Public Services
course.dc:title: Certificate in Knowledge of Policing City & Guilds (3945-30/93) Certificate Level 3
course.abstract: Certificate in Knowledge of Policing
course.learningOutcome:
There are no guarantees of employment following completion of this course. Although you may still be eligible to join the police service if you have minor convictions/cautions, there are certain offences and conditions that will make you ineligible. If you are at all unsure, contact your chosen force for more information.

The Certificate will remain valid for a period of 4 years for those who have continuing operational experience in policing (operational Special Constables and PCSOs).

For students undertaking a Foundation Degree in Policing and those who undertake the Certificate in Knowledge of Policing as a stand-alone course the currency of the certificate will be three years from completion of the Foundation degree or the stand-alone course.
course.mlo:objective: The Certificate in Knowledge of Policing course is one of a range of qualifications which can be accepted as evidence of Recognised (Accredited) Prior Learning (RPL) towards the Diploma in Policing but only represents circa 50% of the Diploma. It comprises some elements of the Initial Police Learning and Development Programme (IPLDP), which is the required learning programme undertaken by all trainee Regular Police Constables to the Police Service of England and Wales. The course is delivered through 10 individual units on a part-time basis, part of the course is taught, and the remainder of study is carried out on a self-study basis.  Assessment will be through a series of in-class tests.
course.mlo:prerequisite: Candidates should be a minimum of 19 years of age and capable of undertaking a Level 3 programme of study.

course.dc:description:
Bursaries are available, for more information please contact Admissions on 01579 372233 or email uni@duchy.ac.uk

Due to the practical nature of these modules some learning and training is conducted outdoors and will require wet weather clothing and boots.

There will be opportunities to engage in voluntary field trips during your course.  Previous field trips and training have taken place at the following venues:

  • A multi-agency exercise with several emergency services
  • Fire & Rescue training at RAF Portreath
  • Naval fire fighting training at RNAS Culdrose
  • Urban Search & Rescue training with Devon & Somerset Fire & Rescue Service
  • Search and rescue and navigation training on Dartmoor
  • Rope rescue training on Dartmoor

 

New For 2014-15, planning is currently being undertaken for a proposed field trip to New York to study the 2011 attack on the World Trade Centre.

UCAS Code: N290
Institution Code: DUCHY D55

This unique practical Foundation Degree programme has been designed for anyone wishing to develop specialised skills and knowledge prior to entry into the emergency services, emergency management or civil contingency sectors. The course has evolved in response to the Civil Contingencies Act 2004 and focuses on 'bronze' operational and 'silver' tactical management functions. It is designed to develop aspirant team leaders who understand this complex area of practice and can lead improvements in an organisations service delivery and inter-agency working at all levels.

The curriculum has been developed in conjunction with local emergency services and responder organisations. This will enhance knowledge, skills and understanding of key topics and improve working practices.

Modules

 

Year 1

 

  • Search Management (20 credits)
  • Personal & Employability Skills Development (20 credits)
  • Community Preparedness (20 credits)
  • Environmental Protection (10 credits)
  • Patient Assessment (20 credits)
  • Operational Fire fighting (20 credits)
  • Research Skills (10 credits)

 

Year 2

 

  • Technical Rescue (20 credits)
  • Research Project (20 credits)
  • Resource Management (20 credits)
  • Managing Incidents & Emergency Situations (20 credits)
  • Emergency Planning & Contingency Management (20 credits)
  • Patient Management from Hostile Environments (20 credits)
course.dc:subject: FdSc, public services, emergency services, paramedic, medic, disaster relief, safety and rescue, firefighter, coastguard, fire fighting, rescue,
Public Services
course.dc:title: FdSc Rescue and Emergency Management
course.abstract: FdSc Rescue and Emergency Management
course.learningOutcome:
The theory and practical training you gain from this foundation degree gives you the opportunity to progress in Higher Education or pursue a range of careers.

For example:

  • Firefighter
  • Paramedic (via BSc Paramedic Science)
  • Coastguard
  • Armed forces
  • Rope access emergency teams
  • British Red Cross emergency team
  • Humanitarian relief agencies
  • Local Authority, civil contingencies or emergency planning in the UK and overseas
  • Other response organisations

 Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression. Call 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm) or email careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
The programme is delivered through the use of lectures and seminars and includes work-based and work-related learning and training including practical exercises which are delivered and assessed by emergency services personnel. 

The strength of this programme lies in the experienced staff who deliver it. The course manager has 30 years experience as a Devon & Cornwall police officer who specialised in search and rescue and emergency management and who is the current chairperson for the Cornwall Search & Rescue Team. Other specialist tutors include a former senior Devon and Somerset firefighter qualified to deliver Swift Water Rescue and Rope Rescue. In addition, students' will benefit from the experience of a serving South West Ambulance Trust Paramedic from the Hazardous Response Team and a former naval medic and helicopter winchman. The real-life knowledge and expertise of these tutors will give an informed view of the reality of day-to-day emergency work. Assessment will consist of formal written essays and reports, practical tests and presentations. In addition, there are two in-class tests.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level) or relevant Level 3 qualification (ie BTEC National Diploma/Extended Diploma - PPP grades) or Access to HE Diploma (45 credits at Level 3).  GCSEs at grade C or above in English Language and Mathematics also required, alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

If you are unsure of your suitability please call us on 0845 60 50 455 or email enquiries@duchy.ac.uk.

This unique practical, higher education Foundation Degree programme has been designed for anyone wishing to develop the specialised skills and knowledge which would enable them to prepare for entry and future careers in the Police Service, Military Police, the Criminal Justice System or private / commercial security services. The programme provides students with academic understanding and practical experience of the nature of policing together with in-depth analysis of the conflicts of a modern day society. Graduating students are offered guaranteed entry to the University of Plymouth one year 'top-up' BSc (Hons) Public Services, BSc (Hons) Public Services (Policing) or the BSc (Hons) Police and the Criminal Justice System.

The Certificate in Knowledge of Policing is delivered alongside the delivery of the FdSc Police Studies.

Achievement of the Certificate in Knowledge in Policing (CKP) will help prepare those seeking recruitment to the Police Service as a Police Constable in England or Wales.  The qualification is also relevant to other related roles within the Criminal Justice Sector. The certificate is an important element of the Professional Entry into Policing Pre-Join Strategy, and accredits the knowledge and understanding which also forms part of the Diploma in Policing qualification. The Diploma in Policing is the minimum mandatory qualification which Regular Police Constables are required to achieve to be confirmed in rank and forms part of the Initial Police Learning and Development Programme (IPLDP). All those who achieve the Certificate in Knowledge of Policing through a provider approved by the College of Policing will be able to submit this as evidence of the knowledge component of the Diploma. All awarding organisations offering the Diploma in Policing recognise and accept the relationship between the CKP and Diploma in Policing. Successful achievement of the Certificate in Knowledge of Policing does not in itself provide any guarantee of recruitment as a trainee Police Constable. Each police force within England and Wales sets out its own recruitment process and selection policy and entry requirements vary from force to force. Prospective students are therefore strongly advised to check the specific requirements of their chosen force prior to undertaking study. It should be noted that all candidates need to pass medical and fitness tests as well as background and security checks and undertake a series of assessments, tests and an interview at a Police SEARCH® assessment centre.

• The course contains 7 modules in each year
  • Part time students study the same modules over a 3 year period
  • Each year has 3 blocks of 10 weeks of delivery (not counting holidays)
  • An average of 4 assignments per 10 weeks

Public Services
course.dc:title: FdSc Police Studies
course.abstract: FdSc Police Studies
course.learningOutcome:
You can join the civil police service, the military police, or the wider criminal justice community that includes the security industry.
 
The programme aims to give you a wide range of academic, personal and transferable skills which enable you to be effective in various areas of employment. Many of the skills gained are particularly useful for careers in the police service, military police, criminal justices system or private and commercial security services.

Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression.

Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm)

Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
The programme consists of a mixture of theory and practical work based and work related modules. These include Introduction to Criminology; Civil Liberties, Human Rights and the Law; Race, Racism and Cultural Diversity; and Crime Scene Management & Forensic Evidence. Students will also undertake the Police Policy & Society module which incorporates the Certificate in Knowledge of Policing, a vocational qualification validated by the College of Policing.

You will be offered the opportunity to further develop your fitness levels through participation in various sporting activities. In addition, opportunities exist for you to engage in community based work programmes through joining the Special Constabulary, the Police Volunteer Programme or other community volunteer work.

You will study a combination of modules over two years full-time (there is also an option to study part-time for three years).

This foundation degree is delivered by police professionals together with qualified college lecturers who have relevant vocational and academic experience.

Some modules have timetabled practical sessions. These specialist sessions will be invaluable to you and such practical work can be a major factor in your learning, and in your approach to it.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level) or relevant level 3 qualification, ie BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - PPP Grades required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3.  Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language and mathematics: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

If you are unsure of your suitability please call us on 0845 60 50 455 or email enquiries@duchy.ac.uk.

course.dc:description:
Students will be required to purchase the following items of personal uniform from the suggested supplier or from a supplier of their choice to wear on the course. 

 Cadet Uniform package cost £40 inc VAT consisting of: Assault boots, Soldier 95 trousers, shirt and Ripstop jacket, 2 piece cameo wet weather suit and commando socks. Available from:http://www.britishmilitarysurplus.co.uk/ishop/1069/shopscr43.html

 In addition, a tracksuit and T shirt embroidered with the College Military Academy logo is required and can be purchased from: http://www.plymouthmilitarygifts.com/store/Duchy_College.html Embroidered Track Suit £32.99, embroidered T shirts £4.50.

 Large or expensive items of kit such as Bergens, cooking equipment, tents, sleeping bags etc will be provided by the College.  Students are encouraged to purchase/bring their own sleeping bags etc if they prefer. A refundable deposit of £35 is required for the issue of College kit and equipment.

 There is an additional cost of £55 for the 3 day survival school training course which is delivered by an outside provider and £20 for issue of rations for overnight exerccises.

 

Financial support may be available from the student support fund, details are available from Student Services.

The NCFE Level 2 Diploma for Entry to the Uniformed Services is part of the Cornwall College Military Academy and is designed to prepare potential recruits for entry to the Armed Forces.  The course is 16 weeks and runs from January. The programme is portfolio based therefore there are no examinations. All theory and practical assessment will be conducted in the class room or out-doors as suitable. Learners will undertake practical military training and education in order to equip them with the necessary skills to enable them to make decisions on which service to apply for and to prepare them in all respects for initial selection. Alongside the main qualification learners will undertake GCSE or functional skills in English and/or maths dependant on their entry qualifications.
course.dc:subject: Public Services
course.dc:title: Entry to the Uniformed Services NCFE Diploma Level 2
course.abstract: This intensive 16 week course will prepare you for entry to the Armed Forces. Courses run September-January and February-June.
course.mlo:assessment:
There are no examinations in this course, assessment is through a portfolio based system. Students are issued with a complete portfolio of their programme which gives full information of the learning outcomes for each individual unit of study. After each practical activity or lesson students write up reflective logs to record what they have learnt and answer specific questions associated with the learning outcomes for that unit. To pass the course a student must provide evidence in their portfolio that they have completed 100% of the learning outcomes and assessment for each unit. Units are graded pass, merit or distinction and students receive an overall grade for completing their course.

The main evidencefor the portfolio may include:

  • candidates proof of work
  • Assessor observation
  • witness testimony
  • worksheets
  • assignments, projects or reports
  • records of professional discussion
  • record of oral and written questioning
  • candidate and peer reports
  • recognition of prior learning (RPL)
course.learningOutcome:
On successful completion of your course you can apply for selection to the Armed Service of your choice. 

Or you can progress to :

  • Entry to the Uniformed Services NCFE Diploma (Military Academy) Level 3
  • Public Services (Uniformed) BTEC Extended Diploma Level 3 (5 x GCSE grade C including English and/or maths are required for this course).
course.mlo:objective:
The aim of this course is to prepare you for Armed Forces selection. You will study a number of units which will improve your overall fitness and stamina levels and equip you with the knowledge and skills to allow you to perform to the best of your ability at the Armed Forces selection centre. 

Units include:

  • Investigate employment in the uniformed services
  • Physical fitness for the uniformed services
  • Develop team working and problem-solving skills
  • Health and safety in the uniformed services
  • Health and hygiene in the uniformed services
  • Carry out map reading and navigation
  • Follow uniformed services routine
  • Exploring equality and diversity for the uniformed services
  • Participate in competitive sports
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal academic entry requirements for this course. However, learners will be expected to be able to work towards GCSE or functional skills in English and/or maths dependant on individual entry qualifications.

This outstanding programme is designed to make learners employable at the end of the course and ready for a career in the outdoor industry.
It is designed for those learners wanting to gain valuable practical experience in instructor training alongside gaining the relevant industry National Governing Body awards to improve personal skills and practical ability in a variety of outdoor and adventurous activites.
course.dc:subject: outdoor instructor kayak canoe climbing pursuits sport
Outdoor Pursuits & Adventurous Activity
course.dc:title: Outdoor Instructor Training Programme
course.abstract: Designed for those wanting to gain practical experience in instructor training
course.learningOutcome:
• Progress onto the Advanced Instructor Training Programme Level 3
  • Gain employment in the outdoor industry
course.mlo:objective:
• The college week consists of 1 day theory work and 2-3 full days of practical activity covering land and water-based instructor training throughout the course. Attendance for these days, whatever the weather, is compulsory to be successful to gain a well-rounded understanding of the role of an instructor in a work setting; you will be continuously assessed and gather evidence for your final portfolio.
  • Develop leadership skills to safely lead safe, effective and enjoyable land and water-based sessions for school groups. 
  • Undertake a summer season placement at an outdoor centre.
  • You will have opportunity to gain a range of outdoor / leadership qualifications, e.g. Paddlesports 1* & 2*, BCU Level 1 Coach, CWA training, Mountain Bike Leaders, and First Aid for the Outdoors.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
There are no formal entry requirements However, all learners will demonstrate an outstanding work ethic and motivation throughout the course to progress to the work placement after Easter of the course. 

All learners are required to be water confident and able to swim 50 meters in open water.
Relevant Senior Tutor and employer DBS checks will be undertaken to ensure that all learners are suitable to be working with young children and vulnerable adults; two successful character references will also be required.

Finally, in order to successfully undertake the outdoor provider work placement you will be required to be 18 years old by the end of the course.

course.dc:description:
Are you ready to take your game to the next level? Be careful how you respond because we'll hold you to it. Training and learning to compete as a tournament golf professional is no mean feat. It requires drive, determination, application and most of all effort and commitment from you. Here at Tournament Golf College (TGC) we will prepare you mentally, physically, tactically, technically, personally and academically for the challenges that lie ahead.

At TGC our philosophy is to enjoy the journey, to not just work hard, but work smart and become a disciplined, solution-based thinker: a key attribute for all top players. Learn how we break the game of golf down into performance segments, and work on solutions in many areas to make many small improvements. Learn more about what affects performance so you can take that all important responsibility for your own game. With your efforts, discipline and open mind we are a very powerful tool to help you achieve and maximise your potential.

The programme prides itself on its relationships with industry and as such the opportunities for academic study and game play are extensive. The fantastic facilities provide a golfing environment second to none. For instance, over the past two years students have been enrolled onto the Algrave Professional Golf Tour and have competed with professionals. A number of our students have undertaken work placements at the prestigious Saadiyat Golf Resort, Dubai.
course.dc:subject: Sport
course.dc:title: BSc (Hons) Tournament Golf
course.abstract: Are you ready to take your game to the next level?
course.learningOutcome:
You can progress onto Postgraduate study at Master Level.

Possible careers include Tournament Professional, Corporate Hospitality, Sports Management and Event Organiser.
course.mlo:objective: The BSc (Hons) Tournament Golf is a three year programme of study with winter training in Portugual during the second semester of each year. The taught programme runs from Septembher until the end of March, finishing in time for the start of the golf season. You can expect to work at weekends, some evenings and have independent study during the playing season. The first semester is in the UK at St Mellion International Resort and thre second in Portugsal at Oceanico Golf.
course.mlo:prerequisite: 200 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels or relevant Level 3 qualifications. Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language and maths. Applicants must also have a handicap of five or less.

course.dc:description: Bursaries available, please contact Student Services for further details.

UCAS Code: F710
Institution Code: CORN C78

If you want to study marine science in one of the most beautiful coastal regions and pursue a career in the marine industry then this is the course for you. You will study a series of modules to gain the essential knowledge and skills to work in the marine science sector. Our location gives us access to a superb 'outdoor classroom' and we are within half an hour of a range of coastlines of all types from pounding surf beaches to sheltered sandy bays. You will be able to study these areas and learn all about the influences and habitats that create them. You will also have the opportunity to undertake research projects and gain many practical outdoor survey skills.

Students are encouraged to develop a strong team ethic through a variety of activities, whilst being introduced to a range of employers and industry contacts.

Modules

Year 1

  • Introduction to Marine Science (10 credits)
  • Coastal & Ocean Processes (20 credits)
  • Benthic Biology A (20 credits)
  • Marine Resource Management (10 credits)
  • Pelagic Biology A  (20 credits)
  • Personal & Employability Skills Development (20 credits)
  • Practical Skills & Research Development (20 credits)

Year 2

  • Oceanography & Meteorology (20 credits)
  • Benthic Biology B (20 credits)
  • Pelagic Biology B (20 credits)
  • Biology & Culture of Aquatic Species (20 credits)
  • Marine Spatial Planning (20 credits)
  • Project (20 credits)
course.dc:subject: FdSc, Marine biology, marine, oceanography,fish, dolphins, turtles, whales, marine animal, animal behaviour, marine zoology, coastal, wave formations, oceanographer, conservation, ranger, dive, ecologist,
Marine Science & Biology
course.dc:title: FdSc Marine Science
course.abstract: If you want to study marine science in one of the most beautiful coastal regions then this is the course for you
course.learningOutcome:
Many of our graduates go on to obtain both honours degrees and higher degrees with some of the most prestigious marine based academic institutions in the world. Former graduates have gone on to establish successful careers ranging from marine conservation, marine environment management, aquaculture, fisheries management, marine based research, marine exploration and development and marine recreation.

Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression.  Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm) Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
Foundation degrees lay emphasis on the concept of work-based learning together with the support required to develop strong academic skills required for progression on to honours degree programmes.

The lectures are supported by a significant level of practical work including laboratory skills, such as water quality assessment, field work, such as boat based cetacean observations, together with the opportunity to obtain industry specific experience or  qualifications including snorkelling, diving, boat handling, aquatic husbandry and population sampling.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level, preferably in a science subject) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - PPP Grades required, specific unit grades may be required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3.  Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language, mathematics and a science: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 0845 22 32 567 or email enquiries@cornwall.ac.uk
