course.dc:description:
Please note: this foundation degree is based at the UKSA centre in Cowes, Isle of Wight and is validated and supported by Falmouth Marine School.

  

Do you want to study a life changing course?  Do you have the passion to work in the Superyacht industry?  Do you already work in the Superyacht industry?  The FdSc in Operational Yacht Science is designed to work to produce professional Superyacht employees who want to have an employment edge amongst their peers and increase their options for their future careers.

 

You will gain the skills you need to work as Deck Crew onboard Superyachts, working towards MCA Officer of the Watch 3000,  (OOW
3000), allowing you to work as a Deck Officer on Yachts up to 3000 GRT plus the experience and qualifications that allow you to work towards First Mate and Captain level.  We work in partnership with the UKSA Cadetship course, and have a 90% employment record.  If you are able to work hard, enjoy the yachting industry and are happy to spend long times abroad, then this course is worth the enquiry.

 

NB.  As this course is specialist and involves a lot of time on yachts achieving RYA and MCA qualifications, there are additional fees.  Bursaries and sponsorship routes are available for those that enquire.  The additional course fees are available on request.

For more information about UKSA click here http://uksa.org/professional-training/deck/fdsc-foundation-degree-in-operational-yacht-science/

Modules

Year 1

  • Yacht Theory and Practice (20 credits)
  • Yacht Operations (20 credits)
  • Navigation and Meteorology (20 credits)
  • Reflective Practice (20 credits)
  • Marine  Engineering (20 credits)
  • Personal & Employability Skills Development (20 credits)

Year 2

  • Small Ships Business (20 credits)
  • Ocean Passage Planning and Global Weather Systems (20 credits)
  • Yacht  Construction and Design (20 credits)
  • Leadership and Management at Sea (20 credits)
  • Research Project (30 credits)
course.dc:subject: Operational Yacht Science. Watersports, sailing
Falmouth Marine School
course.dc:title: FdSc Operational Yacht Science
course.abstract: Do you want to study a life changing course?
course.learningOutcome:
On completion of this course you will be experienced in all areas of yachting and will be able to start a career in areas such as:

    • Yacht Crew
    • Bosun
    • Mate
    • Captain
course.mlo:objective:
This programme has been designed in order for you to gain the qualifications and experience that you will need for a career in the Superyacht industry.  You will be spending much of your time in yachts, working 6 or 7 days a week plus evenings, learning the theory and practicing yacht science.  The modules are designed and flow so that you pick up the basics early in the course, to allow progression to the second year.  Some of the modules are embedded into the RYA and MCA qualifications that you will be studying to gain even more qualifications that the Superyacht industry recognise e.g. RYA Yachtmaster and MCA Engineering.

The course is split between 2 intensive learning periods based at the UKSA in Cowes.  After the first learning period (year 1) you will have enough qualifications to be expected, with support, to gain a work placement in the Superyacht industry.  After your work placement you return to the UKSA to finish the second year of your course and add more industry relevant qualifications to your portfolio.

Whilst at the UKSA in Cowes you will be part of a large yachting community, with the benefit of intimate class sizes to ensure an encouraging a productive, driven and learning atmosphere.

You will be assessed mainly though coursework and assignments. The assignments will be industry based and the work you carry out will be largely be scenarios and reflection on performance. You will also have to sit in class tests, participate in group work and presentations, and also write reports based on your practical work.

If you already have relevant industry qualifications (a list available on request), or are doing them privately, you can access the modules privately, organised through Falmouth Marine School, delivered at the UKSA in Cowes.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - PPP Grades required, specific unit grades may be required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3. Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language and mathematics: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 0845 22 32 567 or email enquiries@cornwall.ac.uk

course.learningOutcome: Successful completion of this course will widen your future career prospects and employment opportunities. You will now be able to provide safety cover to a range of craft.
course.mlo:objective: This RYA qualification offers study and practical training in boat handling, towing, fleet management, rescue techniques for sailing dinghies, windsurfers and canoes.

course.dc:description:
Regarded by many as the 'driving licence' for powerboats, our RYA Powerboat Level 2 course offers a thorough introduction to powerboat handling.

Topics covered include:

  • Launching and recovery
  • Confined space manoeuvring
  • Mooring
  • Man over board procedure
  • Anchoring
  • Towing
  • Engine checks
  • High speed handling
  • Collision regulations
  • Buoyage
  • Basic chartwork and navigation
  • Tides
  • Communication afloat
  • Emergency procedures

Your level 2 certificate can also be exchanged for the International Certificate of Competence (ICC) for vessels up to 10 m / 33ft. We also offer the CEVNI (European inland waterways theory) test FREE of charge to anyone taking a practical course with us. The ICC is only available to people aged 16 years+ who are either British Residents or British Passport holders.
course.dc:subject: powerboat, power boats, RYA, watersports, outdoor pursuits, outdoors sports, water sports, watersports, sailing, boat, boats, boating, instructor, coaching,
course.dc:title: National Powerboat RYA Certificate Level 2
course.mlo:objective:
RYA Powerboat Level 2

This two-day course provides the skills and background knowledge needed to drive a powerboat and is the basis of the International Certificate of Competence.

It includes close quarters handling, high speed manoeuvres, man overboard recovery and collision regulations. The course can be taken inland or on the coast and your certificate will be endorsed accordingly.
course.mlo:prerequisite: None (it is not necessary to have completed the level 1 course)

CE:cost.dc:description: Please call our Enquiries Team for more details on this course.

course.dc:description:
Start windsurfing instructor training 

RYA Start Windsurfing instructors are qualified to teach the Start Windsurfing course and Stages 1 and 2 of the Youth Windsurfing Scheme under the supervision of a senior instructor. In addition the instructor certificate is endorsed to show whether you are qualified to teach on inland or coastal waters. The instructor is a competent, experienced windsurfer capable of windsurfing in strong winds and handling small powerboats. The instructor has been assessed as competent to teach adults and children at the beginner level. Although responsible for teaching individuals and small groups, the instructor has not been assessed as competent in running a sailing centre, and should always work under the supervision of an RYA Senior instructor (for dinghy and multihull courses) or the chief instructor of a keelboat training centre.

course.mlo:objective:
This course runs over a 5 day period with the final day being the moderation and assessment of candidates (this aspect is run by an external examiner). 

 Expect the course to run into the evenings on Tuesday and Wednesday.

The course will begin at 9.00am each day.

course.learningOutcome: When qualified as an instructor you will be eligible to work for outdoor centres both in the UK and worldwide. You will be qualified to teach beginners in all aspects of the sport.
course.mlo:objective:
Dinghy, keelboat & multihull instructor training 

Instructors teaching the National Sailing Scheme need to be qualified for the type of boat in which they teach, ie dinghies, small keelboats or multihulls. In addition the instructor certificate is endorsed to show whether you are qualified to teach on inland or coastal waters. The instructor is a competent, experienced sailor capable of sailing a training boat in strong winds and handling small powerboats. The instructor has been assessed as competent to teach adults and children, beginners and improvers. Although responsible for teaching individuals and small groups, the instructor has not been assessed as competent in running a sailing centre, and should always work under the supervision of an RYA Senior instructor (for dinghy and multihull courses) or the chief instructor of a keelboat training centre.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
Minimum age 16, valid first aid qualification. Acceptable certificates include the RYA’s First Aid Certificate, First Aid at Work, First Aid at Sea, or any other certificate issued on completion of a course which is a minimum of one day’s duration, recognised by the Health and Safety Executive and includes the treatment of hypothermia, cold shock and drowning. 

You must also be a member of the national governing body (Royal Yachting Association for windsurfing/dinghy sailing and the British Canoe Union for Paddlesport).

RYA Powerboat Level 2

RYA intermediate sailing

RYA Day sailing

RYA Pre instructor assessment

course.mlo:objective:
UKCC paddlesport coach Level 1

This is the first step on the paddlesport coaching pathway. It will introduce you to the fundamentals of good coaching practice and help you to understand and coach technical and tactical aspects of your sport. This course is for anyone interested and involved in paddlesport! If you want to encourage others into paddlesport or help existing paddlers to improve their skills then this is the award for you. You could be someone with family members involved in paddlesport, someone wanting a career instructing in the outdoor industry, or an experienced paddler wanting to move into coaching. As the award is either bank-based or boat-based it is accessible for anyone interested in coaching paddlesport. You can assist higher level Coaches, delivering coaching sessions under their supervision, and deliver taster sessions.

You must also be a member of the national governing body (Royal Yachting Association for windsurfing/dinghy sailing and the British Canoe Union for Paddlesport).

course.learningOutcome:
Options for progression are to a further course at Level 1 in a specific vocational area, a course at Level 2, an apprenticeship or other employment with training.

 

 

During the year, you will be encouraged to discuss your personal aims and aspirations with a Careers South West adviser and with your personal tutor.
course.mlo:objective:
This is a Foundation Learning programme which combines vocational learning with functional skills in English, Maths and ICT and personal and social development.  You can choose options within a single vocational area or sample from a range of options that could include agriculture, horticulture, conservation, animal care, horse care, sport, early years or public services depending on the campus. You will also work towards a C&G Certificate in Employability and Personal Development to develop the skills and qualities that employers look for.

During the year you will take part in many enrichment activities designed to improve confidence, team working skills and communication skills.  There are opportunities to take part in volunteering in the community, sport and outdoor education, fund raising activities, team building and problem solving.  You will also work on independent living skills such as cooking and personal finance.

course.dc:description: This course is awarded by Plymouth University.

There has never been a more pressing need to study this subject. The oceans cover 70% of the Earth, they are the largest habitat for life, supply over 50% of the oxygen we breath and are the only source of protein for one in six people on the planet. And they are under increasing pressure: overfishing, pollution, invasive species, climate change, offshore development, ocean noise, marine debris … the list can seem overwhelming. We need a generation of knowledgeable passionate people who can work to protect this amazing environment. Marine Conservation is about exploring the wonders of our oceans and developing workable strategies for their conservation.

During the course you will gain an understanding of the science underlying conservation efforts in an exciting and vocationally relevant learning environment. This course has been designed in close consultation with the marine industry, to deliver the practical skills and knowledge that is highly relevant for a career in this expanding field

Have a look at our facebook  page here: FdSc Marine Conservation

Modules

Year 1 

  • Personal & Employability Skills Development (20 credits)
  • Marine Science (20 credits)
  • Ecology of Aquatic Systems (20 credits)
  • Biological Principles (20 credits)
  • Diversity, Classification & Evolution (20 credits)
  • Marine Survey Techniques (20 credits)

 Year 2

 Core

  • Marine Vertebrate Biology & Conservation (20 credits)
  • Algal & Coral Biology & Culture (10 credits)
  • Fish Ecology (20 credits)
  • Marine Invertebrates (20 credits)
  • Marine Conservation in Practice (20 credits)
  • Individual Research Project (20 credits)

 Optional modules (choose one)

  • Aquaria & Conservation of Aquatic Organisms (10 credits)
  • Contemporary Issues in Marine Conservation (10 credits)
course.dc:subject: FdSc, marine, conservation, coastal, diving, fishing, surfing, aquarium, marine environment, marine organisms, science, marine consultancy, ecology,
Conservation, Zoology and Animal Behaviour
course.dc:title: FdSc Marine Conservation
course.abstract: FdSc Marine Conservation
course.learningOutcome:
The unique combination of academic and practical skills gained during a Foundation Degree in Marine Conservation enables you to become well qualified for employment in a range of marine conservation sectors. Other opportunities include working as an education officer, an employee of the Environment Agency, or within other industries related to the marine environment. You can also gain many useful contacts with potential employers, both nationally and internationally, during your studies. Marine Biology is a highly competitive field: you must be prepared to work hard and make the most of work related learning opportunities. However the marine environment has come to the forefront of the agenda for the European community so the demand for academically qualified and practically experienced people has never been higher.

Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression. 

 

Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm)

Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
Studying this course will provide you with a firm scientific background and enable you to learn the practical skills required to understand the marine environment and to minimise the harmful effects of human activities.

First year modules include Ecology of Aquatic Systems; Marine Science; Marine Survey Techniques; Diversity, Classification and Evolution; Personal and Employability Skills Development; and Cellular, Genetics and Reproduction Biology of Aquatic Organisms.

The second year includes Marine Conservation in Practice, which incorporates the requirement to gain 100 hours of work-related experience; Fish Ecology; Marine Vertebrate Biology and Conservation; Marine Invertebrates; Algal and Coral Biology and Culture; the choice of either Aquaria and Conservation of Aquatic Organisms or Contempory Issues in Marine Conservation.

Finally, there is the Individual Research Project. All academic modules are taught using lectures, workshops and practical work, both in the field and laboratory. Work-based study is an important part of all foundation degrees and whilst it is up to you to develop this in your field of interest, we have strong links with commercial partners e.g. Blue Reef Aquarium, the National Lobster Hatchery and Cornwall Wildlife Trust.

An important part of the second year will be your individual project which will enable you to carry out first hand research into an area that interests you. A first year optional field trip to the Algarve in Portugal explores human impact on one of the biggest and most beautiful lagoon systems in Europe. There is also the option of a second year field trip to locations like Egypt. These trips are of additional cost and are subject to change.

re taught using lectures, workshops and practical work, both in the field and laboratory. An important part of the second year will be your individual project which will enable you to carry out first-hand research into an area that interests you.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level, preferably in a science subject) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - PPP Grades required, specific unit grades may be required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3.  Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language, mathematics and a science: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 0845 22 32 567 or email enquiries@cornwall.ac.uk

presentation.dc:description: Students are based at the Newquay campus and the course delivery takes full advantage of this spectacular location in the heart of North Cornwall. Much of the practical work will be carried out on local beaches. Whilst most teaching takes place in our sustainable building on campus, some lectures will be delivered at our marine classroom overlooking Tolcarne Beach. This is a full-time course with delivery spread over four days each week with occasional weekend workshops. Throughout the course, you will have the opportunity to gain first-hand experience working in the nearby Blue Reef Aquarium and the National Lobster Hatchery, gaining valuable practical experience which will help you in any future employment. As well as traditional lectures, fieldwork and laboratory work, there is also the opportunity to take part in workshops delivered by experts from organisations such as the Cornwall Wildlife Trust, Surfers Against Sewage, the Marine Biological Association and the Environment Agency. The field trip to Portugal is an excellent additional part of the Marine Conservation degree allowing students to experience a diverse range of ecosystems.

UCAS Code: CF68
Institution Code: CORN C78

This course is for students who want a thorough grounding in areas of Science, Technology and Social Sciences relating to the sport of surfing.

This is a 2-year full-time course. You will be taught through a series of lectures, tutorials, flexible learning and workshop sessions spread over 4 days. There will also be some fieldwork, although not every week. Friday is normally a free day, ie no lectures. You will be assessed mainly by coursework assignments such as written reports, oral presentations and poster displays. There will also be written tests and some end of module examinations. The course is taught mainly in small groups of about 15 in quite an informal but supportive atmosphere.

Science
Sport
course.dc:title: FdSc Surf Science and Technology
course.abstract: FdSc Surf Science and Technology
course.learningOutcome:
The surf science and technology specialism provides the opportunity to move into a variety of careers in surf or environmentally related industries. This could include top brands like Billabong, charities like Surfers Against Sewage, board building and shaping. You will also be well equipped to start your own surfing related business from selling clothes and equipment to promoting the lifestyle and surfing holidays or go into teaching.

The surf industry is vast and diverse. This foundation degree covers so many aspects of the industry that if you want to make a career out of surfing, this programme will definitely set you up to do so.

Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression.

Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm)

Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
You will study the following: Event Management, Marine Conservation, Surf Culture and History, Design and Production, Business and Law, Psychology, Health & Fitness relating to sport, Media and Marketing, Politics of Sport, Fieldwork, Environmental Dynamics, Surf Practice and Coaching. Work experience is an integral part of the course and students have the opportunity to complete a work placement in a surf related industry. During the course you will have the opportunity to design and build your own surfboard, take a surf coaching award, organise and judge a surfing competition and develop a training and fitness regime. An important part of the second year will be your individual project which will enable you to carry out first hand research into an area that interests you. There will also be a field trip to France and Spain to explore further the culture of surfing and also the human and climatic impacts on the environment.

You will not be taught how to surf and it is important to realise that this is an academic course. As the classrooms are on the beach in the heart of Newquay, you will have plenty of opportunity to surf some of the best surfing beaches in Europe. Most of our students get plenty of time in the water, but the surfing is done in students own time! Some of your lessons will also take place at the Cornwall College Newquay campus where the Learning Resource Centre and laboratories are based.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level, preferably in a science subject) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - PPP Grades required, specific unit grades may be required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3.  Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language, mathematics and a science: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 0845 22 32 567 or email enquiries@cornwall.ac.uk.

A healthy interest in one of the surf disciplines such as surfing, body-boarding, kite-surfing, wave-skiing or knee boarding would be helpful but is not a requirement.  You do not need to be a good surfer.

course.dc:description: This course is awarded by Plymouth University.

Modules

Year 1 

  • History of the British Countryside (10 credits)
  • Habitats & Communities (10 credits)
  • Diversity, Classification & Evolution (20 credits)
  • Ecology of Aquatic Systems (20 credits)
  • Introduction to Ecology (10 credits)
  • Fieldwork (20 credits)
  • Bird Survey Techniques (10 credits)
  • Personal & Employability Skills Development (20 credits)

 Year 2

Core Modules

  •  Genetics for Conservation (10 credits)
  •  Vertebrate Zoology and Conservation (20 credits)
  •  Ecology and Conservation in Practice (20 credits)
  •  Habitat Survey & GIS (20 credits)
  •  Individual Research Project (20 credits)

Optional Modules

  •  Freshwater Ecology (10 credits) or
  •  Reptile & Amphibian Ecology & Survey (10 credits)
  •  Invertebrate Ecology & Survey (20 credits) or

NB. Optional modules are not guaranteed to run.

course.dc:title: FdSc Conservation and Ecology
course.abstract: FdSc Conservation and Ecology
course.mlo:assessment: A variety of teaching methods are used including fieldwork, lectures, laboratory work and workshops. This variety is also reflected in the assessment methods: you will have to complete assignments, practical work and exams. By doing field work such as assessing areas of the Cornish countryside and producing management plans, you will develop and enhance your problem solving skills.
course.learningOutcome:
The ecology course means that you will have a broad knowledge, not just of animals, but the habitats too, so you could work as a guide in the UK or abroad, ecological consultant, ranger... Employment is varied, such as setting up and running the Newquay Orchard Project, Eden Project, ecologist at a consultancy and RSPB ranger. Many current and former students were also SINNG volunteers, and you can see what they've acheived here.

Previous students on the FdSc Conservation and Ecology course have gone on to top up their qualification to a BSc, which can usually be achieved in one year. In addition there are further opportunties to study at Cornwall College for a Master's degree.
course.mlo:objective:
Ecology is the study of relationships of organisms, their environment and with each other. At the end of the course you will be confident and surveying and identifying species and their habitats as well as understanding management and conservation.

 

The Conservation and Ecology course is to help you develop the skills to work in this sector such as surveying for species and habitats, managing sites, research, geographical information systems (GIS) and employability. On the course you gain a solid background in biology through modules such as: Diversity; Vertebrate Zoology and Conservation; and Introduction to Ecology. You'll gain fieldwork, species identification and survey skills through modules including: Surveying and Management of Mammals; Fieldwork; Habitats and Communties; and Reptile and Amphibian Ecology and Survey, and understand management ideas and conflicts through Habitats and GIS, among others. 

 

  

The programme is delivered over three to four days per week. In the first year you will be going out on fieldwork in the interesting Cornish countryside and learning about the processes of change that have shaped Britain geologically and anthropogenically as well as how to use mapping techniques as a practical application. The huge benefit of studying in Cornwall is the diverse nature of the landscape which you will be exploring: the coastline, remains of the mining industry and the strong agricultural history all combine to create a very varied environment in which to learn. Students also work closely with the Student Invasive Non-Native Group to gain experience in practical and id skills, education, IT and media.

 

During the second year there are a number of core modules to give you further skills: a broad knowledge of zoology and genetics; use of geographical information systems; and the opportunity to carry out your own research project in a subject of your choice. As well as these core subjects you have a choice of optional modules, depending on your areas of interest. As part of this course you will undertake a minimum of 100 hours of work experience during your time here which will benefit your studies and future career prospects enormously. 

 

In addition Cornwall College Newquay currently offers all Higher Education students the opportunity of fieldtrips to Borneo and/or Kruger National Park. The cost of these are not included in the course fee but these trips would be invaluable to ecologists with opportunities to: learn survey skills abroad, such as tracking elephants; take part in ongoing monitoring programmes, for example kingfisher territory mapping; and be involved with conservation efforts including tagging rhinos.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level, preferably in a science subject, including geography, geology or environmental studies) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - PPP Grades required, specific unit grades may be required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3.  Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language, mathematics and a science: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 0845 22 32 567 or email enquiries@cornwall.ac.uk

This qualification is available as a full time and a part time course.  This top up degree is ideal if you would like to extend your skills and knowledge in ecology, animal behaviour, science communication and marine and terrestrial conservation.

The part time course is suitable for people in part time work with an HND in a related subject or students graduating from Cornwall College and Duchy College foundation degrees in animal sciences and conservation.

course.dc:title: BSc (Hons) Applied Zoology
course.abstract: This qualification is available as a full time and a part time course
course.learningOutcome:
Upon completion of the course you could continue your studies at the Plymouth University for a year to gain a master's degree in conservation, or you may wish to go straight into employment in a variety of directions such as animal collections, conservation education, animal welfare management, biodiversity protection, environmental monitoring and surveying and other related areas, when combined with the relevant work experience.

BSc students from our course have secured employment as environment officers in several governmental bodies, such as the Environment Agency, Natural England and county councils.

Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression. Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm) Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
This course is designed as a follow on from the varied zoology-based foundation degrees at Cornwall College Newquay. There are a range of module options allowing you to decide the direction in which you wish to extend your applied zoological knowledge, including a full honours project in the second.

There is an option to study the importance of developments in zoological sciences and conservation and their implications in human and global affairs, partly through an international field course. For your Honours, you will be given the opportunity to gain first-hand experience at centres such as Newquay Zoo, the Blue Reef Aquarium in Newquay and at nature reserves and sites of biological interest as well as working with other conservation organisations in the South West.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
A foundation degree (FdSc) in a biological / environmental science or related subject. Applicants with an HND may also apply but a bridging module may need to be completed before being accepted onto the degree.

If in doubt, call 0845 22 32 567 or email enquiries@cornwall.ac.uk.

course.dc:description:
Institution Code: CORN C78
UCAS Code: 0B4X

What is more exciting or enigmatic than the life in our oceans? We still know so little about this alien world which makes up 98% of the living space on our planet but with technology developing at such a pace more and more discoveries are being made. It is an exciting time to be involved in any aspect of marine science, and a one crucial too, as our impact on the world's oceans have never been greater.

 About the course:

This honours degree course is designed to hone your interest and develop your professional skills to equip you for work in a growing industry. Situated on the beautiful coast of North Cornwall we are perfectly situated for fieldwork and we have a strong practical element running through the course. You will get hands on experience in using sampling and survey equipment, as well as planning and undertaking marine surveys; from plankton trawls, to underwater video mapping and offshore marine life surveys.

This Course is also available for year 3 entry to students who have completed a suitable foundation degree in marine studies. Contact the course manager for more details.

This Course is also available as a top-up for FdSc students wishing to progress onto a BSc (Hons).

Modules:

Year 1

  • Marine Science (20 credits)
  • Marine Survey Techniques (20 credits)
  • Biological Principles (20 credits)
  • Diversity, Classification and Evolution (20 credits)
  • Ecology of Aquatic systems (20 credits)

Year2

  • Marine Vertebrate Biology and Conservation (20 credits)
  • Fish Ecology (20 credits)
  • Marine Conservation in Practice (20 credits)
  • Biosecurity & Invasive Species (20 credits)
  • Marine Invertebrates (20 credits)

Choice of:

  • Research Methods and Tropical Surveys (20 credits) (optional)
  • Research Methods in Zoology (20 credits) (optional)

Year 3

  • Research project (40 credits) (core)
  • Monitoring Marine Ecosystems (20 credits) (core)
  • GIS and Marine Environmental Management (20 credits) (core)

Choice of 2 modules to a total of 40 credits from:

  • Marine Pollution and Ecotoxicology (20 credits) (Optional)
  • Conservation Project management (20 credits) (Optional)
  • Application in zoology (20 credits) (Optional)
course.dc:subject: Marine Science & Biology
course.dc:title: BSc (Hons) Applied Marine Zoology
course.abstract: Exciting three year degree studying marine life
course.mlo:assessment: Employers expect graduates to be skilled communicators and you will find that coursework takes a variety of formats from scientific reports and posters, assessed practicals to presentations and discussions. In addition many modules have test or exam elements.
course.learningOutcome:
Successful graduates could go on to have careers in a variety of areas for example: marine conservation, marine research, marine planning and management, science education, fisheries management, marine survey and monitoring, marine expedition and exploration.

Academic progression for graduates obtaining a good degree (2.1 or 1) could continue to postgraduate study (MSc or PhD) at a variety of institutions.
course.mlo:objective:
Course content

During this course we will develop your understanding of marine animals; working from cellular processes up to whole organism and ecosystem levels.  In the first year you will receive a firm grounding in aquatic ecology, marine and biological science as well as developing practical survey skills before moving into more specialised modules such as fish ecology and marine vertebrate biology and conservation, the final year you will be able to choose from options such as GIS and marine management and monitoring or marine pollution and ecotoxicology as well as undertaking you own research for you honours project.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
220 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 180 points must be at A2-level, preferably in a science subject) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - MMM Grades required, specific unit grades may be required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3.  Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language, mathematics and a science: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

For year 3 entry you will need to have acheived at least a 55% grade profile for year 2 of a relevant foundation degree. Please contact enquiries for further details.

The BSc (Hons) Applied Zoology and Conservation is a full-time three year course designed to equip students with the necessary skills and knowledge to work within the field of conservation. Modules cover a range of subjects from anatomy and physiology to behaviour and population/habitat management, with details listed below.

There is an emphasis on practical application using both national and international examples, and utilising field specialists within the institute and externally as guest speakers to discuss current issues and research in zoological conservation.

course.dc:description:
This course is awarded by Plymouth University and thus you have access to their on-line and campus facilities also! The course is taught via three days contact time, usually spread over four days per week, over a total of 31 weeks with an average class size of 20 students.

In classroom-based learning you are assessed through pair and group work, presentations, exams and course work. During practicals, visits and guest speakers you are assessed via participation and questions that you pose.  Although there are different aspects to the assessment process, this programme is assignment focused.

This course is ideal if you would like to study a wide series of modules providing a developed understanding of the evolution and ecology of behaviour, animal training methods, animal behaviour therapy and using animals as therapy.

Modules
 
Year 1 
 
• Introduction to Animal Behaviour (10 credits) 
• Animal Training (10 credits) 
• Personal & Employability Skills Development (20 credits)
• Evolutionary Theories (10 credits) 
• Hygiene, Health & Welfare of Captive Animals (20 credits) 
• Anthrozoology (20 credits) 
• Business Skills for the Animal Care Sector (10 credits) 
• Psychological Principles (20 credits) 
 
Year 2
 
• Behavioural Ecology (20 credits) 
• Education & Interpretation in Public Spaces (20 credits) 
• Animal Behaviour in Practice (20 credits) 
• Animal Behaviour Management & Therapy (20 credits) 
• Applied Psychology (20 credits) 
• Individual Research Project (20 credits) 
 
Modules may be subject to change.
course.dc:subject: Animal Behaviour and Psychology, psychology, animal behaviour, animal training, animal, animals, foundation degree, degree, FdSc, animal courses, conservation, zoo, behavioural ecology, animal management, animal therapy, applied psychology, dogs, cats, primate, monkey, Screech, Paradise Park, Newquay, Cornwall
Conservation, Zoology and Animal Behaviour
course.dc:title: FdSc Animal Behaviour and Psychology
course.abstract: This niche subject is for those who have an interest in animal behaviour and the development of behavioural problems
course.learningOutcome:
In the longer term it is intended that as a graduate you will have developed skills which prepare you for employment in animal training, welfare assessment, animal husbandry and other related fields of work.

The animal behaviour specialism provides the opportunity to move into employment within the animal industry. Our graduates have gone on to work in bird parks, zoos, wildlife trusts, the pet store industry, teaching at further education level, the police force as dog handlers and have taken up honours degree offers at various universities.

Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression. Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm) Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
This programme introduces you to the different ways in which zoologists and psychologists research and interpret animal behaviour.

Through study of the essential science you will learn about techniques used in the management of animal behaviour in a range of contexts and species: companion animals, working dogs, enrichment for captive zoo animals.

There will be a particular emphasis on consideration of the promotion of humane treatment of animals and their welfare.

This course is taught over approximately three days per week with an average class size of 20-30 students.

In classroom based learning you will be assessed through group and pair work, presentations, exams and course work. Although there are different aspects of the assessment process, this programme is assignment focused.

Another aspect of the programme is the 100 hours of work experience that is included. You will be able to build on your classroom based learning by working in local businesses to put your knowledge to practical use. This is compulsory and although the College will help with finding work experience placements, this is an assessed and compulsory module which you are responsible for in order to make the most of your degree.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level, preferably in a science subject) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - PPP Grades required, specific unit grades may be required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3.  Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language, mathematics and a science: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 0845 22 32 567 or email enquiries@cornwall.ac.uk

course.dc:description:
This course is awarded by Plymouth University.

Facilities

Cornwall College Newquay is situated directly next to Newquay Zoo. Our partnership with Newquay Zoo, and Blue Reef Aquarium, provides students with free access to their facilities which are used for teaching and independent study. Additional facilities are also accessed via Duchy College Animal Unit at Rosewarne, Westcountry Trout Farm and local farms and veterinary surgeries.

Students also benefit from our on-site facilities including:

-              modern buildings set in a grassed campus, managed to allow our native wildlife to flourish,

-              a well-stocked learning centre where books, computers and DVDs are available,

-              extensive individual learner support from teaching staff and dedicated learning support staff.

Progression note:

Successfull completion of this foundation degree enables students to top up to a BSc at Plymouth Univerisity (currently BSc (Hons) Animal Conservation Science). Other top up options are available (e.g. BSc (Hons) Applied Zoology at Newquay) subject to your grades.

UCAS Code: D301
Institution Code: CORN C78

This foundation degree is for Individuals interested in working with animals, for example in a zoo, on a farm, in a laboratory or with companion animals, applicants wishing to increase their knowledge in areas such as animal nutrition, health, welfare and biology and those interested in improving their practical skills and experience with a range of animals.
 
It provides you with the practical skills and knowledge required for managing companion, zoo, farm, wild and laboratory animals. The programme offers a series of modules to develop your skills in many areas of animal care, animal welfare and animal biology.

Year 1

Animal Husbandry (20 credits)

Cells and Microbiology (20 credits)

Introduction to Animal Behaviour (10 credits)

Personal and Employability Skills Development (20 credits)

Diversity, Classification and Evolution (20 credits)

Health, Hygiene and Welfare of Captive Animals (20 credits)

Business Skills for the Animal Care Sector (10 credits)

Year 2

Biology of Exotic Species (20 credits)

Bird Biology (10 credits)

Captive Diet & Feeding (10 credits)

Mammal Biology (20 credits)

Zoo Animal Management in Practice (20 credits)

Animal Nursing and Disease (10 credits)

Genetics and Reproduction of Animals (10 credits)

Individual Research Project (20 credits)

Following successful completion of the foundation degree (FdSc) you might choose to complete a one year top-up course in order to achieve a full honours degree BSc (hons). Please contact us for further details on current progression opportunities. Alternatively you might choose to go straight into employment. Former graduates have gone on to work in bird parks, the pet store industry, zoos, wildlife trusts, teaching in further education and the police force as dog handlers.

course.mlo:objective:
You will complete 100 hours of work experience during the two year course. You might choose to undertake a placement with a local organisation such as Newquay Zoo, Screech Owl Sanctuary, local farms or veterinary surgeries; or you might arrange a placement abroad. Previous students have completed placements with lions in Africa, elephants in Sri Lanka and dogs and cats in Thailand. This opportunity allows you to develop practical skills in your specific area of interest and apply your theoretical knowledge gained through your studies. It also enables you to make professional links for your future career.

Teaching of the course involves lectures, workshops, practical activities, visits and input from guest speakers working in the field. The course includes a range of assessment methods such as reports, exams and presentations.

The programme can be taken on a full-time or part-time basis.

course.dc:description:
Bursaries available - see Student Finance/Tuition Fees pages of this website for details.

This course is awarded by Plymouth University.

UCAS Code: C390
Institution Code: CORN C78

Zoological conservation is concerned with maintaining the wonderful diversity of animal life that exist on our planet and involves the protection and management of animal populations and their habitats in order to minimise the harmful effects human activities may have on them.  The course gives you the skills required to help conserve wild animals by developing your knowledge in topics such as ecology, biodiversity, animal nutrition, conservation genetics, anatomy and physiology aswell as primate behaviour and learning.  You will also gain first hand experience in observing wildlife and surveying different habitats.

The course is delivered using a range of lectures, seminars, field and lab practical and workshops. Guest speakers also play an important role in your learning and they are used regularly to provide more expert knowledge in some of the specialised modules and give an insight into conservation in action.

Module descriptions

Year 1 - All modules are core modules
 
  • Introduction to Animal Behaviour (10 credits)
  • Introduction to Zoology (20 credits)
  • Hygiene, Health & Welfare of Captive Animals (20 credits)
  • Fieldwork (20 credits)
  • Introduction to Ecology (10 credits)
  • Diversity, Classification & Evolution (20 credits)
  • Personal & Employability Skills Development (20 credits)
 
Year 2 
 
Core
 
  • Captive Diet & Feeding (10 credits)
  • Disease & Disease Control (10 credits)
  • Primate Behaviour & Cognition (10 credits)
  • Individual Research Project (20 credits)
  • Conservation in Practice (10 credits)
  • Genetics for Conservation (10 credits)
  • Vertebrate Zoology & Conservation (20 credits)
 
Optional modules (choose two 10 credit modules or one 20 credit module)
 
  • Insect Biology & Conservation (10 credits)
  • Aquaria & Conservation of Aquatic Organisms (10 credits)
  • Avian Behaviour & Ecology (20 credits)
  • Marine Vertebrate Biology & Conservation (20 credits)

Conservation, Zoology and Animal Behaviour
course.dc:title: FdSc Zoological Conservation
course.abstract: This course is for anyone concerned with maintaining the diversity of animal life that exists on our planet.
course.learningOutcome:
You may wish to go straight into employment in a zoos, or government advisory bodies or non government wildlife conservation organisations and other industries related to the animal world.

Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression.

Students who have completed a foundation degree may also wish to continue in higher education and progress to a full bachelor of science. Students can gain direct entry onto the BSc (Hons) Applied Zoology course delivered at Cornwall College Newquay, or BSc (Hons) Animal Conservation Science delivered at Plymouth University.
course.mlo:objective:
This foundation degree has been developed by Cornwall College and Plymouth University, working closely with staff from Newquay Zoo. You will be based at our Newquay campus adjacent to Newquay Zoo.

The programme is concerned with maintaining the huge diversity of animal life that exists on our planet and involves the protection and management of animal populations and their habitats. It is delivered over two years and you will have the opportunity to gain first-hand experience of observing animals at various collections. You will also be expected to complete relevant work experience in an area of your choice.

A variety of teaching methods are used including lectures, laboratory work and workshops.

Studying this programme will provide you with a firm scientific background and enable you to learn the practical skills required to understand the natural world. The course reflects the balance of skills and knowledge needed to perform well in wildlife environments.

Working in the industry is the very essence of a foundation degree and as such you will also undertake work experience locally or abroad.

Former students have worked on conservation projects, in rehabilitation centres, zoos and wildlife parks and nature reserves. This opportunity also helps you to develop graduate-level skills that will help you in any job. The work placements and contacts you make from these may well be your link to future employment after the course has finished.

An important part of your studies in the second year is your individual project which enables you to carry out first-hand research into an area that interests you.

Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3.  Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language, mathematics and a science: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered. 

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply. Previous learning and experience may be credited.

course.dc:description:
This course is awarded by Plymouth University.

Bursaries available - see student finance / tuition fees pages of our website for details.

UCAS Code: XP33
Institution Code: CORN C78

The FdSc Wildlife Education and Media course has been running for nearly 10 years and is a small, niche course specialising in mixing biological science, particularly zoology, with creative modes of science communication. This course puts a lot more emphasis on environmental education delivery and interpretation than most courses, using media as a vehicle for environmental education. For the media we will teach you introductory wildlife photography, introductory film-making and introductory podcast production, amongst other skills like site interpretation design, use of social media and use of industry standard software like Final Cut Pro and the Adobe Creative Cloud suite. 

Being a small course, the attention you'll receive from teaching staff will be intensive, with a lot of guidance given. We believe that this can help launch your career. To assist with that aim, we will guide your creation of a portfolio of your output, something to take to interview.

Ultimately, this two-year course (validated by Plymouth University and leading to the one-year top-up BSc (Hons) Applied Zoology with us (subject to conditions) or either of the one-year top-ups (BSc (Hons) Animal Conservation Science or BSc (Hons) Biosciences at Plymouth University) is aimed at those who want to be environmental educators and communicators. For example, nature reserve, zoo and aquaria educators; campaign co-ordinators for wildlife charities; PR for wildlife charities; educators in the natural history sections of museums; eco-tour and wildlife guides and rangers; teachers; environmental interpretation designers; scientific journalists; and - of course - wildlife photographers and film-makers who want a lot more science in their education. Basically, anyone interested in science communication!

Don't let the "media" word put you off - this is a foundation degree science qualification which uses science communication, potentially leading to a Bachelor's degree in a scientific qualification in three years, the same amount of time as a traditional degree. Also, don't let the "education" word put you off - you will quickly gain confidence! Those with no media or education delivery background are welcome to apply - we will teach you that. Those without a level 3 science qualification are also welcome to apply - see below for requirements.

For more information, please see below and click on the other tabs. Also head to www.facebook.com/WildlifeEducationMedia and like the page and/or follow the course on Twitter - @WildlifeEdMed. These social media sites highlight the topic areas this course is into.

For an idea of the kind of job you could do with this foundation degree, especially if you take a one year top-up to a BSc, take a look at the video below*:

http://youtu.be/O8TeJ8EsuhM 

* The video above is provided for information purposes and does not imply accreditation or approval of the course.

Modules

Year 1 

  • Wildlife Education (20 credits)
  • Wildlife and the Media (20 credits)
  • Evolutionary Theories (10 credits)
  • Personal & Employability Skills Development (20 credits)
  • Introduction to Zoology (20 credits)
  • Introduction to Ecology (10 credits)
  • Introduction to Animal Behaviour (10 credits)
  • Fieldwork Techniques (10 credits)               

Year 2

  • Education & Interpretation in Public Spaces (20 credits)
  • Educational Event Management ( 20 credits)
  • Communicating Science & Natural History (20 credits)
  • Primate Behaviour & Learning (10 credits)
  • Introduction to Avian Biology & Conservation (10 credits)
  • Marine Vertebrate Biology & Conservation (20 credits)
  • Individual Project (20 credits)

The course features group and personal tutorials which run alongside the main course. During induction, you will have an initial assessment and free-writing exercise which will be used to determine whether you require any additional support. If, at any time during the course, you feel you need to some additional support then all you need to do is ask and we can put something in place. We are a small, friendly site but part of a large organisation that can provide you with support. For those with educational statements or those that get given one after our initial assessment processes, you will be entitled to the provisions of that statement.
course.dc:subject: FdSc, Wildlife, Media, Conservation, zoology, education, journalism, reporter, writer, feature writer, journalist, science, wildlife education officer,
Conservation, Zoology and Animal Behaviour
course.dc:title: FdSc Wildlife Education and Media
course.abstract: For those who want to educate the public about wildlife
course.mlo:assessment: A mixture of assessment modes is used - coursework - including those using creative avenues - and tests/exams.
course.learningOutcome:
If you'd prefer not to leave Newquay you could progress onto our BSc (Hons) Applied Zoology top-up. This course has a module called Communicating Zoology that is well-worth choosing. It means that providing you pass your second year modules at first attempt, you could consider your enrolment on the FdSc Wildlife Education and Media course as a three year degree course culminating in a BSc (Hons) Applied Zoology.

Alternatively, you can progress onto the 1 year BSc (Hons) Animal Conservation Science or the BSc (Hons) Biosciences top-up courses at Plymouth University. This is the official progression route.

As a further alternative, you could progress onto the BSc (Hons) Environmental Resource Management, a 1 year top-up at our sister site at Cornwall College Camborne. This course may set entry requirements.

The above options mean that you could achieve a bachelor-level degree after three years - the same time as a degree in a traditional institution.

Finally, there are other degree courses around the country that you may find of interest. However, acceptance and year of entry is at the discretion of the institution that you apply to.

The Wildlife Education and Media course is an ideal platform to pursue these potential careers:

  • Wildlife education officer in zoos, wildlife parks, aquariums and nature reserves
  • Education officer in museums, particularly in natural history sections
  • Wildlife tour guides leading holiday expeditions for ecotourism companies
  • Teaching/instructing for outdoor education providers
  • Ranger for outdoor organisations
  • Education officer for wildlife charities
  • Conservation campaigns manager
  • Science journalism
  • Teaching science, particularly biology, in primary and secondary schools (would require a PGCE)
  • This course allows the opportunity to enter the competitive field of wildlife documentary production. The requirement is often for having a science degree (which this route provides, especially if you top up with a science BSc), and a high degree of drive and ambition, supported by lots of relevant work experience.
course.mlo:objective:
The Wildlife Education and Media Foundation Degree has been developed by Cornwall College Newquay and Plymouth University, working closely with Newquay Zoo, Blue Reef Aquarium and local primary and secondary schools. The programme aims to equip you with the necessary skills to talk to a variety of audiences about science and wildlife through a range of media.  You can study full-time (two years) or part-time (four years).

Based on the campus next to Newquay Zoo, this programme is designed to give you a solid grounding in many wildlife subjects such as anatomy and physiology, behaviour, ecology, and wildlife conservation, and the skills to communicate and educate members of the public whether your audience is young or old. You will study a wide range of modules that will help you increase your knowledge and understanding of communication, education and media. In addition you will develop graduate-level skills that will help you in any job due to the versatile nature of the content that you will be taught.

Throughout your studies you will have the opportunity to visit various science communication centres and also to gain first-hand experience of teaching in the classroom, through our afterschool club, Saplings.  Your media education will range from film and photography to interpretation, science writing, audio communications (like radio), and the creative arts. You will develop introductory skills in different media types and explore their strengths and weaknesses in conveying environmental messages to different audiences.

All through your course, we strongly recommend that you gain work experience, volunteering experience and internships. The more contacts you make - and the more you impress them with your ability and dedication - the more likely you'll find employment in the sector.

The programme normally caters for around 15 to 20 students each year enabling you to maximise your learning potential. 

Delivery is across approximately three to four days per week.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
If you are aged 18-20:

We welcome anyone with 120 UCAS points from Level 3 qualifications (e.g., AS and A-Levels, BTEC/City and Guilds Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma, International Baccalaureate, Access to HE Diplomas, Welsh/Scottish/Northern Irish equivalents to Level 3 qualifications). These Level 3 qualifications do not need to be in science (see below) or media to apply for this course.

For the AS/A-Level route, 80 UCAS points must be at A2-Level.

For the Access to HE route, you must have 45 credits at Level 3.

We also welcome candidates with an International Baccalaureate with 24 points or above.

Other qualifications meeting 120 UCAS points are welcome and will be assessed on application.

Those applicants with Level 3 qualifications in non-scientific subjects are more than welcome to apply because the course is about explaining environmental science and wildlife biology to the general public and you will learn the science needed on the course. You will be invited to interview and further entry requirements may be decided. It is strongly recommended if you are offered a place on the course that you read up on biology before enrolling - a reading list can be given.

All applicants need to have GCSEs at grade C or above in English language, mathematics and a science: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

If you are aged 21 or over:

We invite you to apply! You do not need a background in media or science, although reading up before entry, if accepted, is strongly recommended. The advice given and acceptance will depend on individual experience. You will be invited to interview (interview by phone or in person) and further entry requirements may be decided. Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 01637 857 957 or email newquay.enquiries@cornwall.ac.uk

Construction Trades
course.dc:title: Carpentry and Joinery Apprenticeship Level 3
course.abstract: This apprenticeship is designed for people who want to train on the job and gain a nationally recognised advanced qualification
course.learningOutcome:
With a Level 3 Diploma, you are a qualified site carpenter or bench joiner.

If you work for a large company, you may work as a planner and estimator, designer, production controller or specialist craftsperson. Alternatively, you could start your own business or teach wood occupations.

In the future, you may be interested in continuing your apprenticeship studies through Cornwall College Business and enrol in the team leading, people management, level 4 site supervision, wood machining or furniture making apprenticeship.

The full time BTEC Diploma in Construction and Built Environment or the FdSc Sustainable Construction course may interest to you, both are offered at Cornwall College.
course.mlo:objective:
You will attend lectures at the Camborne campus 1 or 2 days per week for 1 year, while the remainder of the week is spent in the workplace.

During this apprenticeship you will learn the complex aspects of site work or bench joinery.  The site carpentry course covers complex roofing, geometry and site operations; while the bench joinery course covers complex curved work.

You will put together a portfolio of evidence to show that you are competent at the tasks you do every day, while receiving support from experienced Cornwall College tutors.

Upon successful completion, you will be awarded the following qualifications:

  • NVQ Diploma in Wood Occupations (Construction)
  • Level 3 Diploma in Site Carpentry or Bench Joinery
course.mlo:prerequisite:
To enrol in this apprenticeship, you need to be aged 16 and over, have a minimum of 2 GCSEs at Grade C and be employed within a suitable position.

You must have completed the Level 2 Carpentry and Joinery Apprenticeship or have the relevant experience.

If you are interested in this apprenticeship and do not have the required GCSEs or an employer, speak to one of our Cornwall College Business Liaison Officers on 0800 731 7594.

course.dc:title: Marine Surface Finishing Apprenticeship Level 3
course.learningOutcome:
With a Level 3 Certificate, you are a fully qualified marine craftsperson and could work as a boat builder, marine surface finisher or a marine maintenance technician. In the future, you could progress to the level of a supervisor, technical manager, programme manager or programme director within the boatbuilding industry.

You may be interested in studying further and enrol in the team leading, people management, carpentry and joinery or engineering apprenticeship through Cornwall College Business. Alternatively you may be interested in the full time FdSc Boat Design and Production course, which is offered at Cornwall College.
course.mlo:objective:
You will attend lectures at the Camborne campus 1 day per week for 2 years, while the remainder of the week is spent in the work place.

During this apprenticeship you will build onto your level 2 certificate and have the opportunity to select a pathway to suit your job e.g. electrical installation and maintenance, mechanical installation and maintenance, sheet metalwork, manual welding, rigging, surface preparation and yacht painting.

You may prepare and finish a variety of tasks within the project from hand grips and marine engines to repairing hulls of boats and carbon fibre masts; you will develop thorough knowledge in boatbuilding and gain valuable experience. You may even see your yacht launched!

You will put together a portfolio of evidence to show that you are competent at the tasks you do every day, while receiving  support from experienced Cornwall College tutors.

Upon successful completion, you will be awarded the following qualifications:

  • Level 3 NVQ Marine Engineering
  • Level 3 Certificate in Boatbuilding, Maintenance and Support
course.mlo:prerequisite:
To enrol in this apprenticeship, you need to be aged 16 and over, ideally have a minimum of 5 GCSEs at Grade C (preferably English, Maths and IT) and be employed within a suitable position.  

You must have completed the Level 2 Marine Surface Finishing Apprenticeship or have the relevant experience.

If you are interested in this apprenticeship and do not have the required GCSEs or an employer, speak to one of our Cornwall College Business Liaison Officers on 0800 731 7594.

Thereafter, you may find yourself working as a teacher, early years practitioner, early years manager, further education lecturer, adult education tutor, care worker, volunteer, social care worker or SEN teacher.
course.mlo:objective:

The main areas of teaching in class include promoting positive behaviour, supporting learning assessment and activities, understanding development and safeguarding of children and young people.

You will put together a portfolio of evidence to show that you are competent at the tasks you do every day, while receiving support from experienced Cornwall College tutors.

Upon successful completion, you will be awarded the following qualification:

course.mlo:objective:
You will attend workshops over the duration of the apprenticeship in the Cornwall College Digital Academy at St Austell

IT technician (Cisco or Microsoft course available)

Two pathways available

  • Cisco - you will attend workshops to develop your skills in networking
  • Microsoft Server 2012 - you will attend workshops to develop your skills in working with servers

The Microsoft pathway will give you the opportunity of 2 units accredited towards the MCSA (Microsoft Certified Solutions Associate)

Website or Software Developer (C++ programming, Software design fundamentals, Software testing courses available)

This pathway includes:

  • Software design fundamentals
  • C++ computer programming
  • Software testing

You will be assessed through building a portfolio of evidence, written assignments or exams.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
To enrol in this apprenticeship, you need to be aged 16 and over, have a minimum of 5 GCSEs at Grade C or above in English, Mathemathics and IT and be employed in a technical IT position.

If you are interested in this apprenticeship, speak to our Customer Services Team on 0800 731 7594.

This apprenticeship is designed for people who want to train on the job to become a fully qualified nail technician.

You must enjoy working in the beauty industry and on a one to one basis with clients. You will need good hand to eye coordination to carry out your work, as well as good customer service skills as you will be working with clients all day. This is a follow on course from the Level 2 Nail Services Apprenticeship, and supports those working as a trainee nail technician.
course.dc:subject: apprenticeship, beauty, spa, nail, nail technician, nails services
Hair & Beauty
Apprenticeships
course.dc:title: Nail Services Apprenticeship Level 3
course.learningOutcome:
With a Level 3 Diploma, you will be a qualified nail technician and can work in a variety of locations including salons, spas, resorts, hotels or start your own business. You may have the opportunity to be involved in photographic nail shoots!

In the future, you may be interested in continuing your apprenticeship studies through Cornwall College Business and enrol in a team leading, people management, customer service or business administration apprenticeship. Alternatively, you may be interested in the full time spa therapy course, offered at Cornwall College.
course.mlo:objective:
You will attend lectures at the St Austell campus 1 day per week for 1 year, while the remainder of the week is spent in the workplace.

During this apprenticeship you will work as a nail technician and learn how to maintain and repair a range of artificial nail systems. You may be involved in planning, designing and creating images for nail art which will give you specialist skills to build on in the future.

You will put together a portfolio of evidence to show that you are competent at the tasks you do every day, while receiving support from experienced Cornwall College tutors.

Upon successful completion, you will be awarded the following qualification:

  • NVQ Level 3 Diploma in Nail Services
course.mlo:prerequisite:
To enrol in the apprenticeship, you need to be aged 16 and over, have a minimum of 2 GCSEs at Grade C and be employed as a trainee nail technician. You must have completed the Level 2 Nail Services Apprenticeship or have the relevant experience.

If you are interested in this apprenticeship and do not have the required  GCSEs or an employer, speak to one of our Cornwall College Business Liaison Officers on 0800 731 7594.

Business, Administration & Law
course.dc:title: Accounting Apprenticeship Level 3
course.abstract: This apprenticeship is designed for people who want to train on the job and gain a nationally recognised qualification in accounting
course.learningOutcome:
With a Level 3 Diploma, you could progress to the AAT Level 4 Diploma.

After completing all 3 levels of the accounting apprenticeship, you could work as an Accounts Clerk, Credit Control Assistant, Finance Assistant or Purchase Ledger Clerk in any type of business or industry e.g. large public sector, small companies, not for profit companies or clubs.

Thereafter you could progress to a full membership of the Association of Accounting Technicians and then complete a professional accounting qualification with a chartered body:

  • CIPFA - The Chartered Institute of Public Finance and Accountancy
  • ACCA - Association of Chartered Certified Accounts
  • CIMA - Chartered Institute of Management Accountants
  • ICAEW - The Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales

Alternatively, you may wish to enrol in a management apprenticeship at Cornwall College Business or a full time business related course at Cornwall College.
course.mlo:objective:
You will attend lectures at the Camborne, St Austell or Saltash campus 1 day per week for 44 weeks, while the remainder of the week is spent in the workplace.

During this apprenticeship, you will learn more complex finance officer processes e.g. final accounts for sole traders and partnerships, reports and returns, and professional ethics. You will also learn how to use Sage accounting software.

You will put together a portfolio of evidence to show that you are competent at the tasks you do every day, while receiving support from experienced Cornwall College tutors.

Upon successful completion, you will be awarded the following qualification:

AAT Level 3 Accounting Diploma
course.mlo:prerequisite:
To enrol in the AAT Level 3 Accounting Diploma, you need to be aged 16 and over, have a minimum of 5 GCSEs at Grade C (ideally in English and Maths) and be employed in a trainee accounting position. You must have completed an AAT Level 2 Apprenticeship or have the relevant experience.

If you are interested in this apprenticeship and do not have the required GCSEs or an employer, speak to one of our Cornwall College Business Liaison Officers on 0800 731 7594.

This apprenticeship supports a variety of administration job roles in any industry e.g. executive assistants, secretaries and administration assistants.
course.dc:subject: Admin, administration, admin assistant, Business foundation degree,business management, management, marketing, planning, post grad, retail business, public services, enterprise, marketing, management, accoutnancy, human resource, business law, business development, venture, employability, leadership, strategy development, business finance, legal, economics, research,
Business, Administration & Law
Apprenticeships
course.dc:title: Business Administration Apprenticeship Level 3
course.learningOutcome: Upon successful completion, you can progress onto any of the Business Skills courses offered at Cornwall College at the same or a higher level.
course.mlo:objective:
This course consists of six mandatory units and a range of optional units, to give a minimum of 58 credits in total.  Delivery will consist of class-based and work based learning.  The mandatory units are:

  • Communicate in a business environment
  • Principles of business communication and information
  • Principles of administration
  • Principles of business
  • Manage personal and professional development
  • Understand employer organisations

 You then select the optional units to suit your specific job role, which may include:

  • Contributing to the improvement of business performance
  • Document production
  • Co-ordinating an event / meetings
  • Evaluating and maintain customer service
  • Managing information and data

As part of the apprenticeship framework you are required to complete Functional Skills in English, Maths and ICT at Level 2 unless exemptions are provided.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
To enrol in this apprenticeship, you need to be aged 16 and over and be employed in a senior administrative role.

If you are interested in this apprenticeship and do not have the required GCSEs or an employer, speak to one of our Cornwall College Business Liaison Officers on 0800 731 7594.

This apprenticeship is designed for people who want to become a fully qualified electrician while training on the job.

You must have good practical skills, be able to follow technical drawings and work carefully and methodically. Due to the nature of the work, you must be willing to work in confined spaces and have a head for heights. This course supports those working as a trainee electrician.

course.dc:title: Electrotechnical Apprenticeship Level 3
course.abstract: This apprenticeship is designed for people who want to become a fully qualified electrician while training on the job
course.learningOutcome:
With the above qualifications and certificates, you are a qualified electrician and could work in the following positions:

  • Installation Electrician - installation of power systems, lighting, fire protection, security and structured cabling in a variety of buildings
  • Maintenance Electrician - regular inspection of systems to ensure they are working correctly

You may find yourself working for a large employer and progress to managing projects or clients; or start your own business.

In the future, you may be interested in completing further qualifications e.g. 2391 Test and Inspection, 17th Edition Wiring regulations (2382), Photovoltaic systems, PAT (Portable Appliance Test) Inspection or Introduction to Carbon Management. Thereafter you could progress to a FdSc Carbon Management or FdSc Renewable Energy Technologies, and work on environmentally friendly systems or innovation projects.
course.mlo:objective:
You will attend lectures at the Camborne, St Austell or Saltash campus for 42 months. During the first 3 years, you will attend lectures 1 day per week, assessment in the workplace.

During this apprenticeship you work under the direction of a qualified electrician. You will learn how to diagnose and correct electrical faults; and install and connect wiring systems, wiring enclosures and equipment. You will be required to complete 2 technical certificates:

  • Inspection
  • Testing and Commissioning Assignment
  • Fault Diagnosis and Rectification Assignment

You will put together a portfolio of evidence to show that you are competent at the tasks you do every day, while receiving support from experienced Cornwall College tutors.

Upon successful completion, you will be awarded the following qualifications:

  • Level 3 NVQ Electrotechnical Diploma
course.mlo:prerequisite:
To enrol in this apprenticeship, you need to be aged 16 and over, ideally have a minimum of 3 GCSEs at Grade C (preferably English, Maths and IT) and be employed within a suitable position.  

If you are interested in this apprenticeship and do not have the required GCSEs or an employer, speak to one of our Cornwall College Business Liaison Officers on 0800 731 7594.

This apprenticeship is designed for people who want to train on the job and gain a nationally recognised qualification in Hospitality Supervision and Leadership.

This course supports a variety of roles including head housekeeper, head reception, unit manager in a hotel chain, regional supervisor/manager in a restaurant/pub and more.

This is a follow on course from the Level 2 Hospitality Apprenticeship.

Apprenticeships

course.learningOutcome:
In the future, you could progress to a more senior position in your organisation, regional management or general management.

You may wish to study further and enrol in a People Management Apprenticeship, an FdA Event Management or FdA Hospitality Management at Cornwall College. This could lead to a BSc (Hons) or BA (Hons) in a variety of areas through Cornwall College or the University of Plymouth.
course.mlo:objective:
This apprenticeship is work based, so you will receive training on your job for 18 months. During this apprenticeship, you will develop advanced skills in leadership and customer service, while you will be required to put together a portfolio of evidence and undergo college assessments.

Throughout this course, you will receive support from experienced Cornwall College tutors.

Upon successful completion, you will be awarded the following qualifications:

  • NVQ Diploma in Hospitality Supervision and Leadership
  • Level 3 Award in Hospitality Supervision and Leadership (QCF)
course.mlo:prerequisite:
To enrol in this advanced apprenticeship, you need to be aged 16 and over, have a minimum of 5 GCSEs at Grade C (Maths and English preferred) and be employed in a suitable position within the hospitality industry.

You must have completed a Level 2 Hospitality Apprenticeship or have the relevant experience.

This advanced apprenticeship is designed for people who want to train on the job to become a qualified senior stylist. You must enjoy working within a salon environment and enjoy working on a one to one basis with clients.
