course.abstract: Horse Care Apprenticeship
course.learningOutcome: On successful completion you can commence work in the industry using your practical skills or progress onto the advanced work based diploma in horse care, further or higher education opportunities.
course.mlo:objective:
This level can take up to eighteen months to complete where you will work towards the
Level 2 Work-based Diploma and technical qualification. On this programme you will develop and demonstrate competence in the following areas:

• Maintain health and well-being of horses
• Preparing horses for use
• Supervision, riding and exercising
• Feeding and welfare
• Cleaning of stables
• Loading and unloading horses under supervision
• Ensure own actions reduce risks to health and safety
• Maintain effective working relationships
• Health and safety with horses certification (technical certificate)
• Functional skills or key skills (where applicable)
• Emergency first aid
• Employment rights and responsibilities

In addition to the above, a further specialist pathway will be undertaken relating to:

• Care of performance horses
• Riding
• Exercising
• Driving
• Leading a trek
• Assisting riders with special needs
• Reproduction and care of young stock

These apprenticeships are delivered at our Duchy College Stoke Climsland campus with possibilities at Rosewarne or an industry based venue. This normally means one day each week spent at college and the remaining four days in the workplace with your employer.
You will be assigned a Liaison Officer who will also visit you at your workplace to offer you further support and guidance.
course.mlo:prerequisite: 2 GCSEs at grade D or above are essential - however, applicants with relevant prior experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered, and must be prepared to work towards a level 2 functional skills qualification in English and Maths.

course.dc:description:
If you are interested in this apprenticeship, contact Cornwall College Business and complete an online apprenticeship form. If you meet the requirements, you will be invited for an interview and be given advice and guidance on how to proceed.

There are no apprenticeship course fees charged for anyone between the ages of 16 and 18.  For those aged 19 and over, fees do apply.

Contact us for more information.

This apprenticeship is designed for people who want to train on the job and gain a nationally recognised qualification in site carpentry or bench joinery.

You must have good practical and hand skills, be able to follow technical drawings accurately and have good attention to detail.

Cornwall College Business will help you choose the right pathway to suit your job; this apprenticeship supports those working as a trainee site carpenter or bench joiner.
course.dc:subject: Wood, occupation, carpentry, joinery, timber, apprenticeship, construction, carpenter, joiner, cabinet making, city & guilds, CG, C&G, city and guilds
Construction Trades
Apprenticeships
course.dc:title: Carpentry and Joinery Apprenticeship Level 2
course.learningOutcome:
With a Level 2 Diploma, you can start working towards the nationally recognised Level 3 Diploma by enrolling in the advanced apprenticeship.  

Once you are a qualified carpenter or joiner, you may progress to the level of a supervisor or manager. If you work for a large company, you could work as a planner and estimator, designer, production controller or specialist craftsperson. Alternatively, you could start your own business or teach wood occupations.

In the future, you may be interested in continuing your apprenticeship studies through Cornwall College Business and enrol in the team leading, people management, level 4 site supervision, wood machining or furniture making apprenticeship. The full time BTEC Diploma in Construction and Built Environment or the FdSc Sustainable Construction course may interest to you, both are offered at Cornwall College.
course.mlo:objective:
You will attend lectures 1 or 2 days per week for 2 years, while the remainder of the week is spent in the workplace.

During this apprenticeship you will learn all aspects of site carpentry or bench joinery. The site carpentry course covers truss roofing, hanging doors, kitchen fitting and windows installation; while the bench joinery course covers making doors, windows and stairs.

You will put together a portfolio of evidence to show that you are competent at the tasks you do every day, while receiving support from experienced Cornwall College tutors.

Upon successful completion, you will be awarded the following qualifications:

  • NVQ Diploma in Wood Occupations (Construction)
  • Level 2 Diploma in Site Carpentry or Bench Joinery
course.mlo:prerequisite:
To enrol in this apprenticeship, you need to be aged 16 and over, ideally have a minimum of 2 GCSEs at Grade C and be employed within a suitable position.

If you are interested in this apprenticeship and do not have the required GCSEs or an employer, speak to one of our Cornwall College Business Liaison Officers on 0800 731 7594.

This apprenticeship is designed for people who want to train on the job and gain a nationally recognised qualification in Business Administration.

If you are efficient and enjoy organising people and resources, this is a great apprenticeship for you to start your career. This apprenticeship supports a variety of administration job roles in any industry e.g. executive assistants, secretaries, administration assistants, data entry clerks and office juniors.
course.dc:subject: Admin, administration, admin assistant, Business foundation degree,business management, management, marketing, planning, post grad, retail business, public services, enterprise, marketing, management, accoutnancy, human resource, business law, business development, venture, employability, leadership, strategy development, business finance, legal, economics, research,
Business, Administration & Law
Apprenticeships
course.dc:title: Business Administration Apprenticeship Level 2
course.learningOutcome:
Upon successful completion, you can progress onto another Level 2 qualification in a complimentary subject such as Customer Service, Sales or IT.  To progress onto Level 3 your role must include additional responsibilities which may involve supervision or training.

Completing both the Level 2 and Level 3 Business Administration apprenticeships will help you progress in your career through senior administration to management.

In the future, you may be interested in continuing your studies through Cornwall College Business and enrol in the customer service, team leading, people management or leader management apprenticeships. Thereafter, you may wish to study further and complete an FdA Business or FdA E-business Management, followed by a BA (Hons) Business Enterprise through Cornwall College.
course.mlo:objective:
This course consists of six mandatory units and a range of optional units to suit your job role, to give a minimum of 45 credits in total.  Delivery will consist of class-based and work based learning.  The mandatory units are:

  • Communicate in a business environment
  • Principles of providing administrative services
  • Principles of business document production and information management
  • Understand employer organisations
  • Manage personal performance and development
  • Develop working relationships with colleagues

You then select the optional units to suit your specific job role, which may include:

  • Use a telephone and voicemail system
  • Manage diary systems
  • Store and retrieve information / Archive information
  • Use and maintain office equipment
  • Maintain and issue stationery stock items
  • Prepare documents/ Prepare text from notes using touch typing
  • Support the organisation of an event / meeting / travel and accommodation

As part of the apprenticeship framework you are required to complete Functional Skills in English, Maths and ICT at Level 1 unless exemptions are provided.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
To enrol in this apprenticeship, you need to be aged 16 and over, have a minimum of 2 GCSEs at Grade C (ideally in English and Maths) and be employed in an administrative role.

If you are interested in this apprenticeship and do not have the required GCSEs or an employer, speak to one of our Cornwall College Business Liaison Officers on 0800 731 7594.

course.dc:title: Accounting Apprenticeship Level 2
course.abstract: This apprenticeship is designed for people who want to train on the job and gain a nationally recognised qualification in accounting
course.learningOutcome:
From this apprenticeship, you could progress to the AAT Level 3 Diploma and then advance to the AAT Level 4 Diploma.

Upon completion of all 3 levels of the accounting apprenticeship, you could work as an Accounts Clerk, Credit Control Assistant, Finance Assistant or Purchase Ledger Clerk in any type of business or industry.

Thereafter you could progress to a full membership of the Association of Accounting Technicians and then complete a professional accounting qualification with a chartered body:

  • CIPFA - The Chartered Institute of Public Finance and Accountancy
  • ACCA - Association of Chartered Certified Account
  • CIMA - Chartered Institute of Management Accountants
  • ICAEW - The Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales

Alternatively, you may wish to enrol in a management apprenticeship at Cornwall College Business or a full time business related course at Cornwall College.
course.mlo:objective:
You attend lectures at the Camborne, St Austell or Saltash campus 1 day per week for 35 weeks, while the remainder of the week is spent in the work place. There are a number of start dates throughout the year, contact Cornwall College Business for more information.

During this apprenticeship, you will learn finance administrator skills e.g. double entry bookkeeping, basic costing principles, and purchase, sales and general ledgers. You will also learn how to use Sage accounting software.

You will put together a portfolio of evidence to show that you are competent at the tasks you do every day, while receiving support from experienced Cornwall College tutors.

Upon successful completion, you will be awarded the following qualification:

AAT Level 2 Accounting Certificate
course.mlo:prerequisite:
To enrol in the AAT Level 2 Accounting Certificate, you need to be aged 16 and over, have a minimum of 5 GCSEs at Grade C (ideally in English and Maths) and be employed in a trainee accounting position.

If you are interested in this apprenticeship and do not have the required GCSEs or an employer, speak to one of our Cornwall College Business Liaison Officers on 0800 731 7594.

This apprenticeship is designed for people who want to train on the job and gain a nationally recognised qualification in plumbing.

You must enjoy working in the construction industry, have good practical and hand skills and be able to follow technical drawings and building plans. No two days are the same; you must enjoy doing a variety of tasks and be good at solving problems.
course.dc:subject: plumbing services, plumbing, plumber, construction, apprenticeship, water, oil, firing, solar thermal, domestic hot water, gas fires, gas cookers, water regulations, LPG, water, city & guilds, city and guilds, CG, C&G
Apprenticeships
Construction Trades
course.dc:title: Plumbing Apprenticeship Level 2
course.abstract: This apprenticeship is designed for people who want to train on the job and gain a nationally recognised qualification in plumbing.
course.learningOutcome:
With a Level 2 Certificate, you are a qualified plumber and can start working towards the Advanced Level 3 Certificate. At this point you could complete the Domestic/Light Commercial Oil Firing System Installation qualification, or complete this after the level 3 apprenticeship.

Upon successful completion of the Level 3 Apprenticeship, you are qualified to an advanced level and could work as a plumbing technician or be involved in designing environmentally friendly systems e.g. water management, grey water systems and rain water catchment.

You may wish to gain further qualifications through Cornwall College:

  • Domestic/Light Commercial Oil Firing System Installation
  • NICEIC Building Regulations Part P Domestic Installer Qualification - Defined Scope Level B
  • LPG - Boats
  • LPG - Leisure Activity Vehicles
  • LPG - Residential Park Homes
  • NICEIC Natural Gas to LPG Gas Changeover Assessment
  • NICEIC Energy Efficiency Building Regulations
  • NICEIC Level 3 Solar Thermal Hot Water
  • NICEIC Gas Fires and Heaters
  • NICEIC Gas Cookers
  • Combustion Performance Analysers
  • Heat Pumps Ground and Air Source to be offered soon
  • Rain Water Harvesting to be offered soon

In the future, you may be interested in starting your own business, teaching or working in a management position in a variety of industries e.g. plumbing, oil, water.
course.mlo:objective:
You will attend lectures at the Camborne, St Austell or Saltash campus 1 day per week for 2 years, while the remainder of the week is spent in the work place. During this apprenticeship you will install basic cold water, hot water, sanitation and central heating systems.

You will put together a portfolio of evidence to show that you are competent at the tasks you do every day, while receiving  support from experienced Cornwall College tutors.

Upon successful completion, you will be awarded the following qualifications:

  • Level 2 NVQ Diploma in Plumbing and Heating
course.mlo:prerequisite:
To enrol in this apprenticeship, you need to be aged 16 and over, ideally have a minimum of 2 GCSEs at Grade C (ideally in Maths and English) and be employed within a training plumbing position.  

If you are interested in this apprenticeship and do not have the required GCSEs or an employer, speak to one of our Cornwall College Business Liaison Officers on 0800 731 7594.

This apprenticeship is designed for people who want to train on the job and gain a nationally recognised qualification in craft masonry. You must enjoy working in the construction industry and have good practical and hand skills.

This course supports those working in a trainee craft masonry position.
course.dc:subject: trowel, plaster, bricklay, occupation, construction, building, apprenticeship, craft mason, brick laying, flooring, builder, plastering, city and guilds, CG, C&G, city & guilds
Construction Trades
Apprenticeships
course.dc:title: Trowel Occupations Apprenticeship Level 2
course.learningOutcome:
With a Level 2 Diploma, you are qualified to a semi skilled level in craft masonry and can start working towards the Level 3 Diploma by completing the advanced apprenticeship. Once you are fully qualified, you could progress to a foreman or supervisory role within the construction industry.

In the future, you may be interested in studying further and complete a Level 3 NVQ Diploma in Construction Contracting Operations, Level 3 NVQ Diploma in Site Supervision or FdSc Sustainable Construction. Thereafter you could progress to a BSc (Hons) in Environmental Construction Surveying, Building Surveying or Construction Management.
course.mlo:objective:
You will attend lectures at the Camborne, St Austell or Saltash campus 1-2 days per week for 2 years. For practical tests, you will be required to complete a number of 1 week blocks at Cornwall College.

During this apprenticeship you will build cavity walling forming masonry structures, plaster and render surfaces, interpret working drawings to set out masonry structures, maintain slate and roof tiling and build solid walling masonry structures.

You will put together a portfolio of evidence to show that you are competent at the tasks you do every day, while receiving support from experienced Cornwall College tutors.

Upon successful completion, you will be awarded the following qualifications:

  • Level 2 NVQ Diploma in Trowel Occupation
  • Level 2 Diploma in Craft Masonry (QCF)
course.mlo:prerequisite:
To enrol in this apprenticeship, you need to be aged 16 and over, ideally have a minimum of 2 GCSEs at Grade C and be employed in a trowel position.  

If you are interested in this apprenticeship and do not have the required GCSEs or an employer, speak to one of our Cornwall College Business Liaison Officers on 0800 731 7594.

This first stage Certificate in Education and Training qualification is designed to support those who are working or hope to work as teachers or trainers in the Further Education and Skills Learning Sector.
course.dc:title: Education and Training Certificate
course.learningOutcome: Successful completion of this qualification will support you in applying for teacher and training roles in the Further Education and the Skills Learning Sector and progress onto the Level 5 Diploma in Education and Training.
course.mlo:objective: Those who study this qualification will gain understanding of the roles and responsibilities of a teacher in relation to legislation, equality, diversity, inclusivity and meeting the needs of learners. You will learn to use initial and diagnostic assessments and plan and deliver inclusive teaching and learning. You will also be able to assess learning and use appropriate resources to support effective learning.
course.mlo:prerequisite: You will need to have access to 30 hours of teaching to study this course.

CE:cost.dc:description: Please call our Enquiries Team for more details on this course.

course.dc:description: Contact us for more information call Sue Searle on 01209 617519 or e mail  sue.searle@cornwall.ac.uk

Postgraduate Certificate in Education (PGCE) incorporating the Diploma in Education and Training (DET)  is specifically designed for graduates with a commitment to teaching in the Lifelong Learning sector: Further Education; Community Education; Work-based Learning and similar public sector, voluntary and commercial settings.

The course is offered as both a one year full-time programme at Cornwall College sites in Camborne and St Austell, and as a two year part-time programme in St Austell, Camborne and Saltash and/or Stoke Climsland.

If you decide to study full time, you will be required to attend College for two days a week with additional teaching practice over two or three days a week and other directed study, including the use of our Virtual Learning Environment. If you decide to study part time, you will attend college for approximately 3 hours per week, through the day or in the evening.

Modules

Year 1

  • Learning, Teaching & Assessment (30 credits)
  • Principles of Teaching & Innovation, Enterprise & Employability (30 credits)

Year 2

  • Curriculum & Society (30 credits)
  • Wider Practice & Professional Development (30 credits)
course.dc:subject: PGCE, Cert Ed, DTLLS, CTLLS, PTLLS, Teaching, Teacher, Training, Lifelong Learning Sector, Certificate in Education, niceic, Postgraduate, part time, Certificate
The School of Education and Professional Development
course.dc:title: Postgraduate Certificate in Education (Part Time)
course.abstract: Designed for graduates with a commitment to teaching in the Lifelong Learning sector
course.mlo:assessment: The course is assessed through coursework, observation and practice.
course.learningOutcome:
This nationally endorsed qualification prepares you to work as a teacher or trainer anywhere in the Lifelong Learning sector. It allows you to meet the initial training requirements for membership of the Institute for Learning and will underpin an application for Qualified Teacher of Learning and Skills (QTLS) status.

 

 

 

Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression.

 

Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm)

 

Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
The PGCE  programme supports you in becoming an effective and well-informed teacher of your chosen subject. You will follow a core programme in college throughout the academic year, where you will be involved in presentations, seminars, practical workshops, tutorials, lectures and directed study through our Learning Centre and Virtual Learning Environment. Cor modules

The programme consists of four core modules. Over the four modules, you will explore and analyse current ideas related to teaching and learning in post compulsory education and training, also known as the Lifelong Learning sector.

The programme offers a balance of practical skills, reflection and related education theories. The core modules will be concerned with the processes of teaching and learning, assessment, principles of teaching, continuing personal and professional development, curriculum and society and wider professional practices.

The opportunity to consider all these areas specifically in the light of your own professional life, subject specialisms and experience will be central to your professional development. Through individual professional development planning, the programme gives you the chance to evidence your developing practical skills, knowledge and understanding in relation to a range of aims and targets. It also allows you to reflect upon the complex relationships between practice and theory.

You will follow a teaching practice programme of at least 100 hours, where you will also get invaluable help from other experienced teachers of your subject. Your tutor will support both parts of your training and will regularly observe you teaching. Observations will also be undertaken by other experienced teachers.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
You must hold qualifications relevant to the subject you teach or have substantial relevant work experience.  A full Bachelor's Degree, plus an  English Language qualification at level 2 and Mathematic qualification at Level 1 or above.

 

Proof of qualifications will be required at interview stage.

 

A Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check will be a mandatory requirement after you have been accepted on the programme. It is your responsibility to undertake this before commencing your study.

course.dc:description:
Students benefit from arranging some personal counselling for themselves for purposes of personal support and also to experience counselling as a client. As well as the college counselling available there is also a low cost counselling agency, the Penhaligon Counselling Agency attached to the college.

You will be required to attend an induction session at the start of your course. During this time you will have the opportunity to meet the Programme Manager, teaching staff , other applicants and gain an insight of the course content and requirements.

This course is especially for those working in the caring and helping professions or for those in other areas of work or study where the value of counselling and skills is recognised.

It (or equivalent) is a requirement for anyone wishing to progress onto our HE counselling courses.

course.abstract: This is course is especially for those working in the caring profession.
course.learningOutcome: Successful students can progress to further counselling courses such as the Certificate in Advanced Counselling Studies or the Diploma in Person Centred Counselling and Therapy.
course.mlo:objective:
This qualification consists of 4 mandatory units which must all be completed in order to be awarded the qualification.

Units are:

  • Using counselling Skills
  • Introduction to counselling skills theories
  • Diversity and ethics in the use of counselling skills
  • Counselling skills and personal development

You will complete a portfolio of work demonstrating successful completion.
course.mlo:prerequisite: Candidates must have an interest in the use of counselling skills in a variety of contexts and also be aged 19 or over.

UCAS Code: B942
Institution Code: CORN C78

We are pleased to offer candidates in Cornwall, the opportunity to gain the University of Plymouth Certificate in Advanced Counselling Studies. The programme is intended for persons who have either completed a level 2 or 3 counselling course and who are already using counselling skills in their professional or voluntary work particularly in the helping, caring, healthcare, social care or educational capacities.

Modules
 
  • Counselling Theory and Practice (20 Credits)
  • Counselling Contexts (20 Credits)
  • Personal Development (20 Credits)
  • Professional Development (20 Credits)
  • Ethical Issues in Counselling (20 Credits)
  • Study Skills (20 Credits)
course.dc:subject: Certificate, counsellor, counselling, counseller, social work, community work, social, social work, youth work, psychotherapy, sociology, therapist, psychologist
The School of Education and Professional Development
course.dc:title: Certificate in Advanced Counselling Studies
course.abstract: The course is for persons who have either completed an introductory counselling course or who are already using counselling skills.
course.learningOutcome:
You could choose to study further towards a degree in Counselling. The course has been designed specifically to qualify successful students to be considered for entry to the second year degree level study, the Diploma in Person-centred Counselling & Therapy, a professional qualification accredited by the BACP. This course is currently offered part-time over two years. Thereafter, a further year of study could qualify you for a BA (Hons) in Counselling Studies.

This qualification may also be used in employment in your chosen career or may be used as the basis for further study in an associated subject.

Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression. Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm) Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
You will work in a supportive and stimulating group with tutors who subscribe to the British Association of Counselling and Psychotherapy (BACP) Ethical Framework.  Assessment is through coursework, and we use a self, peer and tutor assessment process.

The 20 credit modules that you will study are: Personal Development, Counselling Theory and Practice, Professional Development, Study Skills, Counselling Contexts and Ethical Issues in Counselling. You will develop your counselling skills within a person-centred framework.

The personal development module will provide a structure for developing awareness of yourself and how you relate to others. The Counselling Contexts module will develop your analytical and evaluative skills.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
A minimum of 19 years of age with a level 2 certificate in counselling skills (min 75 hours - not distance learning) qualification.  You will also hold academic qualifications to at least A-level or satisfy the interviewing tutors that you have appropriate aptitude for academic study at this level.

Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 0845 22 32 567 or email enquiries@cornwall.ac.uk.

School of Education & Training (SET)
course.dc:title: BA (Hons) Counselling Studies
course.abstract: This course is for those with an interest in counselling who have already studied to HE Level 5
course.mlo:assessment: You will be assessed through a variety of activities including essays, presentations and research study.
course.learningOutcome:
The qualification will strengthen your position in the job market so you can go straight into employment or you could continue your studies by taking a master's degree.

Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression. Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm) Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
You will study three core modules and three optional modules. You can also choose a pathway which supports your interest and employment direction:

  • Counselling Supervision Intended for counsellors seeking to develop their professional roles by becoming supervisors of counsellors. It is therefore a pre-requisite of this pathway that you are a qualified, practising counsellor with a minimum of one year post-qualified experience..
  • Social Issues Intended for students who wish to develop their knowledge and understanding of a range of client issues. Contains modules on working with young people and rural poverty.
  • Therapeutic Approaches Focuses on a range of counselling approaches. These modules will be of interest to practising counsellors but there is no requirement to be working with clients. They are therefore accessible to all students on the programme.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
240 credits (including at least 120 at Level 5) in Counselling, Social Sciences or Psychology. 

If you do not have the required points, you can take the Certificate in Advanced Counselling Studies (to give you the first year of the degree) followed by the Diploma in Person-centred Counselling and Therapy.

Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 0845 22 32 567 or email enquiries@cornwall.ac.uk.

UCAS Code: LL53

This three year BSc Honours degree course is for anyone who has an interest in Health, Community and Social Sciences and for those who wish to pursue a career in a related area. The course has been designed to equip you with the skills and knowledge base required to work in your chosen specialism or progress onto other graduate opportunities. It is also a platform from which you can undertake additional vocational and academic qualifications and requires you to undertake work based learning and gain an honours degree that can be completed in Cornwall. The course has been designed with a number of pathways which will allow you to specialise within a particular area of study.

Year 1

Core Modules:

  • Keeping Children, Young People and Adults at Risk Safe (20 credits)
  • Values and Ethics in the Workplace (20 credits)
  • Professional Practice: Skills for Employment (20 credits)
  • Health, Welfare and Social Policy (20 credits)
  • Sociological Perspectives (20 Credits)
  • Developmental Psychological (20 credits)

Year 2

Core Modules:

  • Research in Social Issues (20 credits)
  • Psychology and Interactions (20 credits)
  • Applying Social Theory (20 credits)
  • Development through Work (20 credits)

Optional Modules* (choose 40 credits):

*Optional modules are subject to availability

  • Independent Study (20 credits)
  • The Sociology of Health (20 credits)
  • Perspectives on Disability & Learning Disability (20 credits)
  • Psychological Processes in Learning (20 credits)
  • Issues in mental Health (20 credits)
  • Social Enterprise (20 credits)
  • History of Western Political and Social Theory (20 credits)
  • Leadership Practice (20 credits)

 Year 3

Core Modules:

  • Health, Community and Social Sciences Dissertation (40 credits)

Optional Modules* (choose 80 credits):

*Optional modules are subject to availability

  • Promoting Health (20 credits)
  • Work-based Learning (40 credits)
  • Rural Poverty (20 credits)
  • Working with Young People (20 credits)
  • Youth justice (20 credits)
  • Alternative Interventions (20 credits)
  • Childcare and Mental Health (20 credits)
  • Collaboration and Multi-agency Working (20 credits)
  • Social and Political Identity (20 credits)
  • Psychology in Practice (20 credits)
course.dc:subject: Health, Social Work, Community, Mental Health, Welfare, Support Worker, Youth and Community and Nursing, access
Social Care & Health
course.dc:title: BSc (Hons) Health, Community and Social Sciences
course.abstract: The course has been designed with a number of pathways which will allow you to specialise within a particular area of study.
course.learningOutcome: Successful students can apply for relevant Masters level Programmes at another University or a PGCE Course here at Cornwall College or enter employment in appropriate fields such as local government, community development, teaching, youth justice, management, family support work, drug and alcohol rehabilitation, housing development and research. The degree will allow students to develop a number of graduate skills such as critical analysis, research, presentation skills and interpersonal skills which make them attractive to employers. The MA in Social Work at Plymouth University is an approved progression route subject to meeting the admissions criteria of Plymouth University. As a graduate you will have a wide choice of employment opportunities throughout the private and public sectors. The University of Plymouth Colleges enjoy a good record for the employability of their graduates. Career development and planning are supported in tutorials and the College Career Service is available for advice and support during the academic year. Cornwall College fosters links with relevant local agencies and the work based learning modules in years 1, 2 and 3 provide you with the opportunity to network, develop your skills and undertake work experience which is a vital part of gaining employment after a degree programme.
course.mlo:objective: Your programme of study will give you a firm grounding in the skills and knowledge needed for successful employment in the field as well as the academic rigour that you will continue to develop throughout your degree. The second and third years allow you to select optional modules which suit your career aspiration. In Year 2, for example, if you were interested in a career in Mental Health then you might choose the psychology and mental health based units such as Issues in Mental Health and Psychological Processes. An interest in Health may lead you to study Sociology of Health. You could choose to look at the Social Sciences and study Applying Social Theory and History of Western Political Theory. For students interested in Psychology, you may wish to choose Perspectives on Disability. In Year 3, modules are on offer to allow you to continue your interest in a particular pathway. For example, students interested in psychology and mental health may choose to study Childcare & Mental Health and/or Psychology in Practice and/or working with young people. Following an interest in Health, you may wish to study Promoting Health and/or Collaboration & Multiagency Working. Students interested in the Social Sciences may choose to study Youth Justice, and/or Social and Political Identity and/or Rural Poverty. This level of choice means that you can really make this programme work for you and the career that you want to enter.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
180 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 140 points must be at A2-level) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - MMP Grades required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3. Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language and mathematics: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 0845 22 32 567 or emailenquiries@cornwall.ac.uk.

A Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check will be a mandatory requirement after you have been accepted on the programme. It is your responsibility to undertake this before commencing your study.

UCAS Code: L510
Institution Code: CORN C78

This course offers an excellent opportunity for those considering a career in health and social care and provides a programme of study appropriate to a wide range of community, health, social care and education settings.

It is designed for people who wish to develop the skills and knowledge necessary to work with adults and children in these settings. The programme is appropriate for those who are already employed but wish to extend their knowledge, qualifications and career opportunities, as well as college leavers with an interest in working in health, care and community roles.

Module

Core

  • Sociological Perspectives (20 credits)
  • Psychological Perspectives of Development (20 credits)
  • Values & Ethics (20 credits)
  • Personal & Employability Skills Development (20 credits)

 Optional modules (choose two)

  • Social Enterprise & Social Entrepreneurship (20 credits)
  • Professional Practice: Skills for Health & Social Care (20 credits)
  • Legal aspects of Health, Social Care & Education (20 credits)
course.dc:subject: health and social care, community, community work, health and social, social care, social work, psycholoigisty, therapist, child psychologist,
The School of Education and Professional Development
course.dc:title: HNC Health and Community Studies
course.abstract: This course offers an excellent opportunity for those considering a career in health and social care
course.learningOutcome:
The HNC provides you with excellent opportunities for employment a wide range of community, health, social care and education settings.
 
Possible Further Study (subject to availability)
  • FdA Health & Community Studies final year at Cornwall College Camborne or St Austell
  • BSc (Hons) Health & Social Care second year at Cornwall College Camborne
  • BSc (Hons) Combined Social Science second year at Cornwall College Camborne
  • BSc (Hons) Social Work second year at Cornwall College Camborne plus Diploma in Social Work *
  • BSc (Hons) Community Work & Social Policy & Administration at Plymouth University plus Certificate of Assessed Practice * 
*At the discretion of the admissions tutor. 
 
Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression.  Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm) Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
ers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
All modules carry 20 credits and to achieve the HNC requires 120 credits. Some modules are jointly taught with other programmes, in particular the BSc (Hons) Combined Social Science. There are core modules, which you are required to study and a number of optional modules to choose from.

The optional modules will allow you to follow your own interests in working with specific settings: you will be given advice on which modules would be particularly relevant to you. In some of the modules you will be able to complete your assessment tasks by focusing your study on your preferred areas.

A variety of learning assessments are used: case studies, reports, essays, presentations, group work and timed assessments.

Support is offered through the college e-learning portal, were you can access academic and pastoral tutors.
course.mlo:prerequisite: 120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level, preferably in a related subject) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - PPP Grades required, specific unit grades may be required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3. Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language, mathematics and a science: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered. Mature applicants will be considered on their merits.

presentation.dc:subject: The School of Education and Professional Development
presentation.dc:title: HNC Health and Community Studies

course.abstract: designed for people to teaching Literacy and English up to Level 2
course.learningOutcome: The nationally endorsed qualification prepares you to work as a literacy subject specialist teacher or tutor.
course.mlo:objective: The Diploma in Teaching English (Literacy) is studied through attendance at weekly taught sessions.  As well as using Moodle, the College virtual learning environment, you will attend regular workshops to support your regular private study and reading.  You will also undertake 50 hours of teaching practice which will be observed on four occasions.  You will also need to complete a number of assignments reflecting your work on the course.
course.mlo:prerequisite: You must already be working, or have a commitment to working.  You must hold qualifications relevant to the subject you teach or have substantial relevant work experience.  Ideally, you will also hold Literacy qualifications at Level 3 or above and numeracy qualifications at Level 2 or above.

course.dc:description: This 2-year part-time course is ideal if you wish to become a professional counsellor, or if your job role contains a significant element of counselling. The course has been accredited by the British Association for Counselling and Psychotherapy (BACP).

• Modules

    Year 1
    •    Counselling Practice 1 (20 credits)
    •    Personal and Professional Development 1 (20 credits)
    •    Counselling Psychology 1 (20 credits)

Year 2

as above
course.dc:subject: diploma, counsellor, therapist, counseller, social work, community, social, social worker,
The School of Education and Professional Development
course.dc:title: Diploma in Person-Centred Counselling and Therapy
course.abstract: This 2-year part-time course is ideal if you wish to become a professional counsellor.
course.learningOutcome:
On successful completion of the programme you will be able to go on to work as a counsellor and after sufficient experience apply for BACP accreditation.

Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression. Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm) Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
The course contains an in-depth module on personal and professional development, as well as counselling practice, and counselling psychology modules. You will start to work with clients as a counsellor, practise and develop your counselling skills, develop your understanding of the counselling process and expand your ability to be in a professional relationship with your client. You will do this within a person-centred framework and in the second year you will visit other counselling models.

There are no exams: Assessment is through coursework and we use a self, peer and tutor assessment model. In addition to the course attendance you need to complete 100 supervised client hours over the two years within a placement setting.  It is your responsibility to secure a placement.  There is also a requirement to undertake personal therapy.

The programme contains 245 taught hours per year.  You will be expected to work with clients outside course hours, and to have an explicit counselling contract with them. It is probable that this will take place in a voluntary setting, and you will be encouraged to make contact with suitable agencies at an early date.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
At least 19 years of age plus a minimum level 2 certificate in Counselling Skills (min 75 hours not distance learning) and ideally a level 4 in Counselling Studies although this requirement may be met in other ways e.g. relevant experience with higher education credits.

Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 0845 22 32 567 or email enquiries@cornwall.ac.uk.

A Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check will be a mandatory requirement after you have been accepted on the programme. It is your responsibility to undertake this before commencing your study.

presentation.dc:subject: The School of Education and Professional Development
presentation.dc:title: Diploma in Person-Centred Counselling and Therapy

course.mlo:objective: To achieve the Certificate you must achieve four units covering the following topics: SEN policy and context, An Introduction to the Assessment of Learners with Dyslexia, Teaching Strategies, Planning and Delivery, Developing Practice.

Level 3 literacy and Level 2 numeracy skills are required to complete the course.

Places are given following an interview and course members are expected to attend all the taught course sessions.

course.dc:description: This course is normally taught over one morning, afternoon or evening a week for 12 weeks through venues in Camborne, St Austell, Saltash, Duchy Stoke Climsland and other centres throughout Cornwall.  For more information contact Sue Searle at the School of Education and Professional Development - 01209 617519  sue.searle@cornwall.ac.uk

This course is for those with an interest in developing their teaching skills.  You should have an idea of the subject/area you would like to teach and ideally hold qualifications or have relevant work experience in the subject you want to teach.

The Award in Education and training is designed for both people who need a nationally recognised training qualification to successfully deliver certain areas of their professional role and for those who might be considering a career in teaching or training but want to test the water before committing to a longer or more expensive course.

During the course you will participate in a range of activities designed to reflect the current methodology of student-centred teaching. You will learn how to engage difficult or unwilling students and how to ensure students reach their full potential through stimulating and motivating activity. You will understand how people learn and how to plan lessons accordingly. You will explore the limits of the teacher’s role and see how this goes beyond simple subject delivery. You will be enabled to design meaningful assessment activities, to avoid death by powerpoint and know how to include students with a wide range of learning preferences.
course.dc:subject: PGCE Cert Ed DTLLS CTLLS PTLLS Teaching Teacher Training Preparing to teach in the lifelong learning sector Award in Education and Training DET
The School of Education and Professional Development
course.dc:title: Education and Training CG Award Level 3
course.abstract: The Award in Education and Training Level 3
course.learningOutcome:
On completion of the course you will be in possession of a nationally recognised teaching / training qualification. You will have already covered much of the first module of the full-time teaching course and you will be in a position to know which areas of education or training you are most suited for.

Upon completion of this course you could use your skills in a variety of educational roles and continue your studying by taking a Certificate or Diploma in Teaching in the Lifelong Learning sector.
course.mlo:objective: This is a practical course introducing the skills, knowledge and understanding required by successful teachers and trainers in the Lifelong Learning sector.  You will explore Core teaching Skills, Personal Management, Management of Groups and Interpersonal Skills, all linked to ideas about theory and practice of post-compulsory teaching and training.
course.mlo:prerequisite: This course is for those with an interest in developing their teaching skills.  You should have an idea of the subject/area you would like to teach and ideally hold qualifications or have relevant work experience in the subject you want to teach.   The course requires written assignments and a candidate would benefit from holding English  and Mathematics qualifications at level 2 or above - (GCSE A*-C, Key Skills qualifications at level 2 or Adult English and Mathematics qualifications at Level 2).  Course members are expected to attend all the taught course sessions.

course.dc:description:
To achieve the full QCF Certificate in Assessing Vocational Achievement, all 3 units have to be achieved.  Please contact Elaine Hocking for further information on 01209 617671 or elaine.hocking@cornwall.ac.uk.

We offer 3 Course Intakes for this Academic year starting in October in Camborne, December in St Austell and in February in Camborne; please contact us for further information.

The course is for practitioners who need to be qualified to use all methods of assessment - i.e. those who will be carrying out the role of an assessor in a work environment and vocationally related situation (i.e. classroom/workshop/simulated environments). 

A full range of assessment methods must be used: - e.g. in a work environment: observation, examining work products, oral questioning and discussion, use of others (e.g.: witnesses), learner statements and recognition of prior learning (RPL); and in vocationally-related situations e.g. classrooms or workshops, assessment in simulated environments, skills tests, oral and written questions, assignments, projects, case studies and recognition of prior learning (RPL).
course.dc:subject: Assessor Assessing A1 TAQA Assessors
Cornwall College
course.dc:title: Assessing Vocational Achievement CG Certificate Level 3
course.abstract: Level 3 A level and Equivalent
course.learningOutcome: You will receive a Level 3 Certificate in Assessing Vocational Achievement from City & Guilds to confirm that you have achieved the Knowledge & Understanding Unit, the Assessing Competence in the Work Environment Unit and the Assessing Vocationally Related Achievement Unit.
course.mlo:objective:
A two day induction to the course will cover the background knowledge and understanding aspects of the Award and the assessor role you will be required to carry out.  You will continue to work with the Course Tutor through group/one-to-one support at subsequent sessions.

Within the Assessment Centre, you will work closely with at least two learners, through components of their qualification.  You will meet with your Course Tutor/Assessor regularly and build a portfolio of evidence.  You will also be required to work/liaise with other assessors and internal quality assurance staff at your Assessment Centre.
course.mlo:prerequisite: This will depend of the specific occupational area and the Award Sector Skills Council/Awarding Organisation Assessment Strategy; however, it is anticipated that occupational competence and experience of working within the sector may be required.  You will also need to be working with/attached to an Approved Assessment Centre that is offering the QCF/NVQ Award you are planning to assess and have two real learners to assess in a real work environment and assess in a simulated environment i.e. in a workshop or classroom.

course.dc:description:
To achieve the full QCF Certificate in Leading the Internal Quality Assurance of Assessment Processes and Practices, all 3 units have to be achieved. For further information please contact Elaine Hocking on 01209 617671 or by email elaine.hocking@cornwall.ac.uk.

We offer 3 Course Intakes for this Academic year starting in October in Camborne, December in St Austell and in February in Camborne; please contact us for further information.

This course is for practitioners who Lead the Internal Quality Assurance Process, within an Assessment Centre/Organisation; and have a responsibility for managing the quality of the assessment process, practice and the performance of Assessors.  They may also develop systems and lead on visits from outside agencies such as Awarding Organisations.
course.dc:subject: "Internal Verification" "Internal Verifier" IV V1 verifier verification IQA Verifiers
The School of Education and Professional Development
course.dc:title: Leading the Internal Quality Assurance of Assessment Processes and Practice CG Certificate Level 4
course.abstract: Internal Quality
course.learningOutcome: You will receive a Level 4 Certificate in Leading the Internal Quality Assurance of Assessment Processes and Practice from City & Guilds to confirm that you have achieved the Knowledge & Understanding Unit, the Internally Assure the Quality of Assessment Unit and the Plan, Allocate and Monitor Work in Own Area of Responsibility Unit.
course.mlo:objective:
A one day induction to the course will cover the background knowledge and understanding aspects of the Award and the role as the Lead Internal Quality Assurer (IQA) you will be required to carry out.  You will continue to work with the Course Tutor through group/one-to-one support at subsequent sessions.

Within the Assessment Centre, you will Lead the QA process and allocate work, within your own area of responsibility.  As an IQA you will also be required to work closely with at least two assessors, each with a minimum of two candidates of their own, through components of a qualification.  In your role as Lead IQA, you will also work with and co-ordinate with others from External Agencies i.e. Awarding Organisations, as well as meeting with your Course Tutor/Assessor regularly and build a portfolio of evidence.
course.mlo:prerequisite: This will depend of the specific occupational area and the Award Sector Skills Council/Awarding Organisation Assessment Strategy; however, it is anticipated that experience of working as a QCF/NVQ Assessor may be required.  Your role would also require a level of responsibility of Leading and Managing the QA process.

course.dc:description:
This is a three year part time modular course, devised by CHS and validated by the University of Plymouth, with years 1 and 2 incorporating the Chartered Institute of Housing's (CIH) Level 4 Certificate and Diploma in Housing. The programme is being offered by CHS as part of its range of blended learning courses for those working in housing.  If you meet the requirements of the course you will be awarded your foundation degree by the University of Plymouth and the Level 4 Certificate and Diploma by the CIH.

This Foundation Degree (FdA) provides an opportunity for those who work in all types of housing with support to advance both your personal and professional development and your academic development.  It is designed to enable you to develop the skills and knowledge you need to operate confidently in today’s challenging and rapidly changing professional climate.
course.dc:subject: Public Services
course.dc:title: FdA Housing With Support
course.abstract: This FdA is for those who work in all types of housing with support
course.learningOutcome: Completing the Foundation Degree successfully gives you opportunities to progress to the final stages of a full honours degree.  One such opportunity would be to progress to Plymouth University’s BSc (Hons) Public Services. Please note there is a deadline for progression applications.
course.mlo:objective: During the course you gain a broad knowledge of the social, cultural, environmental, economic, legal and political frameworks within which supported housing operates. You will be able to apply key service management principles and quality standards, including staff and performance management. You will also gain a knowledge of the trends within supported housing on an international level.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - PPP Grades required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3.  Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language and mathematics: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

Potential students must be prepared to be actively involved with the many practical opportunities whilst on the course.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 0845 22 32 567 or emailenquiries@cornwall.ac.uk

course.dc:description:
Ideal if: you would like a great foundation to your career in nail services.


You'll need: at least two GCSEs at grade C or above, in English & Mathematics, or an equivalent qualification.


You'll learn: excellent industry-level skills such as how to perform pedicures, manicures, nail art and  client consultations.


Expect: to be continually assessed throughout your course through practical assessments and examinations.


You'll love: the regular tutorials and demonstrations in our purpose-built salons.


You'll go on to: an apprenticeship or further studies at level 3 on our Nail Services Diploma.
course.dc:subject: Hair & Beauty
course.dc:title: Nail Technology Services CG Certificate Level 2
course.abstract: Nails
course.learningOutcome:
After successfully completing the course, you will have achieved the basic practical skills to allow you to work in industry.

However, it is always an advantage to offer as many different treatments as possible to your clients, so once you have achieved your Level 2, we would recommend that you enhance your knowledge base and develop your skills by progressing onto Level 3 Nail Technology Services, or diversify to Beauty Therapy or Hairdressing. These courses are all good options when you are considering up-skilling.

Once you have the right set of qualifications, they could take you all over the world. Past students have gone on to manage their own business, travel on cruise liners, work in the world of television or as session nail technicians at photographic shoots
course.mlo:objective:
You will be learning in our purpose-built salons, training in a commercial environment and learning nail service techniques from industry professionals. They will demonstrate everything that you need to know and you will then practice the skills that you have been shown on friends and family.
Eventually, you will be providing treatments to paying clients. From consultations to pedicure, manicure and nail arttreatments. You will be trained to industry standards.
You will also have the opportunity to develop your work-based skills, working on the salon reception, promoting products and practicing retail services.
Regular tutorials and demonstrations from teaching staff will embed your knowledge, giving you the confidence to practice nail services in paid employment.

Assessments are carried out during practical lessons on paying clients along with some on-line testing.
If you are 16-19 you will continue to develop your skills of Maths, English, Employability and Work Experience as a part of your study program.


This course provides a great foundation for a career as a nail technician.
You will be preparing for industry and are looking to get a good grounding in nail services. This qualification will provide you with the essential salon skills to help you get employed in the industry.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
You will need to have a minimum of 2 GCSEs at grade c, in English and Maths or an equivalent qualification.

At Cornwall College, we recognise that applicants can often offer a high level of competence as well as life experience and we will therefore consider all applications on their merits alongside their qualifications.

If you are unsure as to whether or not you meet the requirements, please call the Hairdressing and Beauty Department and ask to speak to the course manager who will be happy to discuss it with you.

course.dc:description:
This course is an ideal start if you are thinking about pursuing a career in the beauty therapy industry as an apprentice.

As part of your course you will study the following practical elements: facial treatments, eye treatments, hand/foot and nail treatments, waxing treatments, make-up treatments, in addition to science, theory, health and safety and working within a team.

You will train in our purpose-built salons which reflect a commercial environment providing treatments to paying clients. All treatments are provided at industry standards and reflect current trends.

Assessments are carried out during practical lessons along with some on-line testing.
course.dc:subject: Beauty, therapist, beautician, hair and beauty, aromatherapy, complementary therapy, massage, reflexology, spa therapy, make-up, treatments, tinting, manicures, facials, waxing, eyelash and brow treatments,
Hair & Beauty
course.dc:title: Beauty Therapy CG NVQ Diploma Level 2
course.abstract: uty Therapy CG NVQ Diploma Level 2
course.learningOutcome:
Cornwall College offers the complete pathway in Beauty Therapy and you could take your qualifications all over the world. Past students have gone on go on to managing their own salon, travel on cruise liners and teach. There are a number of opportunities available to you once you have the right set of qualifications; from beauty therapist or consultant to image and department advisor, merchandiser or product promoter.

No single qualification covers all of the different services offered by a beauty therapist so once you have achieved your level 2, we would recommend that you develop your specialist skills by progressing onto other courses at Cornwall College.
Beauty Therapy Techniques CG Diploma Level 3, Massage CG NVQ 3, Complimentary Therapy Techniques, Spa Therapy or a Nail Services course are all good options when you are considering up skilling.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
You will need to be employed in the workplace as an apprentice and have a minimum of 2 GCSEs in English and Maths.

 

At Cornwall College, we recognise that applicants without these qualifications can often offer a high level of competence as well as life experience and we will therefore consider all applications on their merits alongside their qualifications.

 

If you are unsure as to whether or not you meet the requirements, please call the Beauty Department and ask to speak to the course manager who will be happy to discuss it with you.

course.dc:description: Spa Therapy consists of non-medical treatments which help with the overall health of the body. If you are involved in massage, stone therapy, hydrotherapy, body wrapping and floatation treatments and you would like a qualification to demonstrate your specialist skills, or you have worked in a salon, spa or similar job for some time and have gained your level 2 beauty therapy/nail services qualification, this course may be for you.
course.dc:subject: spa beauty apprenticeship beauty therapy spa treatments progression advanced apprenticeship level 3 spa NVQ in spa treatments
Hair & Beauty
course.dc:title: Spa Therapy CG NVQ Diploma Level 3
course.abstract: spa, beauty, apprenticeship, therapy, treatments, progression,
course.learningOutcome: Afterwards, you may use your new qualification to gain employment in a resort, destination spa, day spa or beauty salon. Opportunities exist in the UK as well as overseas for this fast growing industry. You may move into management or become a trainer, lecturer or a company field technician.
course.mlo:objective:
Students on this course also get to develop their work based skills; recognising the importance of professional practice. You will be involved with induction, consultation, treatment care and advice, as well as tailoring aftercare advice to individual clients.

Our tutors are industry professionals and they will demonstrate the practical techniques as well as best practice so that you can be sure that you are equipped with the skills and know-how to perform these treatments independently.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
There are no formal entry requirements for this course. However, a level 2 qualification in beauty therapy or nail services is an advantage. As with all beauty professions, you will need to create the right impression with your clients and must therefore be professional, courteous and discreet.  Excellent communication skills are essential.

This is an intensive, knowledge-based course and we do look for enthusiasm and motivation to succeed on the course.

If you are unsure as to your suitability for this course, please contact the Course Manager at the College who will be happy to discuss the course and its content with you.

course.dc:description:
Progress onto level 6 (top-up) via an approved Plymouth University honours degree progression route: BA (Hons) Early Childhood Studies.  Other progression routes are available at Plymouth University, including part-time courses in early years and FLECS (Flexible Learning in Early Childhood Studies) where as an undergraduate you will be expected to become an ‘independent learner’ and take responsibility for your own learning.  More information can be found on: http://www1.plymouth.ac.uk/courses/undergraduate/2056/Pages/FLECS/Welcome-to-FLECS.aspx

Progress onto level 6 (top up) at Cornwall College: BA (Hons) Curriculum and Education

Progress onto a Post Graduate Certificate in Education (PGCE) teaching qualification. You will be required to complete vocational practice for the duration of the course in an early years setting (0 – 8 years), this may be paid or on a voluntary basis. 

Students have the option of completing FREE G.C.S.E. qualifications in English and Mathematics as part of programme.

Bursaries and grants are available – see Student Finance / Tuition Fees pages of our website for details.

This course is for people over the age of 18, who are interested in pursuing a career working within the early years sector.  It is anticipated that applicants will be seeking a qualification which will facilitate the opportunity to explore a wide range of career options, which may include those who wish to choose a career in education, primary teaching, early years practitioner or management.  It is particularly suitable for people who are currently in employment, paid or voluntary and who would like to study a full time course over one day per week.  The course is essentially the first two years of a degree course, the third year can be completed as a top-up course in order to obtain a full degree or honours degree.  UCAS Code: XL35
Institution Code: CORN C78

This course is for people over the age of 18, who are interested in pursuing a career working within the early years sector.  It is anticipated that applicants will be seeking a qualification which will facilitate the opportunity to explore a wide range of career options, which may include those who wish to choose a career in education, primary teaching, early years practitioner or management.  It is particularly suitable for people who are currently in employment, paid or voluntary and who would like to study a full time course over one day per week.  The course is essentially the first two years of a degree course, the third year can be completed as a top-up course in order to obtain a full degree or honours degree.

Modules

Year 1

  •  Social Science (20 credits)
  • Developmental Perspectives (20 credits)
  • Personal & Employability Skills Development (20 credits)
  • Risk versus Challenge in the Outdoors (20 credits)
  • Values & Ethics (20 credits)
  • New Learning Technologies (20 credits)

 Year 2

Core

  • Independent Study Module (20 credits)
  • Special Needs (20 credits)
  • Early Intervention (20 credits)
  • Social Policy (20 credits)
  • Early Years Practice (20 credits)

 Optional (choose one)

  • Parents & Families (20 credits)
  • Cognitive Development (20 credits)
  • Numeracy and Literacy (20 credits)
  • The Child as an individual (20 credits)

Progress onto level 6 (top-up) via an approved Plymouth University honours degree progression route: BA (Hons) Early Childhood Studies.  Other progression routes are available at Plymouth University, including part-time courses in early years and FLECS (Flexible Learning in Early Childhood Studies) where as an undergraduate you will be expected to become an ‘independent learner’ and take responsibility for your own learning.  More information can be found on: http://www1.plymouth.ac.uk/courses/undergraduate/2056/Pages/FLECS/Welcome-to-FLECS.aspx

 

Progress onto level 6 (top up) at Cornwall College: BA (Hons) Curriculum and Education

 

Progress onto a Post Graduate Certificate in Education (PGCE) teaching qualification.
course.mlo:objective: The course will include completing a variety of modules, which cover many elements of early years development.  The modules are designed to equip you with the skills and knowledge required for effective progression within the early years sector.  The activities are varied and interesting and develop both content knowledge in early years, and enable you also to develop personal skills, for example, presentation and communication skills and other transferable skills which are essential for your future employability.  The activities range from first-hand experience of the legal process, experience and development of Forest School skills, and opportunities to develop creative arts skills through practical activities.  These rich and varied experiences will form the basis of your assignments, which range from written essay, peer and self-assessment through to portfolios, case studies and presentations.  You will be allocated a personal tutor who you are encouraged to liaise with throughout the course ensuring you are supported and your personal learning needs are closely met.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
Ideally students should hold a level 3 qualification.  This could include BTEC /CACHE Diploma in a related subject, NVQ at level 3 in early years or a teaching assistant NVQ at level 3, or 2 A levels or an Access to Higher Education course.  However, mature students with relevant academic and practical experience within the sector are welcome to apply and entry will be dependent on a successful interview.  As this is a full time foundation degree course, applicants are required to apply through UCAS.


120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - PPP Grades required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3. Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language and mathematics: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.


Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.


Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 0845 22 32 567 or email enquiries@cornwall.ac.uk.


A Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check will be a mandatory requirement after you have been accepted on the programme. It is your responsibility to undertake this before commencing your study.

course.dc:description:
This course is delivered at various sites.

In order to obtain this qualification, you must attend both days and complete the two units of accreditation.

This course is for those who are working with children and infants. It will be of particular interest to teachers, child minders, crèche assistants, playgroup personnel and anyone else who has a responsibility for their welfare whilst in your care.

It is ideal for individuals who are responsible for children and infants, who wish to gain a nationally accredited Level 3 Award.

In order to obtain this qualification, you must attend both days and complete the two units of accreditation. You will be gaining knowledge and competence to administer administer first aid and basic life support.
course.dc:subject: Paediatric First Aid 2 day course
course.dc:title: Paediatric First Aid FAA Award Level 3 (2 Day)
course.learningOutcome:
CERTIFICATION

Assessment is ongoing by the instructor in respect of the student’s practical skills and there will be multiple choice question paper to answer in respect of their knowledge.


A three year certificate will be issued, subject to assessment.
course.mlo:objective:
Unit 1

  • Responsibilities and reporting; Resuscitation; Wounds and bleeding; Minor injuries; Infection control; Anaphylaxis; Shock; Eplilepsy; First Aid; Dealing with an unresponsive casualty; Assessment of the situation; Choking; Recovery position
     

Unit 2

  • Head injuries; Fractures; Febrile convulsions; Ear, eye and nose injuries; Electrical injuries; Sickel cell anaemia; Diabetes; Foreign bodies; Burns and scalds; Meningitis; Asthma; Heat and cold; Bites and stings; Poisoning
course.mlo:prerequisite:
Learners must be 16 years or older

In order to obtain this qualification, you must attend both days and complete the two units of accreditation.

This course is ideal for adults who would like to return to education but lack either the skill or the confidence to take on a Level 3 course. This 20 week (Level 2) course will prepare you for further education, giving you confidence in your written work and presentation skills. Advice will be given on your best progression route to reach your chosen goal, using careers guidance and by giving you opportunities to explore all the options available to you.

.

On the Progression course you will have the opportunity to get support with your studies; you will be able to recieve support from a range of people and facilities. These include support from the learning resource centre; this could include support with accessing resources and using ICT to support and help facilitate your learning.

Some applicants may be eligible for financial support on this course to assist with childcare, transport etc. The Learner Support Fund is under review and is determined by individual circumstances.

Our Multi Options programme is made up of a series of study programmes in different curriculum areas, aimed at students aged 16-19 who are undecided about their future choices, and would like to try a number of options before making a decision. Students will be able to pick from a variety of vocational subjects including:

  • Public Services

  • Sport
  • Travel and Tourism

Maths and English are compulsory parts of the study programme for learners who have not achieved GCSE grade Cs in English or Maths.

Employability skill are also delivered directly and discreetly through all aspects of the curriculum in order to develop the skills that will aim to make a learner 'work ready'.

course.dc:description:
Some applicants may be eligible for financial support on this course to assist with childcare, transport etc. The Learner Support Fund is under review and is determined by individual circumstances.

If you are under 24 years of age, you may be eligible for fee remission. Information will be given within the workshops, however if your require more information contact the college your applying for and speak to one of the administration tutors for further details.

If you are 24 years of age  or over, please click on this link for funding information and a direct link to the government funding site.

Funding for over 24

Access courses are designed as a stepping stone to enable motivated, enthusiastic people to progress on to Higher Education. This is ideal for those who want to re-train or re-direct their lives to realise their dreams of working professionally in the health and social care sector.  You will receive high quality teaching by subject specialists in a range of subject areas that will fully prepare you for studying at university level.  The course is challenging and requires full attendance and absolute commitment to allow you to fully maximise your opportunities; you will though have access to a range of support mechanisms to enable you to develop the key academic competencies to contribute towards successful progression.

How do you study?

You will timetabled for 2 days a week over a 35 week period, with sessions running from 9am until 4.30pm.  The units that you will study will come from the core subject area, and are detailed in the more info box.  These can be achieved at a Pass, Merit or Distinction Level.  Along with your core subject units, you will study a range of subjects that build and prepare you for academic study at university level, such as: Developing Your Research Skills, Academic Writing and Examination Techniques & Practices.  Overall, you will complete 20 units which correlate to 60 credits for full achievement of the Access to HE Diploma.

 

Help and support

Cornwall College, Saltash has a justifiably enviable reputation for the level of pastoral care and academic support that their students receive.  You will have a dedicated personal tutor who will support your learning journey throughout the academic year, and you will be given a great deal of support in preparing your UCAS application and personal statement.  The Learning Centre team also offer support to students; this can include advice on accessing resources online, proof reading work, and general study support advice.  We also have a dedicated team to help support your success such as: Rachael Allin, our over 19's Careers Advisor, as well as an informed Student Services team and Administrators who are happy to help you with understanding course fees,  FE bursaries, childcare and transport queries.   If necessary, they will refer to you services outside of their remit to ensure your time at Cornwall College, Saltash is a stress free as possible.

 

Access to HE - Health and Social Care (Nursing Pathway) is a nationally recognised qualification which gives students the opportunity of applying to university for a range of health care sector pathways, such as: Adult Nursing, Mental Health Nursing, Children's Nursing, Midwifery, Occupational Therapy, Paramedicine, Operating Department Practitioner, Podiatry etc.  Please be advised that each university stipulates its own entry requirements and you are advised to ensure you research these fully prior to application on the Access course.

You will be developing key academic competencies to underpin your undergraduate journey in your chosen profession.  You will be expected to attend 100% of the modular sessions and develop excellent communication skills through class based discussions, group work, objective and analytical written work and presentations demonstrating a high level of autonomy in your approach to your studies.

On the access course you will have the opportunity to get support with your academic studies; you will be able to recieved support for a range of people and facilities. these include support from the learning resource centre; this could include support with accessing resources and using ICT to support and help facilitate your learning. You will also recieve tutor support with your UCAS application as well as  opportunities for support during some of the colleges holidays.

Some applicants may be eligible for financial support on this course to assist with childcare, transport etc. The Learner Support Fund is under review and is determined by individual circumstances.

If you are under 24 years of age, you may be eligible for fee remission. Information will be given within the workshops, however if your require more information contact the college your applying for and speak to one of the administration tutors for further details.

If you are 24 years of age  or over, please click on this link for funding information and a direct link to the government funding site.

Funding for over 24
