course.dc:title: Nursing, Health and Social Care AptEd Access to HE Diploma Level 3 (E)
course.abstract: Access to HE is a nationally recognised qualification which provides you with access to university study.
course.mlo:assessment: You will be assessed in a variety ways including essays, reports, presentations and observations. You will not be asked to take exams.
course.learningOutcome: Access programmes are specially designed to prepare students for entry into Higher Education and provide the underpinning knowledge and skills needed to progress to a degree or diploma course at college or university. This will provide you with the entry requirements for a range of health degrees including; Adult Nursing, Child Nursing, Midwifery, Physiotherapy etc.
course.mlo:objective:
The Access to Health and Wellbeing course is run over a period of 35 weeks, two evenins per week (5.30pm-8.30pm) and one full day per week, 9.00am-4.30pm. This is a challenging course and it is expected that students will complete a minimum of 15 hours of independent study each week. Students may access college facilities on the days that they are not taught with some evening study available.Please also be advised that most universities require work experience to complement your UCAS application-therefore it is highly recommended that you are working within the health care sector in either a voluntary or paid capacity.


The course is made up of the following subjects; Study Skills ,  Psychology, Sociology, Social Policy,  Biology.  You will also be given advice on writing a personal statement and completing a UCAS application . If you require, and do not already have, GCSEs in Maths and English you will be given the opportunity to take these alongside your main diploma (subject to entry requirements).
course.mlo:prerequisite: All applicants will be invited to attend an Access Workshop where full course information is given and you will be expected to complete the Initial Assessment and a written exercise.  At the same time,  an appointment with Rachael Allin,  our Careers Advisor so that you are fully aware of all the options available to you, and make an informed choice of pathway appropriate to your ultimate career aim.

course.dc:description: Access courses are designed as a stepping stone to enable motivated, enthusiastic people to progress on to Higher Education. This is ideal for those who want to re-train or re-direct their lives into forensic science, marine science, chemistry, biology, sustainable construction, renewable energy, sport science, radiology, medical physics, and many other science related university courses. There is a very high level of academic and personal support throughout the course, which can help if you need to combine study with part-time employment and family commitments.
Attendance at the College is required two days per week for one year. Assessment is principally by assignment, although there are also timed tests and at least one extended piece of coursework.

You will be given a personal tutor for the duration of this course with additional support from student services, 1-2-1 tuition if required and research assisstance in our Learning Services department. Help will be given with your UCAS and funding application.

course.dc:description:
Access courses are designed as a stepping stone to enable motivated, enthusiastic people to progress on to Higher Education. This is ideal for those who want to re-train or re-direct their lives into Health professions such as: Chiropodists/podiatrists,;Dietitians; Occupational therapists;
orthoptists; orthotists; Paramedics; Physiotherapists; Prosthetists; Radiographers; Speech and language therapists; as well as Sports Science professions and many other science related careers. There is a very high level of academic and personal support throughout the course, which can help if you need to combine study with part-time employment and family commitments.

Help and support

We also support you through the university application process with tutorials. These are designed to offer guidance and support throughout the learning process.

We do however recommend checking the entry requirements for your course at your preferred university

What will I do on the course?

Attendance at the College is required three days per week for one year. You will study a range of units at level 3 (equivalent to A level). Each unit is worth 3 credits. For successful completion of the access course you will need 60 credits overall. The 60 credits are made up of 45 credits from academic subject subject areas and 15 credits from academic preparation units, which are designed to prepare you for academic study at university level.

How will I be assessed?

Assessment will take the form of coursework, presentations or in class assessments depending on the unit you are studying.

Entry Requirements

All applicants will be invited to attend a workshop where you will find out about how Access to HE courses are structured at Saltash and during which you will you will undertake the College initial assessment to assess your suitablility to study at this level. This will be followed by an  interview where full course information is given and you will be expected to complete an Initial Assessment

Applicants who do not hold a GCSE in mathematics or English at grade C or above will be expected to gain these qualifications before or alongside their Access studies. The opportunity to achieve these qualifications will be provided.

What can I do after the course?

An Allied Health Professions Access to HE Diploma course is a suitable entrance qualification for the many health science based degrees in Plymouth, Cornwall and throughout the country. It is also a recognised qualification that can help you gain entry into the workplace.

Several of our students progress to Plymouth University, other Universitties across the country or have continued their studies at Cornwall College, selecting courses from within with our range of foundation degrees. These include programmes at our Camborne, Newquay, St Austell, Falmouth Marine School, Duchy College, Stoke Climsland and Rosewarne sites.

For more info on foundation degrees available at Cornwall College, just click on this link

You
will attend college, three days per week from 9.00am until 4.30pm over 35
weeks. If you already have GCSEs in English and Maths (C grade or higher) then
you will attend from 10.30am-3.00pm on two if these days.

Some applicants may be eligible for financial support on this course to assist with childcare, transport etc. The Learner Support Fund is under review and is determined by individual circumstances.

course.dc:description:
Access to HE courses are delivered over 35 weeks, 2 days per week from 9.00am-4.30pm. Students are recommended to commit to the same number of hours each week for home study. Below are a list of units that are on offer, however, this is not fixed and students wishing to progress on to teaching will be offered units in teaching practice and placement. Applicants can take GCSE English and/or Maths however, if students already posess these at C grade or higher they will be excused from these sessions.

Students will study a range of 20 Academic (ASC) and Study Skills (APS) units. These will include;

Research, Academic Writing, Creative Writing, Linguistics, History of English Language, Poetry, English for Academic Purposes plus many more. Students wishing to progress on to teaching can study two Education units as entry requiements for B.Ed and other teaching degrees.
You will attend college, two days per week from 9.00am until 4.30pm over 35 weeks. It is expected that students dedicate the same number of hours per week to home study.
A full support package is available for this course.

course.mlo:objective: On this course you will study a wide range of subjects relating to English, Literature and Creative writing. You will meet with visiting professional authors, participate with the 'page to stage' process of creating a drama from original writings and attend plays relating to your course content where possible. You will be taught by specialist teachers including Study Skills which prepares you for the use if harvard and academic writing generally.

course.dc:description:
This course is a 20 credit module (CORC170) from a Foundation Degree, awarded by Plymouth University.

Contact us for more information.

This course is for anyone who wishes to improve business processes in your organisation. You will address a work based problem/issue within your organisation and develop a good systems- based analysis.
course.dc:subject: lean service management dlsc degree level short courses lean services systems event planing uop university of plymouth plymouth university
Business, Administration & Law
course.dc:title: Lean Service Management
course.learningOutcome:
Upon successful completion, you will have the confidence to use your improved business processing skills in your organisation.

There are several flexible progression opportunities for delegates onto other performance boosting degree level short courses, including: People development and leadership; Business enterprise, leadership and growth; Finance for non-financial managers and many more. Training at all levels and in a range of subjects is available through Cornwall College Business.
course.mlo:objective:
This course introduces a range of lean concepts for analysis and improvement of business processes. It focuses on how and why different work activities take place to achieve an end value, while questioning aspects of the work environment from value and structure to management approach.

This course covers:

  • Systems analysis using Vanguard and other models to understand real business processes in a systems context
  • Core lean concepts of value, value stream, flow, pull and incremental continuous improvement
  • Value stream planning and continuous improvement A3 style project management
  • Change management issues.

There will be a number of tutorial and group sessions to support your analysis and project work. You will be assessed according to your systems analysis, project plan and presentation of project implementation. In practice real projects are not always completed within the timescale, so you may present your project in its current status.

There will be a short test at the end of the module.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements for this course.

course.dc:description:
Ideal if: you have experience of working in a kitchen and woud like to learn advanced skills in preparing and cooking complex dishes, store keeping and supervisory skills.

You'll need: the City & Guilds Level 2 Diploma in Food Preparation and Production or are working in a first-class establishment. Equally, you can be a mature student who has the right drive and commitment to succeed and who wants to achieve a nationally recognised qualification.

You'll learn: how to increase your key skills in a specialised area.  Being a very practical course in its approach, the content allows you to learn advanced techniques that meet both national and international standards. 

Expect: to be assessed throughout your course through assignments, projects and practical examinations.

You'll love: learning the techniques you will need to have, to work as a specialised chef in a professional kitchen.

You'll go onto: employment in the industry, or further studies at Foundation Degree level.

course.dc:title: Culinary Skills CG Diploma Level 3
course.abstract: Earn a Level 3 qualification whilst working in the industry
course.mlo:assessment: You'll be assessed throughout your course through assignments, projects and practical examinations.
course.learningOutcome: After successfully completing the NVQ 3 and with sufficient industry experience you will have the opportunity to progress onto a Foundation Degree. This qualification will also enable you to apply for positions in first class establishments with the knowledge that the qualification will enhance your job prospects.
course.mlo:objective:
The course is designed for students with a basic knowledge of cookery and who wish to increase their skills in a specialised area. It is very practical in content and allows the students to learn advanced techniques that will meet both national and international standards. The course is designed to be completed in 1 year and the units covered may be different depending on which site you choose to study at.

NVQ3 Advanced food preparation and cooking ( Kitchen larder)

  • Principles of food preparation and cooking
  • Functional skills
  • ERR
  • CIEH level 3 food safety award
  • Sustainability in Professional Kitchens level 3
  • Food science and molecular cookery
  • Menu planning and food costing
  • Allergen training
  • Butchery work shop
  • Fish and shell fish work shop
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements. However, because of the advanced nature of the course it is advisable that you are either the holder of NVQ level-2 Food Preparation and Production or City and Guilds 706/1 and 706/2 or are already working in a first class establishment. Equally, you can be a mature student who may never have attended college and would like to gain a nationally recognised qualification. In all cases real enthusiasm for the industry and a love of food is vital.

course.dc:description:
The Day release course begins in September 2012.

For those who already hold a 6129 technical certificate there is no specific entry date, you can start when it suits both yourself and your employer. You have up to two years to complete this.   Funding is available for some apprentices, however you may need to achieve key skills at level two in maths, English and ICT as part of the programme. 

For people that are not on an apprenticeship scheme there currently is no funding available.

If you require any further information and confirmation on course costs or funding options please contact us.

This course is aimed at anyone currently working in the industry as a plumber or heating engineer.

This will be studied on a one day a week, day release basis with performance units completed in the workplace.  For candidates who have previously completed the 6129 technical certificate and are now working in the industry, you will be assessed only in the workplace and will not need to attend college.

course.dc:description: In this class there will be yoga posture and breathing exercises.  The class starts and finishes with relaxation

Yoga courses are open to everyone: improve your health and sense of well-being through the practice of Hatha Yoga, the science of health. Students are asked to bring a blanket or sleeping bag and wear loose clothing and a warm sweater.

In this class there will be yoga posture and breathing exercises.  The class starts and finishes with relaxation

Jane Housley-Jeive, Dip DSY, is our yoga teacher on Yoga, Practice & Understanding course here at Saltash.  Read more about Jane..............

I am passionate about Yoga.  I took my first lessons in 1997 and have been practicing ever since, studying different styles with a variety of teachers.  Between 2006 and 2008 I undertook a teacher training course with the Devon School of Yoga, qualifying in 2008.  

Since qualifying I have held a regular weekly class in Saltash and regularly attend workshops with the Devon School and other teachers.  In 2012 and 2013 I went to the Devon Yoga Festivals and experienced many different styles.  I have also been to workshops on the chakras (energy centres) and meditation with Swami Saradananda.

 I’m a firm believer that yoga is for everyone, not just the body beautiful.   In fact, I think that the less flexible can probably get more benefit from yoga than the more supple.   Postures can be modified to suit all abilities, including those unable to stand for long – so long as you can breathe you can do yoga! 

 My style is eclectic, taking the best from all my teachers.  Each class includes postures, breathing, a short meditation and relaxation.
course.dc:subject: yoga hatha vinyasa flow iyengar relaxation stress
Sport

course.mlo:objective: This is an ongoing programme of Yoga for relaxation of body and soul.

course.dc:description:
Term One of this course is ideal for those people who have no or little French language skills.

Term Two of this course would be ideally suited to students who have recently completed the Term One course but would be of equal value to people who have previously completed some formal study or have a grasp of the French language who wish to refresh and further develop and build on their language skills.
course.dc:subject: Cornwall College
course.dc:title: French - Beginners (JE)
course.abstract: Learn how to speak French.
course.learningOutcome: You can try one of our other language courses or any of our other recreational courses or workshops.
course.mlo:objective:
Term One will be structured in a simple and easy to understand format with a specific topic being covered each session. The course is friendly and fun, with an emphasis on participation by all students. Your tutor will assume you have no previous knowledge. You will learn basic spoken language for everyday situations, for pleasure, business, or for socialising.

Term Two will be more student led in order to control the pace and allow time to further develop and build confidence.   Students will be involved in a number of activities such as introducing yourself, describing your family, your job, shopping, ordering meals, booking accommodation, asking directions, dislikes and likes etc.

course.dc:description:
This course is designed for people with a strong interest in biology and the environment who would like to develop their scientific skills and knowledge before progressing to higher level qualifications or to employment in the applied biology sector. You will study a range of modules covering the development of laboratory management, applied scientific skills, biology and ecology. As part of your HND studies you will design and carry out a research project in which you will investigate a topic of your choice.

The HNC / HND programmes at The Cornwall College Group help you to develop a range of skills and techniques, personal qualities and attributes that are essential for successful progression to employment in scientific industries. The courses are taught in well-equipped laboratories with small group sizes and an exceptional degree of academic tutorial support. They provide opportunities for learners to focus on the development of higher level skills in a science and technological context.

Successful completion of the HND Applied Biology to a good standard provides evidence that you have obtained the skills and knowledge to work in a laboratory environment or progress onto BSc studies.

The HND Applied Biology has been designed in collaboration with employers in the UK STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Maths) sector and is endorsed by the Society of Biology.
course.dc:subject: Science
course.dc:title: HND in Applied Biology (Subject to Approval)
course.abstract: HND in Applied Biology
course.learningOutcome:
Upon successful completion of the HND course you could progress directly into employment or onto one of several BSc top-up degrees either within The Cornwall College Group (for example BSC (Hons) Environmental Resource Management) or at another UK Higher Education Institution. Progression to BSc allows you to achieve a full honours degree.

HND programmes are well respected by employers as evidence that candidates have developed a high standard of practical and analytical techniques suitable for working in scientific and technical roles, for example as a laboratory manager, quality control technician, research assistant or analyst.
course.mlo:objective:
HND Applied Biology (*HNC modules)

Level 4 Modules
• *Analysis of Scientific Data and Information
• Laboratory Management
• Quality Assurance and Quality Control
• Management of Projects
• *Cell Biology
• *Physiology of Cellular Systems in Animals
• *Laboratory Techniques for Applied Biology
• *Ecological Principles and their Application

Level 5 Modules
• Project for Applied Science
• Environmental Monitoring and Analysis
• Environmental Management and Conservation
• Statistics for Experimental Design
• Biodiversity, Conservation and Threats
• *Plant Physiology and Environmental Adaptation
• *Applied Genetics of Industry, Agriculture and Medicine
• *Biochemistry of Macromolecules and Metabolic Pathways
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level, preferably in a science subject) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma achieved at a minimum of PPP. Access to HE Diplomas - minimum of 45 credits at Level 3. Applicants will usually also possess GCSEs at grade C or above in English language, maths and science with alternatives at Level 2 considered.

 

Who is this course for?

People with a passion for biology and the environment and the desire to progress to higher level science study or employment in the STEM sector. You may have recently completed study at Level 3, you may be an adult learner returning to education to facilitate a career change or you may be applying from within the European Union and wish to study in the UK.


Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.


Applicants from European countries outside of the United Kingdom are also encouraged to apply with equivalent qualifications considered. Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 0845 22 32 567 or email enquiries@cornwall.ac.uk

course.dc:description:
This course is designed for people with a strong interest in chemistry and the environment who would like to develop their scientific skills and knowledge before progressing to higher level qualifications or to employment in the applied and analytical chemistry sector. You will study a range of modules covering the development of laboratory management, applied scientific skills, chemistry and environmental science. As part of your HND studies you will design and carry out a research project in which you will investigate a topic of your choice.

The HNC / HND programmes at The Cornwall College Group help you to develop a range of skills and techniques, personal qualities and attributes that are essential for successful progression to employment in scientific industries. The courses are taught in well-equipped laboratories with small group sizes and an exceptional degree of academic tutorial support. They provide opportunities for learners to focus on the development of higher level skills in a science and technological context.

Successful completion of the HND Applied Chemistry to a good standard provides evidence that you have obtained the skills and knowledge to work in a laboratory environment, for example as a chemical technologist, or progress onto BSc studies.

The HND Applied Chemistry has been designed in collaboration with employers in the UK STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Maths) sector and offers a progression route to the professional qualifications offered by the Royal Society of Chemistry.
course.dc:subject: Cornwall College
course.dc:title: HND in Applied Chemistry (Subject to Approval)
course.abstract: HND in Applied Chemistry
course.learningOutcome:
Upon successful completion of the HND Applied Chemistry you could progress directly into employment or onto one of several BSc top-up degrees either within The Cornwall College Group (for example BSC (Hons) Environmental Resource Management) or at another UK Higher Education Institution. Progression to BSc allows you to achieve a full honours degree.

 HND programmes are well respected by employers as evidence that candidates have developed a high standard of practical and analytical techniques suitable for working in scientific and technical roles, for example as a laboratory manager, quality control technician, environmental, analytical or service chemist.
course.mlo:objective:
HND Applied Chemistry (*HNC modules)

• *Analysis of Scientific Data and Information
• Laboratory Management
• Quality Assurance and Quality Control
• Management of Projects
• *Inorganic Chemistry
• *Organic Chemistry
• *Physical Chemistry
• *Chemical Laboratory Techniques


Level 5 Modules

• Project for Applied Science
• Environmental Monitoring and Analysis
• Environmental Management and Conservation
• Statistics for Experimental Design
• *Organic Chemistry of Aromatic and Carbonyl Compounds
• *Inorganic Chemistry of Crystal Structures and Transition Metal Complexes
• *Medicinal Chemistry
• Analytical Chemistry
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level, preferably in a science subject) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma achieved at a minimum of PPP. Access to HE Diplomas - minimum of 45 credits at Level 3. Applicants will usually also possess GCSEs at grade C or above in English language, maths and science with alternatives at Level 2 considered.


Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.


Applicants from European countries outside of the United Kingdom are also encouraged to apply with equivalent qualifications considered.
Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 0845 22 32 567 or email enquiries@cornwall.ac.uk


Who is this course for?

People with a passion for chemistry, laboratory practical and analytical techniques and data! You will usually also wish to progress to higher level science study or employment in the STEM sector. You may have recently completed study at Level 3, you may be an adult learner returning to education to facilitate a career change or you may be applying from within the European Union and wish to study science in the UK.

course.dc:description:
With the worldwide demand for IT specialists increasing year on year, being able to study a degree in computing in Cornwall is a real opportunity. It's a fast-moving subject and graduates are eminently employable. 

The programme is designed as a 1 year top-up to the FdSc Computing, Networking & Software Development programme offered at Cornwall College. It offers development and in depth study in the field of evolving computing technologies and also gives you the opportunity to further your specialisation in either the field of networking or software development. The preparation of study for vendor certifications alongside the academic qualification ensures you will meet the needs of industry.
course.dc:subject: Information & Communication Technology
course.dc:title: BSc (Hons) Computing Technologies (Top-up)
course.abstract: The worldwide demand for IT specialists increases year on year.
course.mlo:assessment: Assessment is by means of written reports, presentations, case studies, production of O-O programmes to client specification, in class tests and skills based assessments.
course.learningOutcome:
Possible Further Study (subject to availability)

  • Postgraduate study in a relevant field
  • Cisco CCNP Routing & Switching vendor certification
  • CCNA Security Certification
  • BCS Foundation Certificate in Agile curriculum

Possible Careers

  • Network Security Specialist
  • Network Engineer Manager
  • Network Technician Manager
  • Software Engineer
  • Analyst Programmer
  • Systems Analyst
  • Web Developer
  • Database Developer
  • Agile Project Manager
  • Teacher
course.mlo:objective:
You will study an individual 40 credit Honours Project module, together with a common core of 60 credits.  These include

  • E-Business for the Entrepreneur
  • Digital Forensics
  • Agile Methods
  • Cloud Computing & Security

There are a further 20 credits of electives for you to choose, from either the Advanced Networking or Advanced Object Oriented Programming. The design of the course content is informed by and supported by national and local industry.

Study will be through formal lectures, tutor led seminars, blended learning and self-directed research and study. There will be practical workshops in computer suites and in the Cisco Networking Lab.
course.mlo:prerequisite: FdSc or HND in appropriate subject.  Applicants are assessed and a short bridging course to make up for any shortfall in required skills and knowledge may be required.

presentation.dc:subject: Information & Communication Technology
presentation.dc:title: BSc (Hons) Computing Technologies (Full Time Top-up)
presentation.mlo:assessment: Assessment is by means of written reports, presentations, case studies, production of O-O programmes to client specification, in class tests and skills based assessments.

CE:cost.dc:description: For information on fee payment options please contact our Enquiries Team.

CE:FundingCriteria.CE:criteria: You have achieved a Full Level 3 (A-Levels, NVQ Level 3, Etc) qualification.
You must have been ordinarily resident in the UK or the European Union (EU) or the European Economic Area (EEA) continuously for at least the previous three years on 31st July 2013.

course.dc:description:
The MSc Equitation Science is the first and currently only dedicated full taught masters In Equitation Science.  The ethos that underlines this MSc is to provide you with the knowledge and skills to be able to promote and encourage the application of objective research and advanced practice which will ultimately improve the welfare of horses in their associations with humans.

The MSc Equitation Science is a higher-level qualification that will allow those with a good knowledge of equine science to further develop and focus their skills and to advance their knowledge of the practice and science underpinning equitation.

All of the modules on the course are continuously updated to incorporate recent research findings and will allow you to examine and evaluate current thinking.

This programme offers you the opportunity to study a specific aspect of equitation practice in detail and depth.  After completing the taught modules you will then undertake a final three-month research project of your choice culminating in the submission of a dissertation. 

This programme offers you the opportunity to study a subject that truly inspires and engages you. You will advance and expand your skills in a supportive and personal environment. You will be taught by staff who are not only academically acclaimed and well connected on an international level, but are also accessible and genuinely interested in helping you to develop your potential and achieve personal goals.  Through the staff you will also have access to specialist equitation science equipment and international level research ideas and findings to enhance your learning and future employability.

A Part-Time route is also available.

Full Time route

Year 1

BIO5131  - Postgraduate Research Skills and Methods

CORD402 - Contemporary Issues in Equitation Science

CORD403 - Ethical and Sustainable Equitation

CORD404 - Horse-Human Interaction

CORD405 - Technological developments and applications in Equitation Science

CORD406 - Equine Nutrition and Management

BIO505    - Research Project (Dissertation)

 

 

 

 

Part Time route

Year 1

BIO5131  - Postgraduate Research Skills and Methods

CORD403 - Ethical and Sustainable Equitation

CORD404 - Horse-Human Interaction

Year 2

CORD402 - Contemporary Issues in Equitation Science

CORD405 - Technological Developments and Applications in Equitation Science

CORD406 - Equine Nutrition and Management

Year 3

BIO505 -   Research Project (Dissertation)
You will have support from the Programme Manager and module delivery staff as required.
course.dc:subject: Equine
course.dc:title: MSc Equitation Science
course.abstract: A course for anyone wishing to understand horse training and welfare
course.learningOutcome:
Successful completion of this programme will allow students to apply for post graduate positions within the equine and wider animal science industry.  MSc graduates will also be eligible to apply for relevant PhD positions within the science sector.

Possible careers include:

  • Equine behaviour consultant
  • Equine industry advisor
  • Equine management
  • Lecturer/Teacher
  • Trainer
  • Researcher
  • Welfare organisation
  • Equine charity
  • Equine competition
  • Equine management
  • Training and rehabilitiation
Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression. Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm) Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective: As a MSc student you will quickly appreciate the importance of a multidisciplinary approach to this complex and continually developing area.  As a full-time student, you will study six taught modules covering key aspects of equitation science including equine behaviour, training, psychology, welfare, human attributes and technological developments.  Whilst undertaking the programme you will also gain a thorough appreciation of ethical and sustainable equitation and examine contemporary issues that emerge within equitation science whilst you are studying.
course.mlo:prerequisite: BSc (Hons) in equine related programme, minimum of a 2ii classification

CE:cost.dc:description: Please call our Enquiries Team for more details on this course.

course.dc:description:
This BSc (Hons) in Equitation Science focuses on the unique, varied and exciting area of equitation science and is designed for those who wish to further their knowledge of equitation and horse welfare.  This course continually appraises and evaluates aspects of equitation that have become established over many years. Emphasis is placed on developing an ability to critically evaluate equestrian practice, in particular in relation to training and equitation in order to advance practice within equestrianism. This programme will provide you with access to the latest research findings from all over the world.

Students undertaking this Bachelors programme will be able to rise to challenge of dealing with and solving equid-related physical, behavioural and psychological problems exhibited in novel contexts on both a theoretical and practical basis.   Graduating students will possess advanced research skills and be proficient in addressing unique questions and challenging situations.   BSc (Hons) Equitation Science graduates will be capable of both advanced practice and advanced scholarship, and will be capable of further independent research in areas such as training techniques and equid welfare with any equestrian discipline and at any level.

The programme includes a substantial honours project enabling students to carry out a detailed investigation of an area of their choice within the equitation science discipline. Where appropriate, projects will also be supported by industry professionals and leading international equitation science practitioners. Other areas covered in this programme include equitation science, veterinary issues, advanced equine learning and psychology, the science of rider performance and personal development within the equestrian sphere.

FULL-TIME

YEAR 1

Personal and Employability Skills Development

Equine Anatomy

Animal Welfare and Legislation

Principles of Behaviour and Training

Animal Biology

Equine Business Management

Evidence-Based Communication in the Equine Industry

YEAR 2

Principles of Equitation Science

Application of Training Principles

Research Methods

Equine Business and Resource Management

Equine Nutrition and Physiology

Equine Health and Rehabilitation

YEAR 3

Honours Project

This BSc (Hons) Equitation Science progamme benefits from well-established connections with local, national and international equine organisations and practitioners, providing excellent opportunities for students to develop the knowledge, skills and links necessary for employment in the field.  you will be taught by staff who are proven experienced and active equitation science practitioners who have established track records within their particular equitation discipline.

Comprehensive academic and pastoral support is available and you will also benefit from some small group teaching delivered by readily accessible staff .
course.dc:subject: Equine
course.dc:title: BSc (Hons) Equitation Science
course.abstract: A course designed to support and enhance the welfare of horses in modern equestrian through evidence based research
course.learningOutcome:
The programme allows you to develop a wide range of academic, personal and transferable skills which enable you to be effective in various areas of employment. On graduating you will have gained a comprehensive knowledge of the principles of equitation science. You will be confident in the application of these principles in order to effectively facilitate the management of horses and humans in both performance and non-performance capacities.   Possible careers include:  

  • Equine behaviour consultant
  • Equine industry advisor
  • Equine management
  • Lecturer/Teacher
  • Trainer
  • Researcher
  • Welfare organisation
  • Equine charity
  • Equine competition
  • Equine management
  • Training and rehabilitiation
  • Working alongside veterinary professionals
course.mlo:objective:
Throughout the programme students will have the opportunity to become involved in both pure and applied research identified by the International Society for Equitation Science across all modules. In addition there will be opportunities to continue the development of personal and professional skills and periods of work-related learning in industry are also strongly encouraged and closely supported. BSc (Hons) Equitation Science students will be recognised for their ability to research both established and emerging issues within the equestrian industry.

This BSc (Hons) Equitation Science programme  has been developed specifically to align with the the misison of the International Society for Equitation Science and to produce employable gradauates who are able to conduct objective research in order to address welfare- and practice-  based questions arising within the global equestrian industry.   Throughout the programme students are encourage to develop a high level of autonomy, allowed to pursue their own areas of interests and desired career paths includin advanced practice, research and level 7 study and supported to input directly into the application of equitation sceince within novel scenarios and contexts at local to international levels.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
240 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma.   Access to HE Diplomas.  GCSEs at grade C or above in English language and mathematics are required. 

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

If you are unsure of your suitability please call us on 0845 60 50 455 or email: enquiries@duchy.ac.uk.

The Access to Higher Education Diploma is a nationally recognised qualification that provides students with the entry requirements for most higher education degrees. It consists of a minimum of 20 units of study which include Study Skills, English and Maths GCSE equivalences, ICT and a range of subject specific units. As a part of this course students will also be provided with tutorial guidance which focuses on UCAS applications, preparing your finances for university study. Although this is essentially a progression course into university study, many of our learners use this learning opportunity to prepare for the world of work and possibly part time Foundation degree (Fda) engagement. The college study time is designed around people with family/work commitments i.e. start times are in line with school start times.

The Access to Higher Education Diploma is a nationally recognised qualification that provides students with the entry requirements for most higher education degrees. It consists of a minimum of 20 units of study which include Study Skills, English and Maths GCSE equivalences, ICT and a range of subject specific units. As a part of this course students will also be provided with tutorial guidance which focuses on UCAS applications, preparing your finances for university study. Although this is essentially a progression course into university study, many of our learners use this learning opportunity to prepare for the world of work and be a good progression route into higher education. The college study time is designed around people with family/work commitments i.e. start times are in line with school start times.

On the access course you will have the opportunity to get support with your academic studies; you will be able to recieved support for a range of people and facilities. This includes support from the Learning Resourse Centre as well as support for tutors to help facilitate your leanring.  support will also be avalible during some of the colleges holidays.

Some applicants may be eligible for financial support on this course to assist with childcare, transport etc. The Learner Support Fund is under review and is determined by individual circumstances.

If you are under 24 years of age, you may be eligible for fee remission. Information will be given within the workshops, however if your require more information contact the college your applying for and speak to one of the administration tutors for further details.

course.abstract: Access to HE
course.learningOutcome: This course will prepare you for study at HNC or HND, Foundation Degree or Honours Degree level in any creative subject of your choice. Many courses at this level are also available at Cornwall College at our Camborne site.
course.mlo:objective: Use this learning opportunity to prepare for the world of work and possibly part time Foundation degree (Fda) engagement.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no specific entry requirements, applicants are invited to a presentation/workshop which will give full details of the course content and study demands. You will be asked to bring portfolio evidence of any work you have done previously. Applicants will be required to complete an initial assessment to identify any support needs.

presentation.dc:description:
Entry requirements

All applicants will be invited to attend an Access Workshop where full course information is given and you will be expected to complete the Initial Assessment and a written exercise. You will also be given a questionnaire which needs to be returned before interview.

All applicants need to successfully complete the online and written Initial Assessments to the required standard.You will then be invited in on a separate date for a one to one interview.

What will I do on the course?

You will study a range of units each having the potential to be awarded at level 3 (equivalent to A level). Each unit is worth 3 credits. For successful completion of the access course you will need a minimum of 60 credits at level 3.  Each unit at level 3 is awarded a pass, merit or distinction. Along with your core subject units you will study a range of subjects that build and prepare you for academic study at university level. If you require a higher grade at GCSE English and / or Maths you will be able to study for this alognside your main Access to HE Diploma.

Assessment

You will be assessed using a range of methods including placement, academic essays, reports and presentations.

Access courses are designed as a stepping stone to enable motivated, enthusiastic people to progress on to Higher Education. This is ideal for those who want to re-train or re-direct their lives . There is a very high level of academic and personal support throughout the course, which can help if you need to combine study with part-time employment and family commitments.

course.dc:description:
This qualification is primarily aimed at practising electricians with relevant experience and

other allied professionals eg surveyors, consultants and other trades needing to update and

enhance their understanding of IEE Wiring Regulations. It is also suitable for anyone wishing

to demonstrate an understanding of the IEE 17th Edition Wiring Regulations (BS7671).

This course runs over ten half-day sessions.
course.dc:title: Requirements for Electrical Installations BS7671: June 2008(2015) (QCF) EMTA Award Level 3
course.learningOutcome: Upon successful completion of this course you will then be able to progress on to further electrical quaifications.
course.mlo:objective:
The course will cover the following topics:

Introduction and structure of BS 7671

Part 1 Scope, object and fundamental principles

Part 2 Definitions

Part 3 Assessment of general characteristics

Part 4 Protection for safety

Part 5 Selection and erection of equipment

Part 6 Inspection and testing

Part 7 Special installations or locations
course.mlo:prerequisite:
There are no formal requirements, but it is expected that you will have a working

knowledge of electrical installation practices and some experience in the industry. Please

enquire if you are at all unsure about whether this is a suitable course for your needs.

course.dc:description:
Boost your career, start to learn a new trade or just pick up some handy DIY skills.

This course will allow you to build your skills CV and gain a recognised qualification while training around work and family commitments at the weekend.

Learn practical skills in the workshops at Cornwall College Camborne and work with experienced tutors to achieve a new qualification.

Each course is the equivalent of one unit of the City and Guilds qualification and is the ideal length for you to get a real taste of college life, while working on projects ranging from building chimneys and tiling roofs, to creating your very own piece of furniture.

Call us now on 0800 731 7594 to find out how to book your place.

course.learningOutcome: After completing Saturday Skills you may wish to continue on another part-time or full-time course, or put your skills into practice in the workplace.
course.mlo:objective:
During the ten weeks you will learn the basic skills in your chosen craft as well as health and safety practices in the workshop.

Areas covered include:

  • Introduction to basic tools and their uses
  • Applying materials to solid backgrounds
  • Plastering techniques including skimming and dot-and-dab
  • Plaster boarding techniques
  • How to render and patch plaster

course.dc:description:
Students will be required to purchase the following items of personal uniform from the suggested supplier or from a supplier of their choice to wear on the course. 

 Cadet Uniform package cost £40 inc VAT consisting of: Assault boots, Soldier 95 trousers, shirt and Ripstop jacket, 2 piece cameo wet weather suit and commando socks. Available from:http://www.britishmilitarysurplus.co.uk/ishop/1069/shopscr43.html

 In addition, a tracksuit and T shirt embroidered with the College Military Academy logo is required and can be purchased from: http://www.plymouthmilitarygifts.com/store/Duchy_College.html Embroidered Track Suit £32.99, embroidered T shirts £4.50.

 Large or expensive items of kit such as Bergens, cooking equipment, tents, sleeping bags etc will be provided by the College.  Students are encouraged to purchase/bring their own sleeping bags etc if they prefer. A refundable deposit of £35 is required for the issue of College kit and equipment.

 There is an additional cost of £55 for the 3 day survival school training course which is delivered by an outside provider and £20 for issue of rations for overnight exerccises.

 

Financial support may be available from the student support fund, details are available from Student Services.

The NCFE Level 2 Diploma for Entry to the Uniformed Services is part of the Cornwall College Military Academy and is designed to prepare potential recruits for entry to the Armed Forces. The programme is portfolio based therefore there are no examinations. All theory and practical assessment will be conducted in the class room or out-doors as suitable. Learners will undertake practical military training and education in order to equip them with the necessary skills to enable them to make decisions on which service to apply for and to prepare them in all respects for initial selection. Alongside the main qualification learners will undertake GCSE or functional skills in English and/or maths dependant on their entry qualifications.
course.dc:subject: Public Services
course.dc:title: Entry to the Uniformed Services NCFE Diploma Level 2
course.abstract: The NCFE Level 2 Diploma for Entry to the Uniformed Services is part of the Cornwall College
course.learningOutcome:
On successful completion of your course you can apply for selection to the Armed Service of your choice. 

Or you can progress to :

  • Entry to the Uniformed Services NCFE Diploma (Military Academy) Level 3
  • Public Services (Uniformed) BTEC Extended Diploma Level 3 (5 x GCSE grade C including English and/or maths are required for this course).
course.mlo:objective:
The aim of this course is to prepare you for Armed Forces selection. You will study a number of units which will improve your overall fitness and stamina levels and equip you with the knowledge and skills to allow you to perform to the best of your ability at the Armed Forces selection centre. 

Units include:

  • Investigate employment in the uniformed services
  • Physical fitness for the uniformed services
  • Develop team working and problem-solving skills
  • Health and safety in the uniformed services
  • Health and hygiene in the uniformed services
  • Carry out map reading and navigation
  • Follow uniformed services routine
  • Exploring equality and diversity for the uniformed services
  • Participate in competitive sports
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal academic entry requirements for this course. However, learners will be expected to be able to work towards GCSE or functional skills in English and/or maths dependant on individual entry qualifications.

course.dc:description:

Contact us for more information.

Ideal if: for anyone wishing to study advanced accounting and wanting to obtain an internationally recognised professional accounting qualification.

You'll need: an existing Level 3 qualification in accounting or book-keeping.

You'll learn: financial team leader skills, including financial statements for limited companies, complex management skills and specialist learning areas.

Expect: to develop more complex accounting knowledge, gain more specialist skills in related areas such as tax.

You'll love: the opportunity to gain additional skills throughout the course, learning report writing skills.

You'll go onto: with relevant work experience qualify for AAT full membership. Complete an accounting qualification with a chartered body.
course.dc:subject: AAT, accounts, accountancy, finance, accountant, technician, ACCA, CIPFA, ICAEW, CMA, level 4, accountancy, finance, legal, finances,
Business, Administration & Law
course.dc:title: Accounting AAT Diploma Level 4
course.abstract: If you would like to further your career in accountancy and want an industry recognised qualification..
course.learningOutcome:
Upon successful completion, you will automatically become an AAT affiliate member and with relevant work experience will qualify for AAT full membership.

You could then complete an accounting qualification with a chartered body offered by Cornwall College:

  • CIMA - Chartered Institute of Management Accountants
  • ACCA - Association of Chartered Certified Accounts

Some chartered bodies will exempt you form certain parts of the syllabus, having covered these during your apprenticeship.

Alternatively, you may wish to enrol in a management course at Cornwall College Business e.g. Leader Management; or a full time business related course at Cornwall College e.g. FdA Business, BA (Hons) Business Enterprise.
course.mlo:objective:
During this qualification, you will learn finance team leader skills e.g. financial statements for limited companies, complex management accounting tasks, management skills and specialist learning areas.

  • Financial Statements of Limited Companies - This unit is concerned with competence in drafting and interpreting the financial statements of limited companies. It ensures that learners understand what information is required to be provided, how it is to be presented to users of the financial statements and how the rules and principles established in IFRS apply to the process of drafting financial statements.

     

  • Accounting Systems and Controls - The purpose of this unit is to ensure that learners know and understand the role of accounting in an organisation, and why internal controls should be in place. They should also be able to recognise systemic weaknesses where errors or fraud may occur. Learners should be able to evaluate an accounting system, or part of a system, (either based on a real situation or on a given scenario), and be able to make recommendations for improvement.

     

  • Management Accounting: Budgeting - Budgets are an essential tool in planning, coordinating, authorising and cost control. Drafting Budgets requires new skills to create appropriate forecasts and budgets for a wide range of activities and circumstances; to agree the budgets with other functional managers and to monitor results against budget and trigger suitable management interventions.

     

  • Management Accounting: Decision and Control - Learners will have the knowledge to be able to use a range of techniques to analyse information on expenditure. They will be able to make judgements to support decision making, planning and control by managers.  Learners will have the skills to collect and analyse information, monitor performance, and present reports to management. 

     

  • Two of the following options will also be covered – the choice will be based on learner demand so not all of the options will be available:

    • Personal Tax

    • Cash and Treasury Management

    • Business Tax

    • Credit Management

    • External Audit
course.mlo:prerequisite:
To enrol on this course you should have completed the AAT Level 3 Advanced Diploma in Accounting.

A commitment to study outside college attendance is important. 

If you are interested in this course and do not have the required qualification, contact us to discuss your options further.

course.mlo:objective:
The Level 2 Award in Computerised Payroll is made up of the following:

  • Understand potential health and safety and security risks
  • Maintain the security of data within a computerised environment
  • Understand organisational procedures for processing payroll in a computerised environment
  • Understand the statutory requirements for submitting information
  • Be able to process information on starters, leavers and changes to current employees

  • Be able to back up and update systems when required

Candidates are responsible for their own AAT registration and subscription fee.  This will need to be completed as soon as possible after enrolment in order to be entered for exams.

This course will be 1 day or 1 evening per week for 35 weeks duration.  For Apprentices the course will be 1 day per week for 36 weeks, or 1 evening per week for 40 weeks.

Ideal if: You would like to gain an insight into book-keeping and accountancy. The AAT Foundation Certificate in Accounting is suitable for anyone interested in a new career or developing an existing career.

You'll need: an interest in the subject and commitment to study outside of college attendance.

You'll learn: the fundamental knowledge required of financial and cost accounting to progress to studying both in more depth at Level 3. It also includes units designed to ensure that you gain the necessary skills to work in an accounting environment.

Expect: to gain an overall understanding of the underpinning skills required to work in an accounting role and the areas you might wish to specialise in.

You'll love: the opportunity to develop the skills and knowledge for a variety of accountancy based roles and identify the various career pathways that will open for you.

You'll go onto: AAT Level 3 Advanced Diploma in Accounting, gaining a nationally recognised qualification.
course.dc:subject: AAT, accounting, accountancy, finance, accountant, CIPFA, CMA, ICAEW, certificate
Business, Administration & Law
course.dc:title: Accounting AAT Certificate Level 2
course.abstract: If you would like to start a career in accountancy and want an industry recognised qualification..
course.learningOutcome: Upon successful completion, you can progress onto the AAT Level 3 Advanced Diploma in Accounting by Cornwall College.
course.mlo:objective:
You will develop the necessary knowledge and skills to enable you to understand and use a cost recording system within an organisation, including it's use for recording or extracting data and using spreadsheets to provide information on budgeted income and expenditure.

•Bookkeeping Transactions - This unit looks in more detail at the cash book and petty cash book and introduces the reconciliation of control accounts. You will also be required to make adjustments through the journal and re-draft the initial trial balance once adjustments have been made.

•Bookkeeping Controls - Deals with documents that are sent to and from organisations, and to code and file those documents appropriately. You will need to know how to make entries in sales, purchases and returns day books, and to transfer those totals, and cash book and petty cash book totals, to the sales, purchases and general ledgers.

•Work Effectively in Finance - This unit is about gaining a range of transferable skills which will enable you to work effectively within an accounting environment. This will include gaining an insight into how your role interacts with others and how you are expected to communicate within business with effective results.

•Using Accounting Software- This unit is about using a computerised accounting application to input and process data for business transactions including sales and purchases, receipts and payments, and to prepare management and period end reports.

•Elements of Costing- You will learn to recognise the need to build a sound foundation in costing to give you the relevant knowledge and skills to take forward as well as the importance of the costing system as a source of information for internal management decision making as contrasted with financial accounting which looks outwards.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
To enrol on this course you need to be aged 18 and over, have a minimum of 5 GCSEs at Grade C (ideally in English and Maths).

You must enjoy working in an office environment and be good with numbers.

Given the entry requirements and experience required for this course we have found it may not be suitable for those aged 16 - 18.

Please enquire if you are at all unsure as to your suitability and the course manager will be happy to discuss the course and its content with you.

A commitment to study outside college attendance is important.

course.dc:description: The course is offered as a one session per week:  September to July 2pm to 6pm at the Truro Business Space

Ideal if: you are wishing to start working towards this highly regarded, internationally recognised, professional accountancy qualification.

You'll need: either passes or exemption from the CIMA Certificate in Business Accounting (exemption available if completed AAT Level 4 Diploma in Accounting)

You'll learn:  In depth knowledge in areas of core accounting skills, ‘Big Data’, sustainability, integrated reporting and finance function transformation. Risk, as well as costing and cost management.

Expect: to develop business acumen and core accounting skills that management accountants need to drive business success.

You'll love:  that the real-life skills and competencies employers need are woven into the syllabus.   

You'll go onto:  CIMA Advanced Diploma in Management Accounting.

ENTERPRISE PILLAR

E1 Organisational Management

  • Introduction to organisations
  • Managing the finance function
  • Managing technology and information
  • Operations management
  • Marketing
  • Managing human resources

 PERFORMANCE PILLAR

P1 Management Accounting

  • Cost accounting systems
  • Budgeting
  • Short-term decision making
  • Dealing with risk and uncertainty

 FINANCIAL PILLAR

F1 Financial Reporting and Taxation

  • Regulatory environment for financial reporting and corporate governance
  • Financial accounting and reporting
  • Management of working capital, cash and sources of short-term finance
  • Fundamentals of business taxation
course.dc:subject: Business, Administration & Law
course.dc:title: Management Accounting CIMA Diploma Level 5
course.abstract: If you would like to progress your career in accountancy and want an industry recognised qualification...
course.learningOutcome:
Study the CIMA Advanced Diploma in Management Accounting.

The CIMA qualification offers the opportunity to work in a diverse range of business sectors, from the public to private sector, or pursuing a career in business. Management accounting qualifications are a passport to a rewarding career and CIMA leads to an international transferable qualification.
course.mlo:objective:
The CIMA qualification is frequently revised to keep up with the latest business trends and employer needs.

 Learners study subjects across three pillars.

  • The enterprise pillar
  • The performance pillar
  • The financial pillar

CIMA holders add value to your business by blending financial expertise with business insight.

Translate complex information and communicate it effectively, guiding critical business decisions and creating sustainable business success. (cimaglobal.com/CIMA-in-business/How-MA-supports-your-business-/)
course.mlo:prerequisite: Learners should hold either passes or exemption from the CIMA Certificate in Business Accounting, if you have recently qualified as an AAT Accounting Technician you are able to claim exemption from this. For information regarding exemptions please visit the CIMA website http://www.cimaglobal.com/exemptions

course.dc:description:

You'll need:  to have successfully completed the CIMA Diploma in Management Accounting (operational level)

You'll learn:  In depth knowledge in areas of core accounting skills, 'Big Data', sustainability, integrated reporting and finance function transformation. Risk, as well as costing and cost management.

Expect: to develop business acumen and core accounting skills that management accountants need to drive business success.

You'll love:  that the real-life skills and competencies employers need are woven into the syllabus.   

You'll go onto:  obtain the full CGMA professional qualification.

ENTERPRISE PILLAR

E2 Project and Relationship Management

  • Introduction to strategic management and assessing the global environment.
  • The human aspect of the organisation, managing relationships.
  • Managing change through projects.

PERFORMANCE PILLAR

P2 Advanced Management Accounting

  • Cost planning and analysis for competitive advantage.
  • Control and performance management of responsibility centres.
  • Long-term decision making.
  • Management control and risk.

 FINANCIAL PILLAR

F2 Advanced Financial Reporting

  • Sources of long-term finance.
  • Financial reporting.
  • Analysis of financial performance and position.
course.dc:subject: Business, Administration & Law
course.dc:title: Management Accounting CIMA Advanced Diploma Level 7
course.abstract: If you would like to progress your career in accountancy and want an industry recognised qualification...
course.learningOutcome:
Study the CIMA Strategic Level papers to obtain the full CGMA professional qualification.

The CIMA qualification offers the opportunity to work in a diverse range of business sectors, from the public to private sector, or pursuing a career in business. Management accounting qualifications are a passport to a rewarding career and CIMA leads to an international transferable qualification.
course.mlo:objective:
The CIMA qualification is frequently revised to keep up with the latest business trends and employer needs.

 Learners study subjects across three pillars.

  • The enterprise pillar
  • The performance pillar
  • The financial pillar

 CIMA holders add value to your business by blending financial expertise with business insight.

Translate complex information and communicate it effectively, guiding critical business decisions and creating sustainable business success. (cimaglobal.com/CIMA-in-business/How-MA-supports-your-business-/)
course.mlo:prerequisite: Learners should have successfully completed the CIMA Diploma in Management Accounting (operational level)

course.dc:description:
Some applicants may be eligible for financial support on this course to assist with childcare, transport etc. The Learner Support Fund is under review and is determined by individual circumstances.

If you are under 24 years of age, you may be eligible for fee remission. Information will be given within the workshops, however if your require more information contact the college your applying for and speak to Student Services for further details.

If you are 24 years of age  or over, please click on this link for funding information and a direct link to the government funding site.

Funding for over 24

The Access to Higher Education Diploma is a nationally recognised qualification thatprovides students with the entry requirements for most higher education degrees. Itconsists of a minimum of 20 units of study which include: Study Skills, ICT and a wide rangeof subject specific Art & Design units. As a part of this course students will also be providedwith tutorial guidance which focuses on UCAS applications and preparing for universitystudy. There is currently a very large choice of higher level courses in the creative arts.Although this is essentially a progression course into university study, several of ourlearners use this learning opportunity to prepare for the world of work, combined with parttimeFoundation degree Award (FdA) engagement.

The Access course is a 1 year, full time course, especially intended for those people whohave always wanted to study art and design, but have not previously had the chance to doso. The course runs over 3 days (Wed, Thurs & Fri). The college study time is designedaround people with family and, or work commitments i.e. start times are in line with schoolstart times. In addition, students are expected to spend 5 hours a week as home study.

This is a vibrant and exciting course, during the first term you will be introduced to the basic principles of 2D visual language; through drawing, mark-making, mixed media,photography and graphics. At the same time you will be able to develop your knowledge ofthe history of art and design, through illustrated talks and gallery visits. You will also have the opportunity to improve your research and I.T. skills.

In the second term, you will engage in-depth with the exploration of materials, techniques and processes, through drawing, mixed media, Textiles and Ceramics. The assignments will introduce you to concepts and ideas in art and design and how these are connected to the materials and techniques used to communicate ideas for different creative purposes. Additional study skills units run alongside these practical units.

Before the start of the third term you will be encouraged to think about a topic for the Independent Study, which is intended to consolidate all that you have been taught on the course, up to that point. You will be able to choose the topic, materials and techniques to produce a final piece or series of works for presentation in a final exhibition, at the end of the year.

The course will begin in September and end in June, it runs for 3 days a week from Wednesday to Friday (15 hours pr week plus additional study time).

For further details please contact the course manager Bobbie Russell, Cluster Manager, on 01209 617636 or e-mail bobbie.russell@cornwall.co.uk

On the Access course you will have the opportunity to have support with your academic studies; which could include support from the Learning Centre tutors, as well as support from the teaching staff to help facilitate your learning.

If you are under 24 years of age, you may be eligible for fee remission, if you do not hold a level 3 qualification. If you are 24 years of age or over, there is a new 24+ Learners' Loan available.
course.dc:subject: Art Design Graphics Photography Mixed Media Textiles Ceramics.
Arts, Media & Performing Arts
course.dc:title: Art and Design ASCENTIS Access to HE Diploma Level 3
course.abstract: The course will enable you to gain a broad experience of different subjects in art, design and technology.
course.learningOutcome: This course will prepare you for study at HNC or HND, Foundation Degree or Honours Degree level in any creative subject of your choice. Many courses at this level are available at Cornwall College at our Camborne site.
course.mlo:objective: The course will enable you to gain a broad experience of different subjects in art, design and technology. These will include drawing, painting, printmaking, photography, graphic design, 3D work, programming, animation etc.. It will also provide the opportunity to identify the area of specialisation most relevant to your aspirations and ability. There will also be a structured programme of academic studies supported by a general core skills programme that will provide an English GCSE equivalent and prepare you for the demands of higher level study. The core skills will help you develop confidence and improve written and oral communication, as well as provide career planning, research skills and an understanding of art history and information technology.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
There are no specific entry requirements, but you will need to have enthusiasm, commitment and a desire to further your education in the arts. If you wish to apply you will need to bring along a portfolio, of work, to an informal interview. This could contain any of the following: drawing, painting, craft work, photography, sculpture etc. Applicants will be required to complete an initial assessment to identify any support needs.

If you would like further information about the course please contact:

Bobbie Russell, Cluster Manager, on 01209 617636 or e-mail bobbie.russell@cornwall.co.uk

course.dc:description:
Are you considering returning to study after a break? Do you want a new career? Were your results not what you had hoped for or have your ideas changed since you made your choices aged 16? Do you wish to study in beautiful Cornwall?! This course is for you if you want to study and work in science and do not currently possess the type, level or currency of qualifications usually required to start a science degree. We welcome applications from learners of all ages, living in the UK, EU or further afield.

This inclusive and intensive course covers core principles in biology and chemistry (with physics modules available for progression to some programmes) and provides ample opportunities to acquire new laboratory and fieldwork techniques. You will refresh key elements of maths essential for higher level study and you will develop your academic study skills to a high level to support success on your chosen degree and beyond. You will learn the method of science, research skills, academic writing and referencing, and presentation skills.
course.dc:subject: Cornwall College
course.dc:title: Extended Science HE Foundation Certificate (Subject to approval)
course.abstract: Science Gateway
course.learningOutcome:
On successful completion you can progress to your chosen science programme with The Cornwall College Group. The course helps you develop the underpinning knowledge and skills needed to succeed on our three-year Bachelor of Science (BSc) and two-year Foundation Science (FdSc) degrees. You will choose your route on applying for this course with no need to complete a new UCAS application for internal progression. Tutors are available throughout the year should your ideas change and you wish to move in a different direction. There are a small number of agreed progression routes to science degree programmes at Plymouth University and should you wish to apply to another university your UCAS application will be treated similarly to those of Access to Higher Education learners.


Progression is possible to approximately 25 different science courses at seven different campuses within The Cornwall College Group including:


FdSc Forensic Science (Camborne)
FdSc Zoological Conservation (Newquay)
FdSc Wildlife Education & Media (Newquay)
FdSc Animal Husbandry & Welfare (Newquay
FdSc Animal Behaviour & Psychology (Newquay)
FdSc Conservation & Ecology (Newquay)
FdSc Marine Science (Falmouth Marine School)
FdSc Aquaculture & Fisheries Science (Falmouth Marine School)
FdSc Marine Conservation (Newquay)
FdSc Renewable Energy Technologies (Eden Project)* subject to approval
FdSc Conservation & Countryside Management (Duchy Rosewarne)
FdSc Agriculture (Duchy Stoke Climsland)                            
FdSc Animal Health & Management (Duchy Stoke Climsland / Bicton College)
FdSc Surf Science and Technology (Newquay)
BSc (Hons) Marine Sports Science (Newquay)
BSc (Hons) Applied Marine Zoology (Newquay)
BSc (Hons) Applied Zoology & Conservation (Newquay)
BSc (Hons) Renewable Energy & Carbon Management (Camborne)
BSc (Hons) Agriculture & Food (Duchy Stoke Climsland)
BSc (Hons) Plant Science (Eden Project)
BSc (Hons) Equitation Science (Duchy Stoke Climsland)
FdSc Veterinary Nursing (Duchy Rosewarne)
FdSc Equitation Training & Behaviour (Duchy Stoke Climsland)
course.mlo:objective: You will learn through attending lectures, workshops, group and 1-to-1 tutorials, practical and field classes. You will be assessed through a mixture of formal examinations, in-class tests, practical assessments and through production of coursework including laboratory reports. You will give poster and oral presentations and will benefit from the opportunity to attend guest lectures and seminars given by academics, representatives from industry and research students.
course.mlo:prerequisite: The course is designed to provide an inclusive route into Higher Education and as such attracts applicants from a variety of different backgrounds. For this reason we interview all applicants to assess their suitability, which will include initial assessment. Applicants will usually possess GCSEs (or equivalent) at grade C or above in English and Maths, but it is possible to complete one GCSE alongside the course with suitability assessed at interview. Suitability of mature applicants with no formal qualifications but with relevant experience will be assessed through interview. IELTS 6.0 overall is required for international applicants.

course.dc:description:
All applicants will be requried to undertake a minimum of 2 half days or 1 full day per week work palcement throughout the duration of the course.  Learners will be visited in the workplacment by an Assessor who will undertake observation of working practice.

all applicants will be required to have a clear DBS check prior to enrolment.  DBS may be applied for through the college at a cost of £44.

This course is for volunteers or existing teaching assistants in Primary, Secondary or Special schools who are working under the direction of the class teacher. They will contribute to planning, implementing and evaluating learning activities and will work alongside the teacher to support whole class activities, as well as working on their own with individuals or groups of pupils.
course.dc:subject: Teaching Assistant, TA, Support, Schools, Primary, Secondary, Children,
The School of Education and Professional Development
course.dc:title: Supporting Teaching and Learning in Schools CG Certificate Level 3
course.abstract: For volunteers or existing teaching assistants in Primary, Secondary or Special schools
course.learningOutcome: Upon successful completion of this course, you may be able to gain employment as a teaching assistant. Having gained sufficient school experience you will have the opportunity to progress onto the Foundation Degree for Children and Young Peoples Workforce.
course.mlo:objective:
You will attend a weekly class at one of our campuses, and carry out some home study alongside your work in the classroom. You will need to be able to spend 1-2 hours per week building your portfolio. You will be offered regular tutorial support.

You will work towards nationally recognised units from the QCF (Qualifications and Credit Framework) to achieve the Level 3 Certificate in Supporting Teaching and Learning in Schools. Taught sessions will cover key aspects, including:

  • Supporting learning activities
  • Promoting children and young people's positive behaviour
  • Supporting assessment for learning
  • Understanding child and young person development
  • Understanding how to safeguard the wellbeing of children and young people
  • Promoting Equality Diversity and Inclusion
  • Developing professional relationships with children, young people and adults
  • Schools as organisations
  • Communication and professional relationships
course.mlo:prerequisite:
Support staff will need to have sufficient language, literacy and numeracy skills at the level required to support pupils' learning.  Relevant skills and attributes include:

  • Experience of working in a school
  • Interest and commitment to working with children and/or young people
  • Ability to relate well to children, young people and adults
  • Willing to reflect on your own practice, learn and apply that learning in the workplace

You must provide a positive check through the Disclosure & Barring Service.
